en: Hello!
notes: A universal polite greeting

en: Thank you.
Goodbye.
enAlt: Stay in peace.
notes: Used if you are leaving and the other person is staying.

en: Goodbye.
enAlt: Go in peace.
notes: Used if the other person is leaving.

en: I apologize.
enAlt: I'm sorry.
notes: Say this if it's your fault, don't say this if you just hear bad news.

en: Excuse me!
enAlt: Hey you, over there!
notes: This is a polite way to get someone's attention.

en: It's water.
notes: 물 - water, 이에요 - is.

en: It's a bag.
notes: 가방 - bag, 이에요 - is

en: It's me.
notes: 저 - me, 예요 - is. When the noun ends in a vowel, 이에요 turns into 예요.

en: This is a book.
notes: 이 - this, 것 (거) - thing, 책 - book

en: This is a camera.
notes: 카메라 - camera

en: What is this?
notes: 뭐 - what, 이거 - this

en: This is water.
notes: 물 - water

en: Yes, that's right.
enAlt: Yes, that's correct.
notes: 네 - yes, 맞다 - to be correct, 아요 - present tense ending

en: It's not milk.
notes: 우유 - milk, 아니에요 - is not

en: I'm not a student.
notes: 저 - I, 학생 - student, 아니에요 - am not

en: It's not a cat.
enAlt: That's not a cat.
notes: 고양이 - cat, 그거 - something that is close to the listener, not to the speaker, or something that can't be seen at all.

en: Your voice is good.
enAlt: I like her voice.
notes: 목소리 - voice, 좋다 - to be good, to like. The person whose voice is being discussed isn't mentioned because it's usually clear from the context.

en: I have water.
enAlt: There is water.
notes: 물 - water, 있다 - to exist, to have

en: Do you have time?
enAlt: Do we have time?
notes: 시간 - time, 있다 - to have

en: There is no party.
notes: 파티 - party, 없다 - to not exist

en: No, it's not fun.
enAlt: No, it's not interesting.
notes: This use of 네 means that the previous speaker also said something similar and the current speaker is agreeing.

en: I don't have an apple.
enAlt: There are no apples.
notes: 사과 - apple, 없다 - to not have, not exist

en: Please give me some beer.
enAlt: I'd like a beer, please.
notes: 맥주 - beer, 주다 - to give. The 'please' aspect is included in the honorific ending -세요.

en: Please give me an ice cream.
enAlt: I'd like an ice cream, please.
notes: 아이스크림 - ice cream, 주다 - to give

en: Please give me some kimchi.
notes: 김치 - traditional Korean food

en: I'm American.
notes: 저 - I, 는 - topic marking particle, 미국 - America, 사람 - person, 이에요 - am

en: Are you a [medical] doctor?
notes: 의사 - doctor, 예요 - are

en: Are you Korean?
notes: 한국 - Korea, 사람 - person

en: Jeongmin Kim is a student.
notes: 김정민 - Jeongmin Kim, 씨 - polite term of address, 는 - topic marking particle, 학생 - student

en: Nice to meet you.
enAlt: Literally: I'm meeting you therefore I am glad.
notes: 만나다 - to meet, 반갑다 - to be glad, 서 - therefore

en: My major is economics.
notes: 제 - my, 전공 - major, 은 - topic marking particle, 경제학 - economics

en: Chris is an English teacher.
notes: 크리스 - Chris, 씨 - polite term of address, 는 - topic marking particle, 영어 - English, 선생님 - teacher

en: It's delicious.
enAlt: It tastes good.
notes: 맛 - taste, 있다 - to exist

en: Kimbap is delicious.
notes: 김밥 - Korean food, 맛있다 - to be tasty

en: It tastes bad.
enAlt: It's tasteless.
notes: 맛 - taste, 없다 - to not have

en: Please give me some more (of it).
enAlt: I'd like more, please.
notes: 더 - more

en: It's over.
enAlt: It has finished.
notes: 끝나다 - to end; this is the simple past form

en: Yes, okay.
enAlt: Yes, it's good.
notes: 좋다 - to be good

en: It's unnecessary.
enAlt: There's no need.
notes: 필요 - need, 없다 - to not exist

en: Throw it away.
notes: 버리다 - to throw away

en: It's easy.
notes: 쉽다 - to be easy

en: I eat.
enAlt: We're eating.
notes: 먹다 - to eat

en: I watch.
enAlt: I'm watching.
notes: 보다 - to watch, to see

en: It's simple.
notes: 간단하다 - to be simple

en: I love all of you.
enAlt: Everyone, I love you.
notes: 여러분 - everyone (when directly addressing people), 사랑하다 - to love

en: Let's study together.
notes: 같이 - together, 공부하다 - to study

en: Where are we?
enAlt: Where is this place?
notes: 여기 - here, 어디 - where. Koreans tend to ask "Where is here?" instead of "Where are we?"

en: I eat a meal.
enAlt: He eats a meal.
notes: 밥 - meal, 을 - object marking particle

en: I drink tea.
enAlt: Drink some tea.
notes: 차 - tea, 마시다 - to drink, 를 - object marking particle

en: I read a book in the library.
enAlt: He's reading a book in the library.
notes: 도서관 - library, 에서 - location marking particle, 책 - book, 을 - object marking particle, 읽다 - to read

en: Where is the closet?
notes: 옷장 - closet, 은 - topic marking particle, 어디 - where, 에 - location marking particle, 있어요 - is

en: It was warm yesterday.
notes: 어제 - yesterday, 따뜻하다 - to be warm

en: They are different.
enAlt: It's different.
notes: 다르다 - to be different

en: I went to school.
enAlt: They went to school.
notes: 학교 - school, 에 - location marking particle, 가다 - to go

en: I came to Korea.
enAlt: She came to Korea.
notes: 한국 - Korea, 에 - location marking particle, 오다 - to come

en: Where are you now?
notes: 지금 - now, 어디 - where

en: I'm at home.
enAlt: We're at home.
notes: 집 - home

en: I work at the office.
notes: 사무실 - office, 일하다 - to work

en: This (here) is my house.
notes: Koreans use "our" instead of "my" to describe things like house, school, family members. 여기 - here, 우리 - we/our, 집 - house

en: I study in the room.
notes: 저 - I, 방 - room, 공부하다 - to study

en: When did you do it?
notes: 언제 - when, 하다 - to do

en: When did you arrive?
enAlt: When did she arrive?
notes: 언제 - when, 도착하다 - to arrive

en: When do you get up in the morning?
notes: 일어나다 - to get up, 아침 - morning, 에 - time/location marking particle

en: I am ten years old.
enAlt: He is ten years old.
notes: 열 - ten, 살 - a counter for years

en: I am 20 years old.
notes: You remove the ㄹ from 스물 if it's followed by a counter

en: I'm not going home.
enAlt: I don't go home.
notes: 집 - home, 안 - not, 가다 - to go

en: Aren't you going home?
enAlt: Doesn't he go home?
notes: 안 - negation, not

en: I didn't throw it away yet.
notes: 그거 - it, 아직 - yet, 안 - not, 버리다 - to throw away

en: It doesn't hurt.
enAlt: I'm not sick.
notes: 아프다 - to be sick

en: I'm not eating. I'm not hungry.
notes: 먹다 - to eat, 배 고프다 - to be hungry

en: I don't know.
notes: 모르다 - to not know

en: I don't eat apples.
enAlt: He doesn't eat apples.
notes: 사과 - apple

en: This food is very spicy.
enAlt: This food is too spicy.
notes: 이 - this, 음식 - food, 너무 - too, 맵다 - to be spicy

en: I prepare food in the kitchen.
notes: 부엌 - kitchen, 에서 - location marking particle, 음식 - food, 만들다 - to make

en: Is there a telephone in the room?
notes: 방 - room, 전화 - telephone, 가 - subject marking particle

en: No, it's not a desk.
notes: 아니요 - no, 책상 - desk, 이 - subject marking particle

en: I really worked out.
enAlt: I really did some exercises.
notes: 진짜 - really, 운동 - sports, exercise

en: This is not a refrigerator.
notes: 이거 - this, 냉장고 - refrigerator

en: There is no closet.
notes: 옷장 - closet, 이 - subject marking particle

en: The bag is in the classroom.
notes: 가방 - bag, 교실 - classroom

en: Sally is not at home.
notes: 샐리 - Sally, 집 - home

en: Who is it?
enAlt: Who's there?
notes: This expression is used when you hear someone knocking on your door

en: How much is this?
enAlt: How much does this one cost?
notes: 얼마 - how much (money)

en: How much is that one?
notes: 얼마 - how much (money)

en: How much did you pay?
notes: 얼마 - how much (money), 내다 - to pay

en: Do you like this book?
notes: 이 - this, 책 - book, 좋아하다 - to like

en: Did you find your wallet?
notes: 지갑 - wallet, 찾다 - to find

en: It rained today.
notes: 오늘 - today, 비 - rain, 오다 - to come

en: I stayed at home.
notes: The verb '있다' means 'to stay' in this case

en: I'm studying French.
enAlt: He studies French.
notes: 프랑스어 - the French language, 공부하다 - to study, 를 - object marking particle

en: I eat a lot of Kimchi.
notes: 김치 - kimchi, 많이 - a lot, 먹다 - to eat

en: Where are you going?
notes: 에 - 'direction towards' marking particle

en: It's Wednesday.
notes: 수요일 - Wednesday

en: I meet her on Saturday.
enAlt: Let's meet on Saturday.
notes: 토요일 - Saturday, 에 - time marking particle, 만나다 - to meet

en: I don't drink coffee.
notes: 커피 - coffee, 안 - not, 마시다 - to drink

en: I'm not going to school today.
notes: 오늘 - today, 학교 - school

en: Do you exercise on weekends?
notes: 주말 - weekend, 운동하다 - to exercise

en: No, I don't exercise.
notes: 아니요 - no, 운동 - exercise

en: I have a younger sister.
enAlt: Lit: As for me, a younger sister exists.
notes: 여동생 - younger sister

en: I don't have a hobby.
notes: 취미 - hobby

en: I live in Seoul.
notes: 서울 - Seoul, 살다 - to live

en: I didn't work yesterday.
notes: 어제 - yesterday, 일 - work

en: It’s really strange.
notes: 정말 - really, 이상하다 - to be strange

en: It’s very far away.
notes: 아주 - very (mostly for the written language), 멀다 - to be far

en: Apples were expensive.
notes: 사과 - apple, 비싸다 - to be expensive

en: I cleaned my room.
notes: 방 - room, 청소하다 - to clean

en: A friend of mine called (on the phone).
notes: 친구 - friend, 전화하다 - to make a phone call

en: I taught English.
notes: 영어 - English, 가르치다 - to teach

en: I drank juice.
notes: 주스 - juice, 마시다 - to drink

en: I listened to music.
notes: 듣다 - to listen. In some (most) verbs, the final ㄷ of the verb stem changes to ㄹ if the attached ending starts with a vowel.

en: What's this?
notes: 무엇 - the unshortened form of '뭐', -ㅂ니까 - the formal style question ending, 이다 - to be

en: It's a chair.
notes: 의자 - chair

en: Are you a student?
notes: 학생 - student

en: I don't have a car.
notes: 차 - car

en: How much is the book?
enAlt: How much does the book cost?

en: What's your phone number?
notes: 전화번호 - phone number

en: Do you have any questions?
notes: 질문 - question, 있다 - to have

en: It's good.
enAlt: I like it.
notes: 좋다 - to be good

en: Yes, I'm going to school.
notes: 학교 - school

en: Do you exercise?
notes: 운동하다 - to exercise

en: Yes, I exercise.
I love you, Carol.
notes: 사랑하다 - to love

en: What is Minu's job?
notes: 직업 - job

en: What's your name?
notes: 이름 - name

en: They go to church (regularly).
enAlt: They attend church.
notes: 교회 - church, 다니다 - to attend

en: I'm going to the department store.
notes: 백화점 - department store

en: No, she isn't coming.
notes: 오다 - to come

en: I know Korean.
notes: 한국말 - Korean, 알다 - to know

en: The room is not spacious.
notes: 방 - room, 넓다 - to be spacious

en: There's Jaejun coming (this way).
notes: 저기 - there (far from the speaker), 오다 - to come

en: Where does it hurt?
notes: '어디' is a noun in Korean so it can be followed by the subject marking particle. Sometimes a more accurate translation is 'which place' or 'what place'.

en: Your tie looks nice.
notes: 넥타이 - tie, 멋있다 - to be cool

en: Thank you.
notes: 고맙다 - to be thankful

en: My older brother is tall.
notes: 형 - older brother, 키 - height, 크다 - to be big

en: My younger brother is short.
enAlt: My younger sister is short.
notes: 동생 - younger sibling, 작다 - to be small, 키 - height

en: What do you study?
notes: 무엇 - what, 배우다 - to learn

en: I'm hungry.
notes: 배 - stomach

en: Hami, are you crying?
notes: 울다 - to cry

en: I help my mother.
notes: 엄마 - mom, 돕다 - to help

en: It is difficult.
notes: 어렵다 - to be difficult

en: It was cold.
notes: 춥다 - to be cold

en: Do you like music?
notes: 음악 - music

en: Manho hasn't got any paper.
notes: 종이 - paper

en: I have a stomachache.
notes: 배 - stomach

en: I have a sore throat.
notes: 목 - throat, neck

en: What did you choose?
enAlt: What did you pick?
notes: 고르다 - to choose

en: When did you cut your hair?
notes: 머리 - hair, 자르다 - to cut

en: This TV series is interesting.
enAlt: This TV show is fun to watch.
notes: 드라마 - TV show

en: Hi!
enAlt: Bye!
notes: This is the casual style greeting.

en: He smiles.
enAlt: They laugh.
notes: 웃다 - to smile, laugh

en: Where's the bathroom?
notes: 화장실 - toilet, bathroom. Question "어디예요?" is normally used when asking about the location of buildings or places that can't be moved (like the bathroom). Otherwise question "어디에 있어요?" is used.

en: I want to go.
notes: 가다 - to go, -고 싶다 - to want to

en: I miss you.
enAlt: I want to see it.
notes: This is a common expression. 보다 - to see, -고 싶다 - to want to

en: What do you want to do?
notes: 뭐 - what (short from 무엇), 하다 - to do, -고 싶다 - to want to

en: I want to watch TV.
enAlt: We want to watch TV.
notes: 텔레비전 - TV

en: I want to watch a movie.
enAlt: She wants to watch a movie.
notes: 영화 - movie

en: I want to buy this.
notes: 이거 - this, 사다 - to buy

en: I want to work.
notes: 일하다 - to work

en: Where do you want to go?
notes: 어디 - where, 가다 - to go

en: I hate it too.
enAlt: I don't want to either.
notes: 저 - I, 도 - too, 싫다 - to hate, be unlikeable

en: I'm at the office, come quickly.
enAlt: I'm at the office, hurry up and come.
notes: 사무실 - office, 빨리 - quickly, 오다 - to come

en: The book is on the desk.
notes: 책 - book, 책상 - desk, 위 - on, above, 에 - location marking particle

en: The apple is under the chair.
notes: 사과 - apple, 의자 - chair, 아래 - below

en: The store is in front of the house.
notes: 가게 - store, 앞 - front

en: The restaurant is behind the library.
notes: 식당 - restaurant, 도서관 - library, 뒤 - behind

en: The computer is next to the TV.
notes: 컴퓨터 - computer, 텔레비전 - TV, 옆 - beside

en: The umbrella is in the bag.
notes: 우산 - umbrella, 가방 - bag, 안 - inside

en: What floor is the restaurant on?
notes: 식당 - restaurant, 몇 - which number, 층 - floor

en: The restaurant is on the fifth floor.
notes: 오 - 5, 층 - floor

en: Who did it?
notes: 누가 = 누구 (who) + 가 (subject marking particle)

en: Who called?
enAlt: Who made the phone call?
notes: 누가 = 누구 (who) + 가, 전화하다 - to make a phone call

en: Who came yesterday?
notes: 어제 - yesterday, 오다 - to come

en: Who made that?
notes: 만들다 - to make

en: Who bought it?
notes: 사다 - to buy

en: I got up at 8 o'clock.
enAlt: I got up at 8 am.
notes: 시 - hour, 에 - time marking particle, 일어나다 - to get up

en: How did you find it?
enAlt: How did he find it?
notes: 어떻게 - how, 찾다 - to look for, to find

en: How did you get here?
enAlt: How did you come here?
notes: 어떻게 - how, 오다 - to come

en: Why did you call?
notes: 왜 - why, 전화하다 - to call on the phone

en: Why didn't you come?
enAlt: Why didn't they come?
notes: 왜 - why, 안 - not

en: How often do you come?
notes: 얼마나 - how, 자주 - often

en: How big is it?
notes: 얼마나 - how, 크다 - to be big

en: How heavy is it?
notes: 얼마나 - how, 무겁다 - to be heavy

en: How long does it take to go from Busan to Seoul?
notes: 부산 - Busan, 에서 - from, 서울 - Seoul, 까지 - to, 얼마나 - how (much), 걸리다 - to take time

en: until now
enAlt: so far
notes: 지금 - now, 까지 - until

en: from here to there
notes: 여기 - here, 저기 - there

en: from head to toe
notes: 머리 - head, 발끝 - the end of foot, tip of toes

en: from morning until evening
notes: 아침 - morning, 저녁 - evening

en: since last Friday
notes: 지난 - last, 금요일 - Friday, 부터 - from, since

en: I'll go tomorrow.
enAlt: I'm going to go tomorrow.
notes: 내일 - tomorrow, 가다 - to go, ㄹ 거예요 - the future tense ending

en: I'll go alone.
enAlt: I'm going to go by myself.
notes: 혼자 - alone

en: What are you going to do?
enAlt: What will you do?
notes: 하다 - to do

en: Are you really going to do it?
notes: 정말 - really

en: I'm going to wear blue jeans.
notes: 청바지 - blue jeans, 입다 - to wear

en: What are you going to wear tomorrow?
notes: 내일 - tomorrow, 입다 - to wear

en: I'm going to wear a t-shirt.
notes: 티셔츠 - t-shirt

en: Who are you going to meet?
notes: 만나다 - to meet

en: When are you going to meet?
Where are you going to sell it?
notes: 팔다 - to sell

en: At what price are you going to sell it?
notes: 얼마에 - at what price

en: How many times a week?
notes: 일주일 - one week, 몇 - how many, 번 - times

en: I met a friend and had something to eat.
enAlt: I met some friends and ate something.
notes: 친구 - friend, 그리고 - and, 밥 - food

en: Kimchi is delicious and it is Korean food.
notes: 김치 - a Korean dish, 한국 - Korean, 음식 - food, 그리고 - and

en: Please give me this and this.
notes: 하고 - and

en: I bought milk and bread.
notes: 우유 - milk, 랑 - and (a little more casual than 하고), 빵 - bread

en: I saw a movie with a friend.
notes: 친구 - friend, 하고 - with, 영화 - movie, 보다 - to see

en: Who did you go with?
notes: 누구 - who, 랑 - with

en: I saw a movie together with a friend.
notes: 랑 - with, 같이 - together

en: I'm tired but I want to see a movie.
notes: 피곤하다 - to be tired, 그렇지만 - but, 영화 - movie

ko: 어제 이거 샀어요. 그렇지만 정말 커요.
en: I bought this yesterday but it's really big.
notes: 크다 - to be big. "그렇지만" means it's bigger than you expected and you are unhappy about it.

ko: 어제 이거 샀어요. 그런데 정말 커요.
en: I bought this yesterday but it's really big.
enAlt: I bought this yesterday and it's really big.
notes: 크다 - to be big. "그런데" means it's bigger than you expected but it's not necessarily a bad thing.

en: I went to school yesterday but it was Sunday.
enAlt: I went to school yesterday, and by the way, it was Sunday.
notes: 그런데 - but, 일요일 - Sunday, 이었어요 - was

en: What time is it now?
notes: 지금 - now, 몇 - how many, 시 - hours, time

en: It's 11:12 o'clock.
notes: You say hours using the native Korean numbers and minutes using the Sino-Korean numbers

en: Meet me at 10 o'clock sharp.
notes: 정각 - the exact time

en: one apple
notes: 사과 - apple, 한 - one, 개 - counter for objects

en: how many things
enAlt: how many objects
notes: 몇 - how many, 개 - counter for objects

en: two students
notes: 학생 - student, 두 - two, 명 - counter for people

en: how many people
notes: 몇 - how many, 명 - counter for people

en: three cars
notes: 차 - car, 세 - three, 대 - counter for cars

en: How many Korean friends do you have?
notes: 친구 - friend, 명 - counter for people

en: I am studying.
notes: If you don't want to emphasize that you are in the middle of studying you can simply say: 공부해요.

en: I am working.
notes: 일하다 - to work

en: It was snowing.
enAlt: Snow was coming (down).
notes: 눈 - snow, 오다 - to come

en: I was working.
enAlt: We were working.

en: I will be working.
I will be listening.
notes: 듣다 - to listen

ko: 어제 이 시간에 뭐 하고 있었어요?
en: What were you doing yesterday at this time?
notes: 이 시간 - this time, 뭐 - what

en: What day is it today?
enAlt: Which day of the week is it today?
notes: 무슨 - what/which, 요일 - day of the week

en: What book are you reading?
notes: 무슨 - what, 책 - book, 읽다 - to read

en: What kind of tea are you drinking?
notes: 차 - tea

en: I eat an apple and bread.
notes: 사과 - apple, 하고 - and, 빵 - bread

en: I go to school on Mondays and Thursdays.
notes: 월요일 - Monday, 하고 - and, 목요일 - Thursday

en: Kimchi is cheap and delicious.
notes: 싸다 - to be cheap, -고 - and, 맛있다 - to be delicious

en: I'm studying Korean and meeting my friend.
notes: -고 is used to connect two sentences in a similar way to '그리고'.

ko: 샐리는 텔레비전을 보고 저는 책을 읽어요.
en: Sally is watching TV and I'm reading a book.
notes: 텔레비전 - TV, -고 - and

en: She is cleaning the house and doing the laundry.
notes: 집 - house, 청소하다 - to clean, 빨래하다 - to do the laundry

en: I work at a bank.
notes: 은행 - bank, 일하다 - to work

en: I teach Chinese in college.
notes: 대학교 - college, 중국어 - Chinese, 가르치다 - to teach

en: I was born in the USA.
notes: 미국 - USA, 태어나다 - to be born

en: Which month were you born in?
notes: 몇 - which number, 월 - month, 태어나다 - to be born

en: What date is it today?
notes: 몇 월 - which month, 며칠 - which day

en: My birthday is on the 1st of September.
notes: 제 - my, 생일 - birthday, 9월 - September, 1일 - first (day)

en: I saw it as well.
notes: 도 - also. You cannot use -도 together with the topic marking particle; in that case, -도 replaces -는.

en: I saw it as well.
notes: 나 - I (in the casual speech), 도 - also. To change the verb to the casual style you simply remove the '요'.

en: Do you work today as well?
enAlt: Are you working today as well?
notes: 오늘 - today, 도 - as well

en: Please give some water to me as well.
notes: Adding '도' after '저' means "Give water not only to other people but to me too." If you added '도' after '물' it would mean "Please give me not only other stuff but water as well."

en: to also see
enAlt: to even see
notes: Add '기' to the verbstem to turn it into a noun, then add '도', then add '하다' to turn it back into a verb.

en: I teach English as well.
notes: 영어 - English, 가르치다 - to teach

en: I also teach English.
notes: 가르치기 - the noun form of '가르치다'

en: I fix computers as well.
notes: 컴퓨터 - computer, 고치다 - to fix

en: I also fix computers.
enAlt: I even fix computers.
notes: 고치기 - fixing, 도 - also, even

en: I will buy only this one.
notes: 이것 - this (one), 만 - only

en: In the morning, I drink only coffee.
enAlt: Coffee is the only thing I drink in the mornings.
notes: 아침 - morning, 커피 - coffee, 만 - only

en: I only listened.
enAlt: Listening was the only thing I did.
notes: 듣기 - the noun form of '듣다' (to listen), 만 - only

en: I got here early only today.
enAlt: Today is the only day I came early.
notes: 만 - only, 일찍 - early

en: I ordered only beer.
notes: 맥주 - beer, 주문하다 - to order

en: Why did you buy only this one?
Yesterday I only played (around).
notes: 놀다 - to play, to hang out

en: Please give me only a little bit.
notes: 조금 - a little bit

en: It’s really fast.
notes: 정말 - really, 빠르다 - to be fast

en: It's not that expensive.
enAlt: It's not very expensive.
notes: 별로 - (not) very, 비싸다 - to be expensive

en: It’s not that interesting.
notes: 별로 is always used in negative sentences.

en: It’s not too bad.
enAlt: It's somewhat bad but not very bad.
notes: 별로 - (not) particularly, 나쁘다 - to be bad

en: I’m not busy at all.
notes: 전혀 - (not) at all (mostly in the written language), 바쁘다 - to be busy

en: It’s not hot at all.
notes: 전혀 - (not) at all, 덥다 - to be hot

en: I’m not busy at all.
notes: '하나도' is often used instead of '전혀' in the spoken language.

en: Come home, please.
notes: The honorific suffix in Korean is '시'. It is added right after the verb stem, in this case '오시'. After adding the present tense ending, it changes to '오셔요'. Over time, this form morphed into '오세요'.

en: Buy (me) a ballpoint pen, please.
notes: 볼펜 - ballpoint pen

en: Read a book, please.
notes: The honorific form is used to make polite requests.

en: Put on your shirt, please.
notes: 셔츠 - shirt, 입다 - to wear
천이백 원
이만 팔천삼백오십 원

en: How much is it for one?
enAlt: How much does one item cost?
notes: 한 - one, 개 - counter for things, 얼마 - how much

en: It's 1,500 won for two bottles.
notes: 두 - two, 병 - bottle

en: Welcome.
enAlt: Come on in.
notes: This is a fixed expression used often to greet customers coming into a store or a restaurant.

en: I can't do it.
enAlt: He can't do it.
notes: 못 - cannot

en: I can’t read it.
notes: 못 - can't, 읽다 - to read

en: I can’t meet you now.
to be good at singing
enAlt: to sing well
notes: 노래 - singing, 잘 - well

en: My friend is good at swimming.
enAlt: My friend swims well.
notes: 수영 - swimming, 잘 - well, skillfully

en: I am good at solving puzzles.
notes: 퍼즐 - puzzle, 풀다 - to solve

en: My handwriting is not good.
enAlt: I'm not able to handwrite well.
notes: 글씨 - handwritten characters, 잘 못 쓰다 - to be unable to write well

en: I’m not good at writing.
notes: 글 - writing, 쓰다 - to write

en: I heard the news from the teacher.
notes: 선생님 - teacher, 소식 - news. '한테서' means 'from someone', and it can also be replaced by simply '한테'.

en: I got a present from my mother.
notes: 우리 - our, 엄마 - mom, 한테 - from, 선물 - present, 받다 - to receive.Note that Koreans use the plural 'our' instead of 'my' when talking about their family.

en: I gave a book to my sister.
enAlt: She gave a book to her younger sister.
notes: 여동생 - younger sister, 한테 - to, 책 - book, 주다 - to give

en: My little sister feeds the dog.
enAlt: My little brother is giving food to the dog.
notes: 동생 - younger sibling, 개 - dog, 한테 - to

en: I have to sleep.
enAlt: You should sleep.
notes: verb stem + -아/어 + -야 되다/하다 = to have to, should

en: I have to write it.
enAlt: I should write it.
notes: 쓰다 - to write

en: I have to go home.
notes: 집 - home

en: Until when should I be here?
enAlt: How long should I stay here?
notes: 언제 - when, 까지 - until

en: Whom should I give this to?
notes: 누구 - who, 한테 - to, 주다 - to give

en: Where should I buy it?
Please walk quickly.
notes: 빨리 - quickly, 걷다 - to walk

en: Close the door, please.
notes: 닫다 - to close. This verb doesn't have the ㄷ - ㄹ change.

en: I wake up at 7:00 in the morning.
notes: 일곱 - seven, 시 - hour, 일어나다 - to wake up

en: I wash my face at 7:10.
notes: 십 - 10, 분 - minutes, 세수하다 - to wash face

en: I eat my meals at 8:00.
notes: 여덟 - 8

en: I go to school at 8:30.
notes: 반 - half

en: I go to bed at 11:00.
notes: 자다 - to sleep
분 - minutes

en: It's prettier.
enAlt: She's prettier.
notes: 더 - more, 예쁘다 - to be pretty

en: It's hotter today.
notes: 오늘 - today, 더 - more, 덥다 - to be hot

en: It's bigger.
Do you like milk? Or do you like juice?
notes: Even though '좋다' is often translated as 'to like', actually it means 'to be likeable, to be good' so you have to use the subject marking particle after the thing you like or the thing that is good. If you turn this descriptive verb into an action verb (좋아하다) then you have to use the object marking particle after the noun you like.

en: Do you like me?
enAlt: Are you in love with me?
notes: 좋아하다 - to like, 저 - I

en: Are you still here?
notes: '아직' means 'still' in positive sentences and 'yet' in negative sentences

en: It’s still 10 o’clock.
notes: 아직 - still

en: I haven’t done it yet.
notes: 아직 - yet

en: You still don’t know?
notes: '아직도' is used the same way as '아직' but it has the nuance of the speaker showing his/her dissatisfaction with the situation

en: Oh, you are already here!
enAlt: You're already here?
notes: 벌써 - already. The expression '왔어요?' is widely used almost as a greeting to acknowledge that someone has arrived.

en: It's already over.
notes: 벌써 - already, 끝나다 - to end

en: He already graduated from school.
notes: '이미' means 'already' but it is not interchangeable with '벌써'. '이미' is used when you (and probably the other person as well) already know this fact.

en: Sally is from Canada.
notes: 캐나다 - Canada

en: A friend of mine is coming from America.
Where are you from?

- How do you like studying Korean?
- It's fun.
notes: '어때요?' means 'How is something?' or 'How do you like something?'. It's usually preceded by the subject marking particle.

en: It's nice and cheap.
notes: 싸다 - to be cheap

en: How is the weather today?
notes: 날씨 - weather

en:
- How do you like kimchi?
- It's delicious.
It's difficult to read a Korean newspaper.
notes: 신문 - newspaper, 어렵다 - to be difficult

en: It's October 11th.
notes: 시월 - October, 십일 - 11

en: When is your birthday?
notes: 생일 - birthday, 며칠 - what date

en: Please sell it to me.
notes: 저한테 - to me, 팔다 - to sell

en: Kyeong-eun, hurry up and do some work!
notes: 빨리 - quickly

en: Watch out for fire!
notes: 불 - fire, 조심하다 - to be careful

en: My father is a doctor.
notes: 아버지 - father, 의사 - medical doctor

en: My mother is a teacher.
notes: You should use honorifics when speaking about older people. But never use them when talking about yourself.

en: My father is watching television now.
notes: '세요' is the combined shortened form of the honorific suffix 시+어요.

en: I have one older brother and one younger brother.
notes: 형 - older brother, 남동생 - younger brother

en: I have a guest.
notes: 계시다 is the honorific form of 있다.

en: I don't have a grandfather.
notes: 할아버지 - grandfather, 계시다 - to exist

en: My parents live in Canada.
notes: If a verb stem ends with an ㄹ (살다 - to live) and it is attached to an ending that starts with 'ㄴ', 'ㅂ' or 'ㅅ', the ㄹ is dropped.

en: Do you know Daniel?
notes: 알다 - to know

en: The computer is on the desk.
notes: 책상 - desk, 위 - above, 컴퓨터 - computer

en: The flower pot and coat hanger are beside the desk.
notes: 옆 - beside, 화분 - flower pot, 옷걸이 - coat hanger

en: The dog is inside the house.
notes: 안 - inside, 강아지 - puppy

en: There's a cat outside the house.
notes: 밖 - outside, 고양이 - cat

en: What floor is the office on?
(It's) the 9th floor.
What bus do you take?
notes: 번 - number, 버스 - bus, 타다 - to ride

en: I take bus number 705.
notes: 타다 - to ride

en: It's 25,000 won.
How many family members do you have?
enAlt: How many people are in your family?
notes: 가족 - family, 명 - counter for people

en: We are a family of four.
notes: '넷' changes to '네' in front of counters

en: How old are your younger siblings?
notes: 동생 - younger sibling, 살 - counter for years

ko: 남동생은 스물세 살이에요. 여동생은 스무 살이에요.
en: My younger brother is 23, and my younger sister is 20.

ko: 여기 사과 세 개, 콜라 한 병 주세요.
en: Please give me these three apples and one coke.
notes: 개 - counter for things, 병 - counter for bottles

en: Okay, your total is 5,600 won.
notes: 모두 - all together

en: There are two dogs.
enAlt: I have two dogs.
notes: 개 - dog, 마리 - counter for animals

ko: 텔레비전이 한 대, 컴퓨터가 두 대 있어요.
en: There is one TV and two computers.
notes: 대 - counter for vehicles and machinery

en: We got married in 2001.
notes: 년 - year, 결혼하다 - to get married

en: It's 9:10 in the morning.
notes: 오전 - in the morning

en: Good evening. This is the 9 o'clock news.
notes: '안녕하십니까' contains the honorific suffix '시'.

en: This book is interesting and cheap.
notes: 고 - and

ko: 내일 영화를 보고 서점에 갈 거예요.
en: Tomorrow I will watch a movie and go to a bookstore.
notes: 내일 - tomorrow, 서점 - bookstore

en: I read a book, studied, and did some exercise.
notes: Notice that only the last verb is conjugated into the past tense. But it's also possible to attach the past suffix before each 고. Koreans usually do that if the sentence is longer.

en: In September I will go to Korea, and in October I will go to Japan.
notes: 9월 - September, 일본 - Japan

en: I normally eat lunch at one o'clock.
notes: 보통 - normally, 점심 - lunch

en: It's behind the car.
notes: 자동차 - car

en: What is under the car?
notes: 밑에 - under

en: I'm going to meet them in front of the bank.
enAlt: We're going to meet in front of the bank.

en: I’m sleeping on the sofa.
notes: 소파 - sofa, 자다 - to sleep

en: I go back to my hometown next month.
notes: 다음 달 - next month, 고향 - hometown, 돌아가다 - to go back

en: What will you do this afternoon?
notes: 오후 - afternoon

en: I like watermelons and strawberries.
notes: 과 - and. 과/와 has the same meaning as 이랑 and 하고 but is used more in writing and formal situations.

en: I like strawberries and watermelons.
notes: 과 is used after nouns with a final consonant, and 와 is used after nouns without one.

en: Yesterday, I bought a bag and a hat.
notes: 모자 - hat

en: I'll have a hamburger and coke, please.
Shall we see a movie tomorrow?
enAlt: Do you want to go see a movie tomorrow (together)?
notes: -ㄹ까요 expresses suggestion

en: Shall we drink coffee or beer?
notes: 커피 - coffee, 맥주 - beer

en: I read newspapers and magazines.
notes: 신문 - newspaper, 잡지 - magazine

en: I want to go on a trip together with my family.
notes: 가족 - family, 함께 - together, 여행 - trip

en: Shall we have lunch together with the teacher?
notes: 식사 - meal

en: Who's in the classroom?
notes: 교실 - classroom

en: The teacher and students (are there).
notes: 들 - plural particle

en: What kind of food do you like?
notes: 음식 - food

en: Those shoes aren't pretty.
notes: 구두 - shoes

en: No, it's not far away. It's close.
notes: 멀다 - to be far, 가깝다 - to be close

en: Do you study Korean alone?
notes: 혼자 - alone

en: Who are you going to the theater with?
notes: 극장 - theater

en: I'm going to listen to Korean music.
notes: 음악 - music, 듣다 - to listen

en: I'm going to take pictures in the park.
notes: 공원 - park, 사진 - picture, 찍다 - to take a picture

en: Shall we go mountain climbing?
notes: '산' means just a mountain, but the climbing (or hiking) part is implied.

en:
- Shall we see a movie?
- Yes, (that sounds) good.
A long time ago, there was a princess.
notes: 옛날 - the old days, 공주 - princess

en: Who hasn't arrived?
I'm a lawyer.
notes: 직업 - job, 변호사 - lawyer

en: I wake up at 8:00 in the morning.
I came to Korea on March 2.
What time do you normally go to sleep?
notes: 보통 - normally, 자다 - to go to bed

en: I usually go to sleep at 11:00 P.M.
notes: 보통 - usually, 밤 - night (or P.M. in this case)

en: When will you go back to your hometown?
notes: 고향 - hometown, 돌아가다 - to go back

en: I plan to go back in June of next year.
notes: 내년 - next year

en: He was born on March 5, 1981.
notes: 태어나다 - to be born

en: I graduated from college in February 2004.
notes: 대학교 - college, 졸업하다 - to graduate

en: I'll eat at the cafeteria.
notes: Even though '밥' (meal) is not strictly necessary in this sentence, Koreans like to have an object before a verb.

en: Today, only Carol came to school.
The restaurant is closed only on Mondays.
notes: 쉬다 - to rest, take a break

en: Jason studies only until 12 o'clock, and then sleeps.
notes: 자다 - to sleep

en: Why didn't you come to school yesterday?
Daniel is talking on the phone.
notes: 전화하다 - to make a phone call

en: Sally is sleeping at home.
notes: 자다 - to sleep

en: Fumiko is writing a letter.
notes: 편지 - letter, 쓰다 - to write

en: Hello. Is Sally there?
notes: "여보세요" is the standard greeting on the phone. "계시다" - to be there (honorific)

en: It will be cold.
notes: The '-ㄹ 거예요' ending can express not only the speaker's intention but also his/her supposition based on existing knowledge.

en: This problem is difficult.
enAlt: This question (or exercise) is difficult.
notes: 문제 - problem, 어렵다 - to be difficult

en: In Seoul, it’s really cold in winter.
notes: 겨울 - winter

en: I walked home from school.
notes: 걸어오다 - to come by walking

en: I work from 9:00 A.M. until 5:00 P.M.
notes: 오후 - afternoon

en: Is it far from here to school?
notes: 멀다 - to be far

en: Is this library open on Saturdays?
notes: 도서관 - library, 문 - door, 열다 - to open

en: How do you get from Myeongdong to Dongdaemun?
Please take subway line 4.
notes: 지하철 - subway, 호선 - subway line, 타다 - to get in, ride

en: The lunch hour is from 1:00 P.M. until 2:00 P.M.
notes: 점심 - lunch

en: Please sit here.
notes: 앉다 - to sit

en: Please look at page 15 in the book.
notes: 쪽 - page

en: I want to lose some weight.

ko: 그럼 야채를 많이 드세요. 그리고 운동을 많이 하세요.
en: Then you should eat a lot of vegetables. And get lots of exercise.
notes: 야채 - vegetables, 많이 - a lot, 드시다 - to eat (honorific)

en: Please write down your name and phone number here.
notes: 이름 - name, 전화번호 - phone number

en: Okay.
notes: This is a fixed expression used to indicate that you have understood the instructions or information just communicated to you and you intend to comply or take it into account.

en: Thank you, manager Kim.
notes: 부장 - head of department

en: Why are you tired these days?
notes: 피곤하다 - to be tired

en: I'd like to learn taekwondo.
I'd like to listen to some music.
Let me have four bowls of bibimbap, please.
notes: 그릇 - bowl

en: Who are you writing a letter to?
I'm writing a letter to my friend back home.
notes: 고향 - hometown

en: Why did you buy flowers?
notes: 꽃 - flowers

en: I'm going to give it to my girlfriend as a present.
notes: 선물하다 - to give a present

ko: 아버지는 키가 커요. 그리고 저도 키가 커요.
en: My father is tall. And I am tall, too.
notes: 키 - height

ko: 일본에 친구가 있어요. 그리고 미국에도 친구가 있어요.
en: I have a friend in Japan. And I have a friend in the USA, too.
notes: '도' replaces the subject, object, and topic particles but it doesn't replace other particles.

ko: 왕징 씨는 사과를 좋아해요. 그리고 딸기도 좋아해요.
en: Wang Jing likes apples. And she likes strawberries, too.
notes: 딸기 - strawberries

en: Go outside.
enAlt: Let's go outside.
notes: 나가다 - to go out

en: What will you eat?
What do you study these days?
I study Korean. And I also learn taekwondo.
Who came to the birthday party yesterday?

ko: 마틴 씨가 왔어요. 그리고 요코 씨도 왔어요.
en: Martin came. And Yoko also came.
Studying Korean is difficult.
notes: 한국말 - Korean

en: My hobby is cooking.
notes: 취미 - hobby

en: Carol is tall and slender.
notes: 날씬하다 - to be slender

en: I can't read Korean newspapers.
notes: 신문 - newspaper

en: I have to read it.
enAlt: You should read it.

en: I should go to the hospital tomorrow.
I need to study at home today.
It's to the left.
notes: 왼편 - left side

en: She's in the next room with her boyfriend.
notes: 방 - room, 남자친구 - boyfriend

en: I like listening to Korean songs.
I don't like eating meals by myself.
I'll go fishing this weekend.
notes: 낚시 - fishing

en: I'll visit China during my vacation.

ko: 댄 씨가 지금 음악을 듣고 있어요.
en: Dane is listening to music now.

ko: 미누 씨가 지금 집에 가고 있어요.
en: Minu is going home now.
Wesley was sleeping at that time.
notes: 그때 - (at) that time

en: Yesterday, I ate dinner, and then did my homework.
notes: 숙제 - homework

ko: 오전에는 친구를 만나고 오후에는 도서관에 갈 거예요.
en: In the morning, I'll meet a friend, and in the afternoon, I'll go to the library.
What do you think of your girlfriend?
She's smart and pretty.
notes: 똑똑하다 - to be smart

en: I don’t know, either.
Who cut the cake?
notes: 자르다 - to cut

en: I'll ride my bike.
notes: 자전거 - bicycle

en: I walked for an hour.
Do you believe that story?
notes: 믿다 - to believe, 이야기 - story

ko: 왕징 씨, 지금 시장에 같이 가요.
en: Wang Jing, let's go to the market together.
Why didn't you answer the phone a while ago?
notes: 아까 - a short while ago

en: I was taking a shower.
Where are you living now?
notes: 살다 - to live

en: It was yesterday.
It was me.
notes: 나 - me

en: I met a friend yesterday.
Everyone, do you remember?
notes: 기억나다 - to remember

en: Okay, I got it. / I understand.
enAlt: Okay, I will.
notes: This is a common expression. It has a similar meaning to '알겠습니다' but it is much less formal.

en: Stir it well.
notes: 젓다 - to stir. Some verbs whose stem ends in ㅅ lose it before some endings.

en: I connected the two (objects).
notes: 잇다 - to connect

en: Who built this house?
notes: 짓다 - to build

en: I’m going to wash up.
enAlt: I’m going to wash it.
notes: 씻다 - to wash

en: Are there a lot of flights?
notes: 비행기 - airplane, 자주 - often

en: Can Dane speak Korean well?
notes: 한국말 - Korean

en: Shall we play some basketball?
notes: 농구 - basketball

en: Why don't we rest over here?
notes: 좀 - a little bit, 쉬다 - to rest

en: Which movie do you want to see?
They will read the questions twice.
notes: 문제 - question, 번 - times

en: I can't sing.
notes: 부르다 - to sing

en: My class ends at 12:50.
notes: 수업 - class

en: When did you come to Korea?
Pardon me. Where is the bank?
I can't drive. I never learned how.
notes: 운전 - driving

ko: 한국말을 잘 못해요. 한국말을 잘하고 싶어요.
en: I can't speak Korean well. I want to speak Korean well.
I have been resting at home since yesterday.
notes: 쉬다 - to rest

en: I go to the bookstore sometimes.
notes: 가끔 - sometimes

en: I watch Korean movies often.
from last week until next week
Why didn't you come to the party yesterday?
I get off the bus.
notes: 내리다 - to get off

en: She's coming next week.
enAlt: He will come next week.
notes: This sentence can't be translated as "I'm coming next week" because you must never refer to yourself using the honorifics (시).

en: Good afternoon. I'm An Junho.
I don't like sports.

Who cleaned the room?
- Me.
notes: When you give a one-word answer to a question, attach a '-요' to make it polite.

ko: 김치를 잘 먹어요?- 아니요, 잘 못 먹어요.
en:
Do you eat kimchi well?
- No, I don't eat (kimchi well).
enAlt:
Are you able to eat (a lot of) kimchi without any problems?
- No, I can't.

en: They look good on you (Jisu).
notes: 잘 어울리다 - to fit well

en: I don't want to eat now.
I don't want to work.
Our son doesn't like to clean the room.
notes: When you talk about a third person, you have to use 싫어하다 instead of 싫다.

en: You don’t like this? How about this one?
Where do you live?
notes: 살다 - to live

en: How long have you been dating your boyfriend?
notes: 사귀다 - to date

en: Is there a bus that goes from here to school?
notes: 버스 - bus

en: Who called me?
notes: 부르다 - to call someone's name

en: I'm wearing a skirt.
I'm wearing boots.
I definitely need to meet this person.
enAlt: I need to meet him at any cost.

en: The girl plays well by herself.
notes: 아이 - child, 혼자서 - alone, 놀다 - to play

en: Which outfit is better?
notes: '어느' means 'which' and it is used when you have to choose from a few known options. In this case, a girl is holding two outfits in her hand and asking which one is better. 낫다 - to be better

ko: 오늘은 비가 왔어요. 그래서 집에 있었어요.
en: It was raining today so I stayed at home.
notes: 그래서 - so, therefore

en: I'm a student so I don't have money.
notes: 그래서 - therefore, 돈 - money

en: Can you drive?
notes: '-ㄹ 수 있다' - to be able to do something. '수' means 'way, method' so literally it means "Is there a way to do driving?"

en: Can you speak Japanese?
notes: 일본어 - Japanese

en: Can you read this?

ko: 재준 씨가 캐럴 씨에게 선물을 줍니다.
en: Jaejun gives a present to Carol.
notes: 에게 is the same as 한테, used more in the written language.

en: The teacher teaches Korean to the students.
notes: 들 - the plural particle, 에게 - to

en: I went to the library and studied.
notes: '-아/어+서' is a verb ending that connects two sentences. It is a bit similar to '-고' but not the same. '서' is used when a subject performs two actions one after the other and they are connected. For example, going to the library and studying are connected because the studying takes place in the library.

en: I met my friend in the evening and (we) watched a movie.
notes: When the sentence is in the past tense, you don't add the past suffix before '서', the tense is expressed only through the last verb of the sentence.

en: I wake up in the morning and wash my face.
notes: The two actions in this sentence are connected and happen one after the other so using '서' is appropriate here.

en: I made gimbap at lunchtime and ate it.
notes: 점심 - lunch

en: A watermelon is bigger than an apple.
notes: 수박 - watermelon, 보다 - than

en: Today is hotter than yesterday.
notes: 어제보다 - 'than yesterday'. The word '더' is omitted here because Koreans often do that if the context is clear enough.

en: English is more difficult than Korean.
notes: 영어 - English

en: I’m going to go earlier than yesterday.
notes: 일찍 - early. You could say '더 일찍' but it's not necessary.

ko: 현정 씨가 저보다 더 잘 해요.
en: Hyeonjeong is better than me (at doing that).
notes: 저보다 - than me

en: What is your favorite?
enAlt: What is the best?
notes: 제일 - the most

en: if it rains tomorrow
notes: -면 is the ending that means "if"

ko: 이거 다 먹으면 배가 아플 거예요.
en: If you eat all of it, your stomach will hurt.
notes: 다 - all, 배 - stomach

ko: 리모콘을 찾으면 TV를 볼 수 있어요.
en: If you find the remote control, you can watch TV.
notes: 리모콘 - remote control, 찾다 - to find

en: If you don’t come now, you will regret it.
notes: 후회하다 - to regret

en: I want to go to the US someday.
notes: 언젠가 - someday, 미국 - the US

en: Did you find something?
notes: 뭔가 - something

en: Someone came.
notes: 누군가 - someone

en: What did you buy?
enAlt: Did you buy something?
notes: Koreans often shorten '뭔가' to '뭐' so the only difference between the two meanings is the intonation of the sentence. If you stress '뭐' it means 'what', otherwise it means 'something'.

en: When are you going to go to China?
enAlt: Are you going to go to China someday?
notes: '언제' can mean both 'when' and 'someday'

ko: 저는 학교에 가지만 친구는 안 가요.
en: I go to school, but my friend doesn't.
notes: '-지만' is an ending that connects sentences and expresses contrast. It is attached to the stem of the first verb.

en: How was your trip to Jeju Island?
notes: 제주도 - Jeju Island, 여행 - trip

en: It was fun, but the weather was a little hot.
notes: 지만 - but, 좀 - a little, 덥다 - to be hot

en: Please come (for my sake).
enAlt: Please do me a favor and come.
notes: '-아/어+주세요' is a more polite construction than '-(으)세요'. It includes the meaning of doing the speaker a favor.

en: Please do it for me.
Please teach me.
enAlt: Please tell me (how to do something).
notes: The meaning of 'to me' or 'for me' is included in '주세요'.

en: Buy me an ice cream (please).
notes: This is a less polite expression than '사 주세요' because it doesn't include the honorific suffix '시'.

en: I’m learning English. Please help me.
notes: 돕다 - to help

en: Can you help me?
notes: This sentence combines '아+주다' (me, for me) and 'ㄹ 수 있다' (can).

en: I’m scared. Please go with me.
notes: 무섭다 - to be scared

en: to go to the left
enAlt: to go through the left side
notes: 왼쪽 - left, 로 - particle showing direction

en: to write with a pen
notes: 펜 - pen, '로' - using

en: to talk in Korean
notes: '로' - using

en: to be famous for cheese
notes: 치즈 - cheese, 유명하다 - to be famous

en: to get hurt in an accident
notes: 사고 - accident, 다치다 - to get hurt

en: What did you make this with?
enAlt: What is this made of?
notes: 만들다 - to make

en: Did you come by taxi today?
notes: 택시 - taxi

en: I’m going to go by bus.
notes: 버스 - bus

en: Do you think of me as a friend?
notes: 생각하다 - to think

en: Come out through exit number 2.
notes: 출구 - exit, 나오다 - to come out

en: Give me all of it.
notes: 다 - all

en: I’ve done all of it.
enAlt: I finished it.

en: Are we there yet?
enAlt: Did everybody come?
notes: '다' modifies verbs indicating that the action is complete. In this case, the question is whether the action of 'coming' is finished.

en: to drink all the coffee
notes: In English the word 'all' modifies 'coffee', but in Korean it modifies the verb.

en: to read all of the book, to finish reading it
enAlt: to read all the books

en: I want to buy more clothes.
notes: '더' also modifies verbs, not nouns.

en: Please wait for ten more minutes.
notes: 분 - minutes, 기다리다 - to wait

en: Did you finish talking on the phone?
enAlt: Did everyone make a phone call?

en: I finished the preparation.
enAlt: All of us are prepared.
notes: 준비하다 - to prepare

en: Show me more, please.
notes: 보이다 - to show

en: If you want to study more, come to TTMIK.
notes: -고 싶으면 - if you want to

en: My father went to the office.
notes: 회사 - company, 가셨어요 - the honorific past tense form: 가+시+었어요.

en: My mother read the book yesterday.
When did you get married?
notes: 결혼하다 - to get married

en: Three guests came.
notes: In an honorific sentence, '분' is used as a counter for people instead of '명'.

en: There's a plant to the left of the desk.
notes: 왼쪽 - left side, 화분 - flower pot

en: The coat hanger is to the right of the desk.
notes: 오른쪽 - right side, 옷걸이 - coat hanger

en: Don't go.
notes: -지 말다 is the construction used to make negative orders or requests (please note that it cannot be used with adjectives/descriptive verbs, it has to be used with action verbs)

en: Don't do it.
Don't touch it.
notes: 만지다 - to touch

en: Don’t laugh.
notes: 웃다 - to laugh

en: Don’t worry.
notes: 걱정하다 - to worry

en: Please don’t tell Kyeong-eun (about it).
notes: 말하다 - to tell

en: Don’t send it yet.
notes: 보내다 - to send

en: I haven’t finished writing it.
enAlt: I didn't write all of it yet.
notes: 쓰다 - to write

en: It's ten minutes to two.
notes: 전 - before

en: That guy is really cool.
notes: 멋있다 - to be cool, 너무 - very (in colloquial speech)

en: I really like this.
enAlt: This is really good.

en: It’s too noisy here.
enAlt: It's very noisy here.
notes: 시끄럽다 - to be noisy

en: What's your opinion of this?
notes: 어떻게 - how, 생각하다 - to think

en: I run every morning.
notes: 마다 - every, 달리다 - to run

en: This is Wesley's book.
notes: 의 - possessive particle. It's usually pronounced as [에]. It often gets omitted in colloquial speech.

en: This is Budi's teacher.
notes: 이분 - this person (honorific)

en: My name is Yoko.
notes: 제 = 저의. Similarly, 내 = 나의 (my), 네 = 너의 (your)

en: Whose umbrella is this?
notes: 우산 - umbrella

en: It's Jaejun's umbrella.
I don't go.
enAlt: I'm not going.
notes: -지 않다 - negation

en: I don't eat squid.
notes: In simple sentences, the '안 먹어요' form is used more often, but this form is used when you want to combine the negation with other grammatical structures. For example, 가고 싶지 않아요 - I don't want to go.

en: The room is not spacious.
I will be in Korea for approximately one month.
notes: 쯤 - approximately

en: About 100 people came.
notes: 쯤 - about

en: I lived in Germany for about two years.
notes: 독일 - Germany

en: Around what time shall we meet tomorrow?
How about around five o’clock?
notes: 어때요 - how about

en: I'm going to the pharmacy in order to buy some medicine.
notes: 약국 - pharmacy, 약 - medicine. '-러' is used to express a person's reason for coming or going somewhere. In this case the reason is to buy something, therefore the '러' is attached to the word 'buy'.

en: I'm on my way to watch a baseball game.
notes: 야구 - baseball, 구경하다 - to watch

en: I'm going to the post office in order to send a letter.
notes: 편지 - letter, 보내다 - to send

en: I came here to learn Korean.
I'm going to the beauty salon to get a hair cut.
notes: 미용실 - beauty salon, 자르다 - to cut

en: I'm going to the bank in order to exchange money.
notes: 바꾸다 - to exchange

en: I'm on my way to eat.

ko: 저는 이번 주말에 정민 씨하고 같이 부산에 갈 거예요.
en: This weekend I'm going to go to Busan with Jeongmin.
notes: 이번 주말 - this weekend

en: I'll study.
notes: 'ㄹ게요' is used for the future tense but it is not the same as 'ㄹ 거예요'. 'ㄹ게요' expresses your decision to do something as a result of (or reaction to) what someone else said. For example, if your mother tells you you should study more you can say "Okay, I'll study" using this ending. Or if others around you are talking about going somewhere and you say '저도 갈게요' (I'll go as well), it means that you just decided going with them as a result of this conversation. If you already originally planned to go with them then you should use the standard future tense.

en: (If you don't mind) I'll go.
notes: 'ㄹ게요' can also be used to check what the other person thinks about your plan. If you start a conversation with this ending it means you want feedback/approval/permission from the other person.

en: I’m going to go. Take care.
notes: The meaning of the first sentence is 'I'm going to go unless there is something else I have to do or unless you want me to stay.'

en: Is that so? I’ll do it again.
notes: 그래요 - a form of '그렇다' (to be like that), 다시 - again

en: I’ll be there at around 4 o’clock tomorrow. Is that alright?
notes: 괜찮다 - to be okay

en: However, I don't like baseball.
notes: 야구 - baseball

en:
- How's Tokyo?
- Tokyo is really crowded.
notes: 도쿄 - Tokyo, 많이 - a lot, 복잡하다 - to be crowded. It is typical that the question contains a subject particle and the answer contains a topic particle.

en: It rains so I can’t go.
notes: '서' in this sentence has the same meaning as '그래서'. The first part is the reason and the second part is the result.

en: It rained so I couldn’t go.
notes: The tense of the sentence is expressed only through the last verb.

en: I’m busy today so I can’t watch the movie.
I’m going to go to the park and read a book.
notes: '서' is used in this case because the two actions are linked - the book reading will take place in the park

en: What are you going to do with the money you save up?
enAlt: lit. You save up money and what will you do?
notes: 모으다 - to gather, save up

en: I’m going to buy a cake and give it to a friend.
enAlt: I’m going to buy a cake in order to give it to a friend.
notes: 케익 - cake

en: for example
notes: This is a fixed expression

en: What are you going to do in Korea once you get there?
enAlt: What will you do in Korea after you go there?
notes: This sentence asks for your plan or purpose related to going to Korea. English doesn't have such a sentence pattern so it may take some time to get used to it.

en: I’m glad to have come to Seoul.
enAlt: Since I came to Seoul, I’m glad.

ko: 술을 너무 많이 마셔서 머리가 아파요.
en: I drank too much so my head is aching.
notes: 술 - alcohol, 머리 - head

en: These days I’m busy so I can’t meet my friends.
notes: 요즘 - these days

en: I’m going to study hard so I can get/and I will get a scholarship.
notes: 열심히 - diligently, 장학금 - scholarship, 받다 - to receive

ko: 한국어가 너무 재미있어서 매일 공부하고 있어요.
en: Korean is so much fun that I’m studying it every day.
notes: 매일 - every day

en: Is Tokyo similar to Seoul?
notes: 서울하고 - to Seoul, 비슷하다 - to be similar

en: Are this and this the same?
enAlt: Is this the same as this?
notes: 같다 - to be the same, the first '랑' means 'and', the second '랑' means 'as'.

en: We have the same age.
enAlt: lit. “For us, the age is the same.”
notes: 나이 - age

en: It’s like coffee.
enAlt: It seems to be coffee.
notes: If you don't use '랑' or '하고' with '같다', it changes the meaning to 'to be like'.

en: It seems to be a lie.
enAlt: It sounds like a lie.
notes: 거짓말 - lie

en: That person is like a robot.
notes: 로봇 - robot

en: Kyeong-eun is like an angel.
notes: 천사 - angel

en: Hyunwoo seems to be a genius.
notes: 천재 - genius

en: Please wait for just five minutes.
notes: 기다리다 - to wait

ko: 우리 아이는 하루 종일 게임만 해요.
en: My kids play games all day long.
enAlt: My kids do nothing but play games all day long.
notes: 아이 - children, 하루 종일 - all day long, 게임 - game

en: Only Junho was accepted to the university.
notes: 입학하다 - to get into (a school)

ko: 민우는 다른 책은 안 읽고 만화책만 읽어요.
en: Minu reads comic books only, and no other books.
notes: 다른 - other (different), 만화책 - comic book

ko: 우리 딸은 학교에서만 공부하고 집에서는 공부하지 않아요.
en: Our daughter studies only at school, and doesn't study at home.
notes: 딸 - daughter

en: Do you take both sugar and cream in your coffee?
notes: 설탕 - sugar, 크림 - cream, 넣다 - to put in

en: Please turn off the lights.
notes: 불 - light, 좀 - please, 끄다 - to turn off

ko: 네, 영화가 너무 슬퍼서 울고 있어요.
en: Yes, I'm crying because the movie was so sad.
notes: 슬프다 - to be sad, 울다 - to cry

en: Did you have a nice picnic over the weekend?
notes: 주말 - weekend, 소풍 - picnic

ko: 아니요, 날씨가 나빠서 소풍을 못 갔어요.
en: No, the weather was bad, so I couldn't go.
notes: 나쁘다 - to be bad

ko: 배가 많이 아팠어요. 그래서 학교에 못 왔어요.
en: I had a bad stomachache. So I couldn't come to school.
notes: 아프다 - to be sick, in pain

en: before class
notes: 수업 - class, 전 - before

en: before 1 o’clock
before going home
enAlt: before you go home
notes: '기' turns the verb into a noun

en: before paying money
notes: 내다 - to pay

en: What did you do before you came here?

ko: 집에 가기 전에 술 마실 거예요.
en: I’m going to drink before I go home.
notes: 술 - alcohol

en: Knock before you come in.
notes: 들어오다 - to come in, 노크 하다 - to knock

en: Think well before you buy it.
Catch him before he runs away.
notes: 도망가다 - to run away, 잡다 - to catch

en: This is so cute.
notes: 귀엽다 - to be cute

en: It's 019-8729-9509.
notes: 의 is attached to the second group of numbers when you read it out loud.

en: If you study at TTMIK, studying Korean is easy.
notes: 쉽다 - to be easy

en: Yes, it takes about one hour by bus.
notes: 걸리다 - to take (time)

en: It’s raining. Are you still going?
notes: 그래도 - but still, however

en: Korean is difficult. But still, it is interesting.
But still, we played soccer.
notes: 축구 - soccer

ko: 노래방에 가야 돼요. 그래도 노래 안 할 거예요.
en: I have to go to a karaoke bar. However, I'm not going to sing.
notes: 노래방 - karaoke

en: Please go straight up this road.
Please become a doctor.
notes: 의사 - doctor, 되다 - to become

en: Grandpa, please be healthy. Live a long, long time.
notes: 건강 - health

en: Everyone, please be quiet!
notes: 조용하다 - to be quiet

en: a quiet person
notes: In order to turn a descriptive verb (조용하다 - to be quiet) into its adjective form, you add ㄴ or 은 to the verb stem.

en: an expensive computer
notes: If you want to use an adjective in front of a noun, you have to turn the descriptive verb into its adjective form.

en: white paper
notes: 하얗다 - to be white, 종이 - paper

en: It’s a good idea.
notes: 아이디어 - idea

en: Do you have a smaller bag?
I want to drink some cold coffee.
notes: 시원하다 - to be cool

en: Hyeonwoo is a bad person.
notes: 나쁘다 - to be bad

en: My baby will be born in one month.
notes: 후에 - after, later, 아기 - baby

en: I got a job after college graduation.
notes: 졸업 - graduation, 취직하다 - to get a job

en: I'm going in a year.
enAlt: I'm going a year later.

en: Please come one hour later.
notes: 시간 - hour

en: I eat while watching TV.
notes: "-면서" is used when two actions take place simultaneously. The person doing those actions must be the same.

ko: 우리 언니는 피아노를 치면서 노래를 해요.
en: My older sister sings while she plays the piano.
notes: 피아노를 치다 - to play the piano

en: Don't use the phone while driving. It's dangerous.
notes: 운전하다 - to drive

ko: 네, 그래서 음악을 들으면서 공부를 해요.
en: Yes, that's why I listen to music while I study.
Were you very busy yesterday?
Yes, that's why I ate a sandwich while working.
I attend school and also have a part-time job.
notes: 다니다 - to attend, 아르바이트 - part-time job

en: Then, what is this?
notes: 그러면 = 그렇다 + 면. It means "in that case" or "if it is so".

ko: 지금 바빠요? 그럼 언제 안 바빠요?
en: You’re busy now? Then when are you not busy?
notes: "그럼" is a shortened version of "그러면"

ko: 한국 음식 좋아해요? 그러면 김밥도 좋아해요?
en: Do you like Korean food? Then do you like kimbap too?
Really? If so, what do we do now?
notes: "어떻게 해요?" more literally means "How should we deal with this situation?" but in English it's usually translated as "What should we do?" or similar. You cannot use "뭐 해요" in this situation, you have to use "어떻게".

en: Then how about this one?
a big house
salty food
notes: 짜다 - to be salty

en: I bought some inexpensive clothes.
There is a tall mountain behind the school.
notes: 높다 - to be high

en: I'm going to borrow an easy book.
notes: 빌리다 - to borrow

en: Give me a long skirt, please.
notes: If the adjective stem ends in ㄹ, it is omitted and ㄴ is added.

en: I ate some delicious food.
notes: In this case, '는' is added instead of 'ㄴ'

en: Which dish would you like to eat?
Let me have 4 portions of bulgogi, please.
notes: 인분 - portion

ko: 저는 한국 음식을 다 좋아하지만 불고기를 제일 좋아해요.
en: I like all Korean food, but I like bulgogi the best.
notes: 제일 - the most

ko: 나중에 불고기를 만들어서 가족하고 같이 먹고 싶어요.
en: I want to make some bulgogi and eat it with my family later.
notes: 나중에 - later, 가족 - family

en: Let's start.
notes: There are several ways of saying "Let's" in Korean but this is the most basic one. It's the same as the simple present tense.

en: Let’s start.
notes: This ending is used in the plain speech style, and it means "let's do something".

ko: 저도 서점에 갈 거예요. 같이 가요!
en: I’m going to the bookstore, too. Let’s go together!
notes: 서점 - bookstore

ko: 배 안 고파요? 우리 햄버거 먹어요.
en: Aren’t you hungry? Let’s eat hamburgers.
notes: 우리 - we

ko: 지금 두 시예요. 세 시에 여기에서 만나요.
en: It’s two o’clock now. Let’s meet here at three o’clock.

ko: 저 금요일까지 바빠요. 토요일에 시작해요. 어때요?
en: I’ll be busy until Friday. Let’s start on Saturday. What do you think?
a different place
notes: 다르다 - to be different, 데 - place

en: Teacher, what is the phone number for Namsan Library?
notes: 도서관 - library, 전화번호 - phone number

en: Let's eat Korean food.
notes: Even though this is the formal style, you can't say it to someone older than you. Instead, you can say "같이 -세요."

en: Let's not take the bus. Let's take the subway.
Let's not watch the movie.
If you spend too much time on the computer, you'll hurt your eyes.
I dance when I'm in a good mood.
notes: The '면' construction can be translated as 'when' to English if it's about a repetitive action. Sometimes also to "after", for example: 졸업하면 뭐 할 거예요? (What are your plans after graduation?)

ko: 돈을 많이 벌면 집을 살 거예요.
en: If I make a lot of money, I'm going to buy a house.
Yesterday, I studied for four hours.
notes: "동안" expresses a length of time

en: Bears hibernate during winter.
notes: 곰 - bear

en: My legs hurt, so walking is difficult.
notes: 다리 - legs, 걷다 - to walk

ko: 미누 씨는 한국 사람이고 댄 씨는 영국 사람입니다.
en: Minu is Korean, and Dane is British.

ko: 어제 파티에서 티루엔 씨가 노래도 부르고 춤도 췄어요.
en: At yesterday's party, Tiluen sang songs and danced.
notes: When combining several facts about the same subject, particle '도' is often used.

en: even if you cry
enAlt: even though you cry
notes: 울다 - to cry. The '-도' ending comes from '그래도' and has a similar meaning.

en: even if you study
enAlt: even though you study

en: Even if I go home, there is no food there.
Even if I take a taxi, it takes a long time.
notes: 타다 - to take (a vehicle)

ko: 석진 씨는 제가 전화를 해도 안 받아요.
en: Even if I call him, Seokjin doesn’t answer.
notes: 전화를 받다 - to answer the phone

en: Even though the smell is weird, it’s tasty.
notes: 냄새 - smell

en: I will go to Korea even if I'm busy.
Traffic is heavy, so I take the subway.
enAlt: Lit. The streets are crowded so I take the subway.

en: I was tired so I went to bed.
The market is crowded since there are many people.
I caught a cold so I went to the clinic.
notes: When Europeans say "go to see a doctor", Koreans say "go to the hospital". It's because their health care system works like that, doctors are at hospitals.

en: I should take some medicine because I have a cold.
notes: 약 - medicine

en: I have a baby.
notes: Sometimes Korean sentences can have two subject marking particles, like in this example.

en: What is there across from the department store?
notes: 백화점 - department store, 건너편 - opposite side

en: Go slow!
notes: The plural particle '들' shows that you are talking to several people. As you can see, it doesn't necessarily have to be attached to the noun, it can be attached elsewhere in the sentence as well.

en: They're in the classroom.
I'm hungry because I haven't eaten any food.

ko: 샐리는 요즘 시험이 있어서 아주 바빠요.
en: Sally has exams these days so she is very busy.
notes: 시험 - exam, 아주 - very

ko: 한국어 공부도 해야 되고 도서관에서 책도 빌려야 돼요.
en: She has to study Korean and borrow books from the library.
notes: 빌리다 - to borrow

ko: 그런데 어제부터 머리도 아프고 열도 나요.
en: But she has had a headache and fever since yesterday.
notes: 열 - fever

en: So Sally called Jeongmin.
It's Sunday tomorrow. What are you going to do?
enAlt: Tomorrow is Sunday. What are your plans?
notes: 'ㄴ데'/'는데' is a sentence connecting ending with many different meanings and usage situations. One of the ways it can be used is to give background information before making a suggestion, a request, or a question.

ko: 어제 자고 있었는데 한국에서 전화가 왔어요.
en: I was sleeping yesterday when I got a phone call from Korea.
enAlt: Yesterday I got a phone call from Korea while I was sleeping.
notes: This usage of '는데' is similar to the previous one. It describes the situation that was present when something else (unexpected) happened.

en: It’s still 9 o’clock but I am already sleepy.
notes: 'ㄴ데' can be used to express contrast. This usage is similar to '그런데'.

en: Oh, that’s cool!
notes: '는데' can be used at the end of a sentence to express surprise. In this case, you also have to add '요' if you want to make the sentence polite.

en: Oh, that’s cool!
notes: If you don't add '요', the sentence is in the casual '반말' speech style.

en: So where are you now?
notes: You can use this ending (not only in questions) if you are expecting some explanation about a situation or behavior.

en: Now? I’m busy now, so...
notes: You can also use this ending when you explain a situation and expect an answer (or some other kind of reaction) from the other person. Koreans use this ending a lot because it is less direct than the simple present tense.

ko: 내일 친구 생일인데 선물을 아직 못 샀어요.
en: It’s my friend’s birthday tomorrow, but I haven’t been able to buy a present.
I bought this in Japan, and it’s a present for you.
enAlt: I bought this in Japan. It's a present.
notes: 일본 - Japan

en: I saw it in the news today. Is it true?
This is good!
Huh? It was here...
I saw a movie, and it was scary.

ko: 저 지금 학생인데 일도 하고 있어요.
en: I am a student now, but I’m working too.
In the mornings, I eat bread or rice.
notes: '(이)나' means 'or' and it is used to connect nouns.

en: I'm thirsty. Please give me some water or juice.
notes: 마르다 - to be dry

en: I want to go to Jeju Island or Mt. Seorak during the school vacation.
My house is far away, so coming to school is difficult.
How long will you be in Korea?
I'll be there for three years.
What will you do during the vacation?
The plane will depart in two hours.
notes: 비행기 - airplane, 출발하다 - to depart

en: I'll buy a car two years from now.
not long ago
enAlt: recently

en: My older brother is good at swimming and also good at basketball.
notes: 수영 - swimming, 농구 - basketball

en: I like strawberries and I also like bananas.
notes: 딸기 - strawberries

en: I ate pizza and saw a movie.
At what time are you coming tomorrow?
notes: '나요' is used to politely and gently ask someone a question. It is similar to the basic 아/어요 questions but it is less direct, more introspective. When you use this ending, you are asking the question to yourself as well as to the listener, so it has the nuance of "I wonder..." in English. This ending can be used only with action verbs (and 있다/없다).

en: Has everybody come?
You don't have money?
notes: If you drop '요' from '나요', the meaning doesn't change but the sentence turns into the casual style.

en: Is that what you (director) teach them?
notes: 감독 - director, supervisor

en: I like airplanes because they are fast.
enAlt: Planes are good because they are fast.
notes: 비행기 - airplane, 빠르다 - to be fast

en: I had a rabbit as a pet for five years.
notes: 토끼 - rabbit, 기르다 - to raise

en: I came to Korea two years ago.
Please take this medicine before meals.
notes: 약 - medicine

en: I do warm-up exercises before swimming.
I work a part-time job during vacation.
notes: '때' expresses the time when something occurs. It is often translated as 'when' in English.

en: This is a picture of me when I was four years old.
What are you doing during Christmas?
I use chopsticks when I eat in Korea.
notes: 식사 - meal, 수저 - traditional Korean utensils, 사용하다 - to use

en: Korean is difficult but interesting.
My older brother is big, but my younger brother is small.
Hayeong eats a lot but she's slim.
notes: 날씬하다 - to be slim

en: I walked a lot, but I am not tired.
Even if I ask, there is no answer.
notes: 묻다 - to ask, 대답 - answer

en: It's chocolate.
notes: '(이)야' is used instead of '이에요'/'예요' in 반말 (casual language).

en: It's a desk.
What is this?
I’m going to work tomorrow.
Kyeong-eun! [Calling a person's first name to get their attention]
notes: In 반말, you add 아 or 야 to the name when you're calling the person. You never use '씨' in 반말.

en: Sorry. I ate an hour ago.

ko: 한국에서는 결혼하기 전에 남자가 집을 준비해요.
en: In Korea, before getting married, the groom will secure a home.
It's the same in my country.
Where did you live before coming to Korea?
I arrived at the airport around 1 o'clock.
notes: 공항 - airport

en: These days, tomatoes cost about 3,000 won.
Let's study.
Let’s not do it.
See you tomorrow.
enAlt: Let’s meet tomorrow.

en: Let's buy that one.
Let’s take the day off tomorrow.
notes: Technically '쉬다' means 'to rest' but it's often used in the sense of 'to not work'.

en: Let’s go to Korea together.
Let’s wait a little longer.
Bye! (to the person who is staying)
Bye! (to the person who is leaving)
I'm Kyeong-eun.
Yes, I'm okay.
enAlt: Yes, it's okay.
notes: 어 - yes (in the casual speech)

en: No, I'm not okay.
enAlt: No, it's not okay.

ko: 몇 살 때 첫 데이트를 했어요?
en: How old were you when you went on your first date?
notes: 첫 - first

en: Do you often meet your friends from elementary school?
Wesley goes to church every Sunday.
notes: '마다' is a particle that means 'every'.

en: The train comes once every hour.
I’m going to make a good name.
notes: 짓다 - to build, construct

en: Did you recover (completely) from the cold?
notes: 낫다 - to recover, get better, 감기 - cold

en: Please take your shoes off.
notes: 신발 - shoes, 벗다 - to take off

en: I cut my hair once every two months.
During lunchtime, all the cafeterias become full.
enAlt: There are no available seats in any cafeteria during lunchtime.
notes: 자리 - seat

ko: 이번 주 금요일 저녁에 시간 있어요?
en: Do you have time this Friday evening?
notes: 이번 - this

en: I have taekwondo lessons every Friday.
It's once every two days.
notes: 이틀 - two days

en: Are there computers in every classroom?
Yes, all classrooms have them.
notes: 모든 - all

en: Please go to the right from here.
notes: 오른쪽 - right side

en: I go from Seoul to Jeju Island by airplane.
notes: 제주도 - Jeju Island

en: I cut the paper with scissors.
notes: 가위 - scissors, 종이 - paper

en: I made jam from peanuts.
Are you good at eating spicy food?
enAlt: Can you eat spicy food well?

en: It's windy but not cold.
notes: 바람 - wind, 불다 - to blow

en: It's small but clean.
Yes, he's a foreigner but he can speak Korean well.
notes: 외국 - foreign country

en: I go to school and study.
notes: When you want to say you went somewhere and did something, you have to say '가서', not '가고'. The same rule applies to other similar verbs of motion.

en: Today, I was sitting in the bus during the ride here.
How do we take the listening test?
notes: 시험 - test

en: I can't swim.
notes: '-지 못해요' has the same meaning as 못 + verb.

en: I can't drink today.
I can't sing.
I came about a year ago.
About how much are apples these days?
Lately they cost about 2,000 won for three.
Please go to the right from that pharmacy (over there).
notes: 약국 - pharmacy, 오른쪽 - the right side

en: How do I get from Seoul to Busan?
Go by train. The train is fast.
notes: 기차 - train

en: This candy is good. What's it made of?
notes: 과자 - candy

en: Koreans eat rice with a spoon.
notes: 숟가락 - spoon

en: I go home from school by foot.
notes: If you note the means of transport with a verb, use the '서' form (걷다 -> 걸어서).

en: Does the Internet work now?
notes: 되다 - to function

en: Can you deliver it now?
notes: 되다 - to be possible, 배달 - delivery

en: Would you like to go for a drink after work?
notes: 퇴근 - leaving work

ko: 미안해요. 오늘 약속이 있어요. 다음에 같이해요.
en: Sorry. Today I have other plans. Let's do it next time.
notes: 약속 - appointment

en: Shall I open the window?
enAlt: Do you want me to open the window?
notes: The 'ㄹ까요?' form can be used not only to suggest doing something together, but also for other types of suggestions or asking the listener's opinion.

en: What shall I wear tomorrow?
Would you like (me to get you) some coffee or juice?
enAlt: Lit. Shall I give you coffee or juice?

en: My teeth hurt, so I can't eat.
notes: 이 - teeth

en: In the morning, I either eat bread or drink milk.
notes: '-거나' means 'or', it's added to verbs and adjectives. Note: use it in statements, not in questions.

ko: 주말에 음악을 듣거나 영화를 볼 거예요.
en: On the weekend, I plan to listen to music or watch a movie.

ko: 가족을 2년 동안 못 만났어요. 가족이 보고 싶어요.
en: I haven't seen my family for two years. I want to see my family.
notes: Even though -고 싶다 is usually used with the object marking particle, it can also be used with the subject marking particle. The meaning is the same but more emphasized.

en: Is anyone here?
enAlt: Lit: Is there no-one here?
notes: 아무도 - nobody (has to be followed by a negative verb)

en: Don’t touch anything.
enAlt: Lit: Don't touch "nothing".
notes: 아무것도 - nothing

en: I don’t know anything.
Nobody can come.
Airplanes are faster than trains.
My little sister is taller than my elder sister.
The department store is more expensive than the market.
I have to finish (this) work by tomorrow.
notes: 끝내다 - to finish something

en: I'll go to the department store and buy some clothes.

ko: 여자 친구 생일이에요. 무슨 선물을 살까요?
en: It's my girlfriend's birthday. What present should I get her?
Where should I put this computer?

ko: 낮에는 차가 많은데 밤에는 차가 없어요.
en: In the afternoon there are a lot of cars, but at night there aren't any.
notes: 낮 - daytime

en: I have an older brother but not an older sister.
I can't sing but I can dance well.
Whom shall I ask?
I'll either play tennis or go swimming.

ko: - 목이 아파요.- 그럼 생강차를 마시거나 사탕을 드세요.
en:
- I have a sore throat.
- Then (you should) drink some ginger tea or eat some candy.
notes: 드시다 - to eat (honorific)

en: We'll take a trip or go out to eat.
He peeled a banana and ate it.
notes: 까다 - to peel

ko: 네 시간 동안 공원에 앉아서 이야기했어요.
en: We sat in a park for four hours and talked.
notes: 이야기하다 - to talk

en: I bought a necklace for my girlfriend and gave it to her.
notes: In this sentence, '서' is omitted from '사서'. It can be done often when the meaning of '서' is 'and' (not 'because'). However, this doesn't work with some specific verbs like 가다, 오다, 서다.

en: I study Chinese all the time but it’s still difficult.
I rarely work out these days.
I'm sleepy. I want to drink some coffee.
What do you want for Christmas?

ko: 에릭 씨는 자동차를 사고 싶어 해요.
en: Eric wants to buy a car.
notes: When the subject is in the third person, you have to use -고 싶어 하다.

en: I can speak Korean.
I can't read Chinese characters.
Which is warmer, Jeju Island or Seoul?
Please don't drink alcohol.
Please don't sleep during class.
to walk quietly
notes: When a word ends in -히, it's almost always an adverb (and the same with -게).

ko: - 왜 그 시장에 안 가요?- 가격은 싼데 너무 멀어요.
en:
- Why don't you go to that market?
- The prices are low but it's too far away.
There are many things to do, but the salary is small.

ko: 내일 시험이 있어요. 그래서 공부해야 돼요.
en: I have an exam tomorrow. So I must study.
You have to pay before you eat.

ko: 한 시간 동안 서서 와서 다리가 아파요.
en: I stood for an hour on the way (here) so my legs are sore.
notes: 서다 - to stand

en: The child puts on glasses and reads books.
notes: When talking about wearing clothes or accessories, '고' is always used instead of '서'.

ko: 축구를 할 수 있어요. 그리고 태권도도 할 수 있어요. 그렇지만 수영은 할 수 없어요.
en: I can play soccer. I also know how to do taekwondo. But I can't swim.
Can you understand Korean TV dramas?
The topokki is so spicy that I can't eat it.
notes: '수' is a noun so you can attach the subject marking particle to it. Doing it emphasizes the meaning.

en: Don't watch this movie. It's boring.

ko: 음악을 너무 크게 듣지 마세요. 귀에 안 좋아요.
en: Don't listen to music too loudly. It's bad for your ears.

ko: 오늘부터 한국어를 더 열심히 공부할 거예요.
en: From today, I am going to study Korean harder.

ko: 아마 내일부터 일요일까지 비가 내릴 거예요.
en: It will probably rain from tomorrow until Sunday.

ko: 비행기 표를 예약했어요? 사람이 많아서 미리 예약해야 돼요.
en: Did you reserve a plane ticket? A lot of people will be going (there) so you have to reserve your ticket in advance.
notes: 미리 - in advance

en: I had a lot of things to do so I had to stay at the office and work.
I'll answer the phone.
Sorry. I have work to do so I'll be leaving now.
notes: 먼저 - first

ko: 싫은 사람이 있으면 저는 돌아 가요.
en: If I see someone I don't like I go around (to avoid them).
enAlt: If there is someone I don't like I take a different path.
notes: It was originally '돌아서 가요'

en: Do you love me?
Did you have a pleasant weekend?
I was in such a good mood that I danced.
I'm sorry for arriving late.
Please don't play here.
Please transfer to a bus in front of the school.
notes: 갈아타다 - to change vehicles

en: I'll definitely bring it tomorrow.
notes: 가지고 오다 - to bring, 꼭 - definitely

en: I'll write it down (on paper) for you.
notes: The construction 아/어 드리다 is similar to 아/어 주다, only more honorific. It's often used when you want to offer to do something for somebody politely.

en: Do you have time today?
No, I'm not that busy.

ko: 댄 씨 어머님이 언제 서울에 오시나요?
en: Dane, when is your mother coming to Seoul?
This week I'm busy and don't have time.
Those clothes are so small that I can't wear them.
It's cold, so shall I close the window?

ko: 제 동생은 학생인데 공부를 아주 잘해요.
en: My little sister is a student, and she studies really hard.
You've bought a lot already, so shall we go?
notes: 이제 - now

en: Let's leave in 10 minutes.
I came to Korea to see my Korean fans.
Can you play the piano?

ko: 정민 씨 어머니께서 맛있는 음식을 많이 준비하셨어요.
en: Jeongmin's mother prepared a lot of delicious food.
notes: '께서' is the honorific subject marking particle.

en: Some foreign guests are here, so I need someone to interpret.
notes: 필요하다 - to need

en: No one will do it.

ko: 매운 음식을 좋아해요?- 아니요, 안 좋아해요.
en:
Do you like spicy food?
- No, I don't like it.

ko: 바지가 좀 긴데 다른 바지 없어요?
en: These pants are a little long. Do you have any other ones?
notes: 길다 - to be long

en: The weather is nice. Shall we go mountain climbing?
This bibimpap I'm eating, it's very delicious.
I'm baking bread, but there's no milk.
There's someone outside - who could it be?
I don't have any money. Would you lend me some?
notes: 빌려주다 - to lend

en: This apple is delicious - where did you buy it?
I'm still a student but I will graduate this year.
notes: 올해 - this year

ko: 이 옷을 어제 샀는데 마음에 안 들어요.
en: I bought these clothes yesterday, but I'm not pleased with them.
notes: '마음에 들다' - to like something (that you see for the first time)

en: Grandma can't hear you even if you speak loudly.
notes: 크게 말하다 - to speak loudly, 할머니 - grandma

ko: 이 옷이 마음에 들어요. 비싸도 사고 싶어요.
en: I like these clothes. I want to buy them even if they are expensive.
Even if I listen to the news, I can't understand it.
notes: 이해하다 - to understand

en: Please come visit us over the weekend.
notes: 놀다 - to play, to hang out

en: I'm attending an academy to learn Korean dance.
notes: 춤 - dance

en: Your friend called.
notes: It doesn't sound good if you attach '께서' directly to '친구', you have to make it more honorific first by adding '분'. You would say this about a friend of your parents, for example, not about your own friends.

en: I plan to buy some shoes or a bag.
notes: 구두 - shoes

en: What kind of movie would you like to watch?
notes: 어떤 - what kind of

ko: 어떤 음식을 좋아해요?- 매운 음식을 좋아해요.
en:
What kind of food do you like?
- I like spicy food.
I am going to buy shoes that are cheap and comfortable.
notes: 편하다 - to be comfortable

en: How about a camera as her birthday present?
It's 2:50 right now. We won't be there by 3:00 even if we take a taxi.

ko: 바빠도 아침 식사를 꼭 해야 해요.
en: You have to eat breakfast even if you're busy.
These days, I study English every day after getting off work.

ko: 비나 눈이 오면 집에서 텔레비전을 봐요.
en: If it rains or snows then I watch TV at home.
Please stay in touch when you're back home.
enAlt: Please stay in touch after you go back home.
notes: 연락 - contact, connection

en: Where will you live once you get married?
enAlt: Where will you live after you get married?

en: It's similar to a computer.
It was the same as the Christmas party.
notes: The '랑' here is very important. If you forget it then you'll be saying "It looked like a Christmas party".

en: English is different from Korean.
Women and men are different.
It's the same as yesterday.
Japanese and Korean are similar.
Please be here by 10 o'clock.
notes: '-십시오' is the formal style imperative ending.

en: Be careful not to catch a cold.
Please sit (down) here.
Please go up to the 3rd floor.
notes: 올라가다 - to go up

en: What is your name?
notes: 성함 - the honorific version of '이름'. "어떻게 되세요" is a fixed expression (very polite) to find out someone's name, age etc.

en: I want to become a teacher.
In winter, water becomes ice.
notes: 얼음 - ice

en: Let me help you with that.
I went to Korea without knowing Korean.
We talked while walking.
Why are you asking me (something like) that?
notes: '그런' is the adjective form of '그렇다'.

en: You'll be hot if you wear that.

ko: 하영 씨에게는 보라색 티셔츠가 잘 어울릴 거예요.
en: I think Hayeong will look good in a violet T-shirt.
notes: 보라색 티셔츠 - violet T-shirt

ko: 그 옷은 입기가 불편해요. 그래서 안 사요.
en: Wearing this outfit is uncomfortable so I won't buy it.

ko: 여기는 버스 타기가 불편해요. 지하철을 탑시다.
en: Taking the bus from here is inconvenient. Let's take the subway.

ko: 네, 그렇지만 자주 안 와서 지하철이 더 편할 거예요.
en: Yes, but it doesn't come very often, so the subway may be more convenient.
I didn’t do anything.
I cut my hair short.
I woke up late today.
The children are hungry.
notes: You can use '-아/어 + 하다' to turn descriptive verbs into action verbs. The change in meaning is sometimes very subtle, it's related to outward appearances or actions. For example, in this case you observe that the children are acting as if they were hungry.

en: Recently, my father has been tired.
The child is bored.
notes: 심심하다 - to be bored, 심심해하다 - to act bored

en: What are you waiting for?
notes: 뭘 = 뭐+를

ko: 화장실 청소를 해 주세요. 깨끗하게 해 주세요.
en: Please tidy up the bathroom. Make it clean.
I bought it cheap on sale.
I have a girlfriend.
I want to go to Korea, but I don't have money.
Then please give me two of those.
