notes: 그걸로 = 그것으로. '로' has five usages altogether: means, direction, selection, change of state, and reason. In this example it is selection.

en: I think it's interesting.
notes: The '-는데요' ending can also be used when you disagree with someone. "Well, you may think this movie is boring but I don't."

en: Minu is not at his desk right now.
Don't do it if you don't want to.

ko: 재준 씨, 오늘 왜 이렇게 기분이 좋아요?
en: Jaejun, why are you in such a good mood today?
Can you say that in Korean?
I was eating when my mother called me.
When did you fall ill?
notes: '-기 시작하다' - to start doing something

en: We started studying Korean two years ago.
It started raining a while ago.

ko: 한 달 전부터 아침에 운동을 하기 시작했습니다.
en: A month ago I started exercising in the mornings.
I didn't leave the house for two months.
notes: 개월 - month (counter)

en: A mosquito bit me, so my eye became swollen.
notes: 모기 - mosquito, 물다 - to bite, 붓다 - to be swollen

ko: 컵에 커피와 크림, 설탕을 넣고 저어요.
en: I put coffee, cream, and sugar in the cup and stir it all together.
notes: 젓다 - to stir

en: This is the first time I see such a person.
notes: '이런' = the adjective form of '이렇다' (to be like this)

en: How about that color?
I will (either) go home or meet a friend.
I sang a song for the kids.

ko: 마이클 씨는 무슨 일로 한국에 왔어요?
en: Michael, what brings you to Korea?
notes: 일 - matter; particle '로' is used to indicate reason in this case.

en: Why are you going to Seoul?
The kid resembles his dad.
notes: 얘 = 이 아이 (this kid)

en: I'm not really in a good mood.
What's that?
notes: = 그것이 무엇인데요?

ko: 저에게 한국 영화 DVD가 많이 있어요.
en: I have many DVDs with Korean movies.
Pleaase give me one that's not spicy.
Is there anything else you need?
notes: The verb 있다 has two meanings - existence and posession. The honorific form for existence is 계시다, and for posession it's 있으시다.

en: We don't have a wallet like that here.
enAlt: There's no such wallet here.

en: a person who sings
enAlt: a person who is singing
notes: This is a very important aspect of Korean grammar. In the English translation, "who sings" is a subordinate clause that refers to the word directly before it, in this case "person". In Korean, the same thing is expressed in an adjective phrase that comes before the noun. The verb from the subordinate clause is turned into an adjective by adding either -는 (present), -ㄴ (past), or -ㄹ (future).

en: a book that I like
notes: The noun that is described by the action-verb-turned-adjective can be the subject or the object of the action. In this case it is the object.

en: a book that I don’t like
notes: 나 (I) + 가 = 내가

en: someone that Minji likes
notes: The subject marking particle helps clarify the meaning in this case. Without it, we wouldn't know whether Minji likes someone or someone likes Minji.

en: someone that likes me
This song is a song that I like.
Is there any Korean food that you eat often?
Is there a cafe that you go to often?
Which singer do you like these days?
enAlt: Who is the singer that you like these days?
notes: 가수 - singer

en: The foreign language I am studying these days is Japanese.
notes: 외국어 - foreign language, 일본어 - Japanese

ko: 눈이 오는 날에는 영화 보고 싶어요.
en: On a day when it snows, I want to see a movie.
That person who is over there, is it someone that you know?
notes: 알다 + 는 = 아는 (the ㄹ often gets removed before various endings)

en: No, it's someone that I don't know.
enAlt: No, I don't know him.

en: Is anyone hungry?
I'm going mountain hiking on the weekend.
enAlt: I want to go mountain hiking on the weekend.
notes: '-ㄹ래요' expresses the intention or will (or wish) of the speaker. This is a rather casual ending mostly used among close acquaintances.

en: I'm going to watch a movie in the evening.
I'm going to put on an overcoat.
Do you want to read a book?
enAlt: Would you like to read a book?
notes: When used in a question, this ending refers to the intention or preference of the listener.

en: Are you going to listen to some music?
enAlt: Do you want to listen to some music?

en: Would you like to take a walk with me?
I'm going to make bulgogi.
I'm going to buy a compact car.
doing something
enAlt: the thing that you do
notes: This is one way to turn action verbs into nouns. 것 = 거 = thing.

en: eating
enAlt: the thing that you eat
notes: -는 turns the verb into an adjective (present tense) and adding 것 makes it a noun

en: I'm listening to a song now.
enAlt: What I am listening to now is a song.
notes: 듣다 - to listen

en: Do you know that we are meeting today?
My hobby is watching movies.
notes: 제 취미 - my hobby

en: What is it that you are studying these days?
enAlt: What have you been studying recently?
notes: 요즘 - these days

en: I like chitchatting with my friends.
notes: 수다떨다 - to chitchat. The 'ㄹ' is removed from the verb stem before adding -는.

ko: 저는 책을 읽는 것보다 사는 것을 더 좋아해요.
en: I like buying books more than reading books.
Do you think it will rain tomorrow?
enAlt: I wonder if it will rain tomorrow.

en: Who do you think this person is?
enAlt: I wonder who this person is.

en: Do you think she did it yesterday?
notes: If you insert the past tense suffix, the question becomes about something that happened in the past.

en: for the sake of health
enAlt: in order to be healthy
notes: 건강 - health

en: for the company
enAlt: for the good of the company
notes: '-를 위해서' is more often used in the written language

en: in order to learn Japanese

ko: 저는 한국에 가기 위해서 열심히 공부했어요.
en: I studied hard in order to go to Korea.
I saved up money for my parents.
I am exercising every day for my health.
notes: 매일 - every day

en: Is it okay to start?
enAlt: May I start?
notes: 아/어도 되다 expresses permission or approval of a behavior

en: You may turn on the light.
enAlt: It's okay, you can turn the light on.
notes: 켜다 - to turn on

en: You may do it tomorrow.
Can I do this later?
May I use the computer?
enAlt: Do you mind if I use the computer?

en: You can take the day off today.
You don't have to study today.
enAlt: It's okay if you don't study today.

en: You don’t have to drink it.
I think it’s strange.
enAlt: It seems to be strange.
notes: 이상하다 (to be strange) is a descriptive verb so you have to add -ㄴ instead of -는.

en: It seems to be snowing.
enAlt: I think it’s snowing.

en: I think it will snow.
enAlt: It seems like it will snow.
notes: The 'ㄹ' changes the verb into the future tense.

en: I think they are talking.
enAlt: They seem to be talking.

en: I think they are talking in English.
notes: This '것 같아요' construction might seem strange or overly complicated at first but Koreans use it a lot to make their sentences less direct. Instead of saying '이야기해요', they say '이야기하는 것 같아요'.

en: I think she told him.
enAlt: It looks like they talked.
notes: 'ㄴ' instead of '는' denotes the past tense.

en: I think it's good.
This place seems to be expensive.
I think so.
I think this movie will be interesting.
I think I probably won’t do it.
notes: 아마 - probably

en: This is Hanguk University, isn't it?
enAlt: This is Hanguk University, right?
notes: '지요' (sometimes shortened to 죠) is an ending you can use when you want to confirm something that you think is true.

en: That is a fruit store, right?
enAlt: That is a fruit store, isn't it?
notes: 과일 - fruit, 가게 - store

en: Today is Wednesday, isn't it?
Your brother is a college student, isn't he?
a generous person
enAlt: a person with a "wide" heart

en: I brush my teeth after dinner.
notes: When '후에' is used after verbs, the verb needs to be changed into the ㄴ/은 form. 이 - teeth

en: I got a job after graduating from college.

ko: 미안해요. 바빠요. 수업이 끝난 다음에 식당에서 아르바이트를 해요.
en: Sorry. I'm busy. After class ends, I have a part-time job at a restaurant.
notes: 아르바이트 - part-time job. "다음에" means the same thing as "후에"

ko: 다른 데 가요. 여기 안 좋은 것 같아요.
en: Let’s go somewhere else. I think this place is not so good.
I drink only cola.
enAlt: I drink nothing but cola.
notes: 밖에 + a negative verb means "only". This construction is actually used more often than '-만'.

en: I only have one Korean friend.
notes: This "밖에" construction can't be used in imperative sentences or in sentences where the verb already has a negative meaning (like 싫다, for example).

en: I can only speak a little bit of Korean.
You only have this?
My cat only eats tuna.
notes: 참치 - tuna

en: Why do you only study?

ko: 친구들이 점심을 먹는 동안 나는 숙제를 했어요.
en: I did my homework while my friends were eating lunch.
notes: If you want to use "동안" with verbs, you have to add '는' after the verb stem.

en: after receiving a letter

ko: 영화 본 다음에 우리 커피 마셔요.
en: After watching the movie, let’s drink coffee.
After having lunch, I went to the library.
notes: '뒤에' can be used instead of '다음에' or '후에' but it's not as common as the other two.

ko: 이거 한 다음에 뭐 할 거예요?
en: What are you going to do after doing this?
Contact me after you decide.
notes: 결정하다 - to decide, 연락 - contact, connection

en: Thanks for your concern.
enAlt: Lit. Thank you for worrying about me.
notes: 걱정하다 - to worry

ko: 그러면 비행기를 기다리는 동안 면세점에서 쇼핑을 합시다.
en: In that case, let's do some shopping at the duty-free shop while we wait for our flight.
notes: 면세점 - duty-free shop

en: My friend might know her.
enAlt: My friend might know that.
notes: '-ㄹ 수도 있다' means 'might'

en: We might meet again tomorrow.
The hat could be too small for you.
notes: Koreans often drop the 'too' part when they compare things.

en: I might come here tomorrow.

ko: 저 내일 안 올 수도 있어요.
en: I might not come here tomorrow.
This might be fake.
notes: 가짜 - fake, imitation

en: It might really be so.
a train bound for Busan
notes: '행' means 'bound for', it's usually attached to place names

ko: 시험 볼 때 옆 사람의 시험지를 보지 마세요.
en: Don't look at your neighbors' answer sheets when taking the test.
notes: When you use '때' with verbs, you need to add 'ㄹ' to the verb.

en: I eat a hamburger when I don't have time (to eat properly).
I use it when it's hot.
I didn't know that this series would be so interesting but it is!
notes: You can use the '-네요' ending to show your surprise or impression.

en: (Oh, I didn't know before but) it is big.
notes: '네요' can be used only when you learn something through direct experience.

en: I see that it's correct!
notes: If you already knew that it was correct, you should use the plain present tense ending. '네요' can be used when you find something out for the first time.

en: Oh, here it is!
Oh, it’s not that cold.
Oh, look. Nobody is here yet.
notes: '아무도' means 'nobody'. It has to be followed by the negative form of a verb, in this case "hasn't come".

en: Wow, it’s already November!
Be careful when you sit on the chair.
notes: 조심하다 - to be careful

ko: 제가 한국에 갔을 때 날씨가 아주 추웠어요.
en: When I went to Korea, it was very cold.
I went there when I was a middle school student.

ko: 한국에 올 때마다 한국 음식을 먹어요.
en: Whenever I come to Korea, I eat Korean food.
notes: You can add various particles after '때'.

en: I like walking.
I rest after finishing my work.
notes: You can use '-고 나서' if the first action is (completely) finished and it's followed by the second action (right away).

en: I go to bed after watching TV.
I read the newspaper after eating breakfast.

ko: 이 옷은 실크예요. 세탁할 때 조심하세요.
en: This clothing is made of silk. Be careful when you wash it.
notes: 세탁하다 - to do laundry

en: Is the weather cold?
notes: This ending -ㄴ가요? is used only with descriptive verbs and it has the same meaning as the -나요? ending for action verbs.

en: Is the house roomy?
notes: 넓다 - to be spacious

en: I’ll do it alone.
enAlt: I want to do it alone.

en: I don’t want to go.
enAlt: I’m not going to go.

en: What do you want to drink?
enAlt: What are you going to drink?

en: Do you want to drink coffee or tea?
Do you want to see this?
enAlt: Do you want to watch this one?

en: At what time do you want to meet tomorrow?
Manager Kim, by when should I give you the documents?
Please give it to me after the meeting.

ko: 문제를 잘 듣고 나서 대답을 찾으세요.
en: Listen to the questions carefully, and then find the answer.
It's what you write after you finish reading a book.
notes: 글 - a piece of writing

en: I have been to the U.S.
notes: This is the past perfect tense. It means that the action has been finished and doesn't apply to today. In this example, it means that the person is not in the U.S. anymore.

en: I lived in China.
notes: The person doesn't live in China anymore.

en: My father was overweight.
It's Friday.
notes: The -지요 ending can be used (in statements) when you know that the other person also knows what you are talking about, you're not saying anything new. You're just mentioning what is known already. '지요' can be shortened to '죠'.

en: What is this?
notes: If you ask yourself a question, you have to use the casual style.

en: The weather is cold today, isn't it?
That’s right. Pizza really is delicious.
It’s fun, right?
What is this?
notes: 이게 = 이거 + subject marking particle

en: Yeah, that could be possible.
I wish I had a car.
notes: '-았/었으면 좋겠다' is used to express a wish or hope.

en: I wish I had a lot of money.
I hope it snows on Christmas.
You shouldn’t open it.
enAlt: You may not open it.
notes: '면 안 되다' means 'shouldn't' or 'may not' or 'not allowed'.

en: You may open it.
Am I not supposed to open it?
enAlt: (Are you saying) I shouldn't open it?

en: You shouldn’t touch it.
enAlt: You may not touch it.

en: You should not throw it.
May I sell it here?
notes: Since this is asking for permission, you can translate it into the positive sentence in English.

en: So can't we tell it now?

ko: 바쁘거나 가방이 무거울 때 택시를 타요.
en: I take a taxi when I'm busy or my bag is too heavy.
notes: 무겁다 - to be heavy

en: She's in a meeting now.
enAlt: I'm in the middle of a meeting.
notes: 회의 - meeting, 중 - middle

en: between this book and that book
notes: Use this when choosing from a few options, not when describing location

en: He is popular among friends.
notes: 사이에서 - among, 인기 - popularity

ko: 이 가수는 한국인들 사이에서 인기가 많아요.
en: This singer is popular among Koreans.
notes: 한국인 means the same as 한국사람 but is more formal.

en: I am between the bank and the park.
The pharmacy is between the school and the police station.
notes: 경찰서 - police station

ko: 작년에는 담배를 피웠었어요. 그렇지만 지금은 안 피워요.
en: I smoked last year. But I don't smoke now.
notes: 담배 - cigarettes

en: There were many people (there) in the summer.
Anybody can come.
notes: 아무나 - anybody

en: Please give me (just) anything.
notes: 아무거나 - anything

en: Any place is good.
notes: 아무데나 - anywhere

en: I’m not going anywhere.
Not everybody can come.
enAlt: Not just anyone can come.

en: You shouldn’t eat just anything.
You shouldn’t eat anything at all.
I don’t want to go just about anywhere.
I don’t want to go anywhere.
I'd like to get married before I'm 30.

ko: - 요즘도 바빠요?- 네, 계속 바빠요. 좀 쉬었으면 좋겠어요.
en:
- Are you still busy these days?
- Yes, I'm still busy. I wish I could have some time off.
notes: 계속 - continuously

ko: 친구들하고 스키장에 갈 거예요. 방학이 빨리 왔으면 좋겠어요.
en: I plan to go skiing with my friends. I wish the vacation would come sooner.
notes: 스키장 - ski resort

ko: - 집에 가도 돼요?- 네, 집에 가도 돼요.
en:
- May I go home?
- Yes, you may go home.
May I call at night?
enAlt: Do you mind if I call at night?

en: Is it all right to eat this?
You cannot go home.
You may not enter.
notes: 들어가다 - to go in

en: You shouldn't eat this bread.
You may not take pictures here.
You are not allowed to listen to music in the classroom.
It is my first semester so I am a little busy.
notes: (이)라서 is a combination of 이다 and 아서/어서, and it's mostly used in spoken Korean. It's the same as '이어서/여서'. The sentence above is equivalent to: 첫 학기예요. 그래서 조금 바빠요.

en: I am not busy these days because I'm on vacation.
notes: The '서' part in '라서' is optional. 한가하다 - to have free time

en: Have you tried using this?
enAlt: Have you used it before?
notes: 아/어 + 보다 - to try something (and see what happens)

en: Shall we try going in (and see what it’s like)?
Try doing it one more time.
I want to try doing this.
Try eating this.
enAlt: Try some of this.

en: I haven’t been there yet, either.
enAlt: I haven’t tried going there, either.

en: I will try doing it first.
enAlt: I will give it a try first.

en: I’ve always wanted to ask you.
notes: 항상 - always

ko: 시간이 없어서 친구들을 거의 못 만나요.
en: I don’t have time so I can hardly meet my friends.
notes: 거의 - almost

en: Just come anytime.
You didn’t tell them anything, right?
Don’t give it to anybody.
You can do it whatever way you want.

ko: 여자 친구 생일이라서 선물을 사야 돼요.
en: It's my girlfriend's birthday so I have to buy her a present.
I'm okay.
notes: 전 = 저 + 는. The topic marking particle often gets shortened like this in spoken Korean.

en: I’ll stay here.
What is this?
What brings you to Seoul?
Why didn’t you come yesterday?
Why do you eat apples without peeling them?
notes: 깎지 않고 = 깎다 + 지 않다 + 고

en: Apples aren't tasty if you peel them before eating.
I plan to make some money and buy a camera.
enAlt: I'm going to make some money in order to buy a camera.
notes: 벌다 - to earn money

en: The roads are full of traffic so let's take the subway.
notes: '-니까' expresses the reason or cause for something. Its meaning is similar to '서' but they are not interchangeable. '서' is mainly used to express general statements while '니까' is used in other types of sentences, for example, when asking or suggesting or planning something.

en: It's cold so please close the window.
I took a shower so now I feel good.
notes: When you're stating a subjective reason, '니까' is more appropriate than '서'.

en: the prettiest girl
notes: 제일 - the most

en: the best thing
This is the best (one).
Where is the closest station?
notes: 가깝다 - to be close

en: Which color is your favorite?
notes: '가장' is the same as '제일' but used more often in the written language.

en: Who is the person that came here first?
notes: 먼저 - first

ko: 요즘 가장 인기 있는 가수는 누구예요?
en: These days, who is the most popular singer?
Have you tried Korean ribs?
Please try it on.
I want to visit Jeju Island.
It’s less cold than yesterday.
notes: 덜 - less

en: Don’t you have a less expensive one?

ko: 물은 더 마시고, 술은 덜 마셔야 돼요.
en: You should drink more water and less alcohol.

ko: - 그 맥주 다 마셨어요?- 아니요. 다 안 마셨어요. 덜 마셨어요.
en:
- Have you finished drinking that beer?
- No, I haven't finished it yet.
notes: '덜' can be the opposite not only to '더' but also to '다'.

en:
- Are we there yet?
- Not yet.

ko: - 제 책 돌려주세요.- 아직 덜 봤어요.
en:
- Give me my book back.
- I haven’t finished it yet.

ko: 길이 막히니까 버스를 타지 마세요. 지하철을 타세요.
en: There's a lot of traffic, so don't take the bus. Take the subway.
notes: 막히다 - to be blocked, clogged

en: Do you want to go hiking?
Would you like to have a cup of coffee?
Would you like to go ride a boat on the Han River?

ko: 내일 시간이 있으면 같이 커피 마실래요?
en: If you have time tomorrow, will you drink coffee together (with me)?
It's my mother's birthday and I have to go home.
Girls like flowers, so give her some flowers.
The subway is under construction.
notes: 공사 - construction

en: The subway is in the middle of being constructed.
I'm on the way home.

ko: 이사할 거예요. 그래서 집을 찾는 중이에요.
en: I intend to move. So I'm looking for a new place to live.

ko: - 이 신발 신어 봐도 돼요?- 네, 신어 보세요.
en:
- May I try on these shoes?
- Yes, please try them on.
I would like to make some Korean friends.
notes: 사귀다 - to make friends

en: Have you tried drinking Korean rice wine?
Do you have a lot of Korean friends?
What am I supposed to do?
enAlt: How should we deal with this?
notes: This is a contraction from "어떻게 해요?" and it's used when something bad or unexpected has happened and you have to decide what to do about it.

en: How are you going to take care of it now?
enAlt: Now what?
notes: Short from "이제 어떡할 거예요?"

ko: 유키 씨, 우리 시험 끝나고 뭐 할래요?
en: Yuki, what do you want to do after we finish our tests?
This is much better.
notes: You can omit the '더' if you want.

ko: 서울에서 도쿄까지보다 서울에서 뉴욕까지가 훨씬 더 멀어요.
en: From Seoul to New York is much farther away than from Seoul to Tokyo.
Korean is much easier than Japanese.
to be much less expensive
(Oh, look,) the weather is really nice.
Shall we go mountain climbing since the weather is nice?
You drank liquor, so please don't drive.
notes: You can use the past tense before -니까

en: The road is slippery because of the snow.
notes: Noun + 때문에 = because of Noun

en: I'm tired because of the children.
I can't speak Korean well because I'm a foreigner.
notes: If you want to use '때문에' with a verb (이다 in this case), you have to change it to the noun form first.

en: a book that (I) will read
enAlt: a book to read

en: things to eat
enAlt: food

en: I have a lot (of work) to do tomorrow.
enAlt: There is a lot of stuff that I will do tomorrow.

en: Right now, I have nothing to say.
enAlt: For now, there is nothing I will say.

en: In the refrigerator, there isn’t any food at all.

ko: 백화점이 세일 중이에요. 그래서 길이 막혀요.
en: The department store is having a sale. That's why there's so much traffic.

ko: 김 과장님은 지금 외출 중이십니다. 오후 5시에 들어오실 겁니다.
en: Section Chief Kim is currently out of the office. He should be back at 5 P.M.

ko: 요즘 운전을 배우는 중이에요. 다음 주에 운전면허 시험을 봐요.
en: Recently, I've been learning how to drive. I'm taking a driving test next week.
May I sit here?
enAlt: Do you mind if I sit here?

en: the movie that I saw yesterday
notes: Remember: 보는 - present, 본 - past, 볼 - future.

en: Who are the people who came here yesterday?
the cafe that a friend talked about
It’s a book that I will read.
It’s the foreign language that I studied yesterday.
Are you busy these days?
What time will you leave your house?
This year, I'm going to stop smoking.
notes: -겠- can be used to express an intention or that something will happen. In this meaning, it is usually followed by the formal style.

en: I'll go on the business trip.
notes: If you are expressing someone's will or intention, the subject cannot be in the third person.

en: We will soon arrive at Incheon Airport.
What do you think this is?
Who do you think did it?
I think I’ll arrive soon.
Do you take the bus when you go home?
I'm so full. I'm not going to eat anymore.
notes: 그만 - without doing anything further, only this much

en: to become pretty
notes: When you add '아/어지다' to a descriptive verb, it changes the meaning to 'become [adjective]'.

en: The weather has become warm.
enAlt: The weather has become warmer.
notes: 따뜻해지다 - to become warm

en: The computer has become fast.
enAlt: The computer has become faster.

en: Studying Korean has become fun.
The line has become longer.
It will become cold again tomorrow.
There was a lot of traffic due to the rain.

ko: 토요일은 친구 생일이기 때문에 만날 수 없어요.
en: Saturday is my friend's birthday, so I won't be able to meet you.
I'm going to the department store. Do you want to join me?

ko: 월요일에 시험이 있으니까 클럽에 가지 맙시다. 같이 공부합시다.
en: We have a test on Monday, so let's not go to a club. Let's study together.
I take the train which leaves at 10:00.

ko: 제 친구가 다니는 회사는 서울에 있어요.
en: The company my friend works for is in Seoul.
notes: It would be incorrect to write "친구는" in this case. If it's inside a relative clause (sometimes called a noun phrase), you have to replace the topic marking particle with the subject marking particle.

en: The movie that Sally is watching is a Korean movie.
I want to buy the book that Daniel is reading.
I know the song that Jeongmin is singing.
The one playing tennis is Sally.

ko: 내가 듣고 있는 음악은 한국 음악이에요.
en: The music that I'm listening to is Korean music.
The food that I'm making now is bulgogi.
I know the guy who is studying with Daniel.
I invited all the people I know.

ko: 내일 제가 부산에 가는데 공항에 같이 가 줄 수 있어요?
en: I'm going to Busan tomorrow, so can you go to the airport with me?
In that case, Chief, I will interpret for you.
I don't quite understand.
enAlt: I'm not sure.
notes: '-겠-' can also be used in some fixed expressions to soften the meaning of the sentence and make it more gentle and polite.

en: Using the phone while driving is not allowed.

ko: 오늘은 어제보다 훨씬 따뜻한 것 같아요.
en: I think today is much warmer than yesterday.

ko: 지금 카페에서 어제 산 책을 읽고 있어요.
en: Right now I am in a cafe, reading a book that I bought yesterday.

ko: 네, 안 갈래요. 피곤해서 집에서 쉴래요.
en: No, I'm not going. I'm tired so I plan on resting at home.
Soldiers are people who work for their country.
notes: 군인 - soldiers

ko: 훌륭한 스케이트 선수가 되기 위해 열심히 연습을 합니다.
en: I practice hard to become a great skater.
notes: 선수 - athlete

ko: 학교 옆에 '만나식당'이 괜찮은데 거기 한번 가 보세요.
en: The restaurant Manna right next to school is pretty good, so I suggest you go there.
to be about to buy something
enAlt: to be intending to buy it
notes: '-(으)려고 하다' shows either your intention or plan or that something is about to happen

en: It is about to rain, judging from what I see.
notes: Note: this form is rarely used like this in the plain present tense. People would usually say '비가 올 것 같아요' instead. But it is used often in other forms.

ko: 어제 친구 만나려고 했는데, 못 만났어요.
en: I wanted to meet a friend yesterday, but I couldn’t meet her.
enAlt: I was planning to meet a friend yesterday, but I couldn’t meet her.

en: I’m planning to buy a camera. Which one is good?
My friend is about to cry.
The ice cream is about to melt.
notes: 녹다 - to melt

en: Wow, that looks delicious.
notes: '-겠-' is also used to say how something looks or appears.

en: Look at that poster. It looks interesting!
That looks refreshing.
I don't understand this grammar question.
Please ask instructor Lee or instructor Kim.

ko: 수업 시간에는 영어로 말하면 안 돼요.
en: During class, you may not speak in English.

ko: 한국에서는 밥을 먹을 때 코를 풀면 안 돼요.
en: In Korea, you're not supposed to blow your nose when eating.
You're not allowed to talk in the library.
Will Carol show up today?
Do you think Dane has read this book?
Where do you think Jeongmin is right now?
Do you think there will be many people at the movie theater?
Who do you think knows Jeongmin's phone number?
How about doing it again?
How about asking other people?
How about going inside?
How about meeting and talking about it tomorrow?
How about doing it this way?
notes: This sentence contains the subject marking particle: -는 것이 → -는 게

ko: 반갑습니다. 회사를 위해서 열심히 일해 주십시오.
en: Pleased to meet you. I trust you'll work hard for the company.
Congratulations on buying an apartment.

ko: 이 집을 사기 위해서 우리 부부가 열심히 돈을 모았어요.
en: We both worked hard to save money to buy this home.
notes: 부부 - husband and wife

en: Who is that person sleeping on the sofa?

ko: 오늘 저녁에 먹을 한국 음식이 뭐예요?
en: What's the Korean dish that we'll have for dinner today?
Do you know how to get to Myeongdong?
notes: '-는지' is a sentence connecting ending that is attached to action verbs. It allows to make phrases such as "Do you know...?", "Please tell me...", "I will find out..." etc.

en: I don't know who that person is.
notes: After nouns and descriptive verbs, this ending is -ㄴ지.

ko: 어제 무엇을 했는지 생각이 안 나요.
en: I can't remember what I did yesterday.
Do you know what this is?
I don’t know what is good.
Please ask them whether there is a problem.
Do you know who this person is?
Please see if this is okay.
Please tell me what you want to buy.

ko: 내일 우리 만날 수 있는지 알고 싶어요.
en: I want to know whether we can meet tomorrow.

ko: 내일 우리 만날 수 있는지 없는지 알고 싶어요.
en: I want to know whether or not we can meet tomorrow.
notes: "있는지 없는지" means "whether or not"

en: Do you not know why I worry?
Every day? That sounds tough.
notes: -이요 is added just to make the first sentence polite.

en: This is the book I've been using to study Korean lately.
We plan to live in an apartment near the company.

ko: 요즘 꽃이 비쌀까요?- 졸업식 때니까 비쌀 거예요.
en:
Do you think flowers are expensive these days?
- It's graduation time, so I think they're probably expensive.
notes: The '-ㄹ 거예요' construction can express assumption or supposition when the speaker has a reason for thinking what he's thinking (like in this example).

ko: 댄 씨가 일을 잘하니까 이번에 승진할 거예요.
en: Dane is a hard worker so I think he'll be promoted this time.
Are you selling this picture?
notes: This is an alternative way of saying "이 그림을 팔아요?", the meaning is practically the same.

en: How was the restaurant that you went to yesterday?
I like girls who are nice and pretty.
notes: If there are several adjectives before a noun, only the last adjective has the -은 ending.

en: I know how to make strawberry jam.
notes: '-을 줄 알다/모르다' is a grammar pattern that expresses whether you know how to do something.

en: I know how to send pictures by mobile phone.
I know how to cook a tasty doenjang stew.
notes: 끓이다 - to boil, cook

en: I watched a boring movie.

ko: 수업이 끝나고 나서 우리는 집에 갔습니다.
en: We went home after the class ended.

ko: 숙제를 다 하고 나서 책을 읽었습니다.
en: After finishing all my homework, I read a book.
What kind of work is he doing now?
notes: '-고 계시다' is the honorific version of '-고 있다'.

en: I'm planning to buy a present for my friend.
I'm planning to listen to music at home.

ko: 저는 제주도에 여러 번 가 봤어요.
en: I have been to Jeju Island several times.
Try to play the guitar, please.

ko: 방에 있는데 공부하는지 자는지 잘 모르겠어요.
en: He's in his room but I don't know if he's studying or sleeping.

ko: 그 사람이 일본 사람인지 아닌지 모르겠어요.
en: I don't know whether he is Japanese or not.
notes: "아닌지" comes from "아니다" (to be not)

ko: 우산이 두 개 있는데 빌려 줄까요?
en: I have two umbrellas. Shall I lend you one?

ko: 우리 아이가 벌써 10살이 되었어요. 세월이 참 빠르지요?
en: Our kid is already 10 years old. Doesn't time just fly by?
notes: 세월 - time

en: Have you heard this song (before)?
You certainly have a large family.
You really have read a lot of books.
I will come back anyway.
enAlt: They will come again one way or the other.

ko: 어차피 제가 할 수 있는 일이 아니에요.
en: Even if I try, it’s not something that I can do.
enAlt: This is not something I can do anyway (so there's no use asking me to do it).
notes: 제가 할 수 있는 일 - something I can do. Note that you cannot say '저는' in this case, you have to use the subject marking particle after the subject in noun phrases.

en: You'll be late anyway so take your time.
enAlt: You're already late so take your time.

ko: 어차피 저도 지금 거기 가는 중이에요.
en: I am on my way there anyway.
Would you please take our picture?
notes: This is even more polite than '찍어 주세요'.

en: Please show her to a seat.
notes: 안내하다 - to guide

en: Okay, I'll clear it off right away.
notes: 치우다 - to tidy up

en: Would you mind turning on the air conditioner?
Sure, I'll turn it on.
I think Dane has already left work because it's 7:00.
notes: The '-ㄹ 거예요' ending can also be attached to the past stem if it's used to express a supposition.

ko: 한국어 공부할 때 뭐가 제일 어려워요?
en: What's the most difficult part of studying Korean?
There's only one apple left.
notes: 남다 - to remain

en: There's nothing but milk in the refrigerator.
I only received one present.
What do you think about this book?
notes: The phrase "어떤 것 같아요?" is often used in the spoken language to say "What do you think (about something)?"

en: What do you think about asking (someone)?

ko: 오늘 날씨가 춥지요?- 네, 정말 춥네요.
en:
Isn't it cold today?
- Yes, it really is cold.
notes: The '-네요' ending can also be used when you are agreeing with someone.

ko: 할 수는 있는데 안 하고 싶어요.
en: I could do it but I don't want to.
enAlt: I can do it but I don't want to.
notes: Adding '-는' after '수' changes the meaning slightly.

en: I can do it but on one condition.
enAlt: I can do it but there's a condition.
notes: 조건 - condition

en: Excuse me. Could you please help me?

ko: 아직 친구에게 선물 안 해 줬어요.
en: I haven't given a present to my friend yet.
It's because I couldn't sleep last night.
notes: '-아/어서 그래요' is used when you want to explain the reason for something. It's often an answer to a question (for example "Why do you look so tired?").

en: Because he was brought up in England.
notes: 자라다 - to grow up

ko: 댄 씨에게 음악 CD를 주면 좋아할까요?
en: Do you think Dane would like it if I gave him a music CD?

ko: 매일 음악을 들으면서 다니니까 좋아할 거예요.
en: He listens to music every day, so I think he'd like it.
She has a ring on her left hand, so I think she's married.
notes: 끼다 - to wear

ko: 유치원생은 버스 요금을 내지 않아도 돼요.
en: Preschool students don't have to pay the bus fare.
notes: 요금 - fee

ko: 평일이니까 영화 표를 미리 사지 않아도 돼요.
en: Because it's a weekday, we don't have to buy tickets in advance.
notes: 평일 - weekday

en: On Fridays, we don't have to wear suits.
notes: 정장 - suit

en: It was difficult so I could only read five pages.
Would you like a donut?
Would you like to reserve a room?
Would you like sugar in your coffee?
I plan to travel during the summer vacation.
What were you doing?
If you're busy, you don't have to go.
You don't have to diet.
How did you find out about this place?
notes: 여길 = 여기+를

en: Where should I press?
notes: 누르다 - to press

en: What time will you come tomorrow?
Would you mind calling me in 30 minutes?
In that case, why don't you go to Insadong?
My parents are waiting for me so I'm going home.
Because I am tired.
notes: If you only want to state a reason, you can end the sentence with '때문이다'.

ko: 밥을 안 먹었기 때문에 힘이 없습니다.
en: I didn't eat so I don't have the energy.
We got married because we loved each other.
notes: 서로 - each other

en: Yes, it's going to be cold so dress warmly.

ko: 건강 때문에 올해부터 담배를 끊기로 했어요.
en: I made the decision to stop smoking for my health starting this year.
notes: '-기로 하다' means "decided to do"

en: I decided to go hiking with my friend over the weekend.
We've decided to get married three years from now.
We decided to meet tomorrow morning.
I decided to go to Korea next year.

ko: 백화점이 몇 시에 여는지 알고 싶어요.
en: I'd like to know what time the department store opens.
What are you making?
What will you eat?
I will wait in the office.
Will you come tomorrow morning?

ko: 이번 주말에 캐럴 씨와 데이트하기로 했어요.
en: Carol and I have decided to go on a date this weekend.

ko: 내일 등산 갈 때 누가 카메라를 가져와요?
en: Who will bring the camera tomorrow when we go hiking?
Budi decided to bring one.
The coffee's hot so be careful.
notes: 뜨겁다 - to be hot

ko: 캐럴 씨, 날씨가 좋은데 밖에 나가서 좀 걸을까요?
en: Carol, the weather's nice so why don't we go for a walk outside?
I don't know how to speak English.
Do you know how to do this?

ko: 아직 할 줄 몰라요. 그런데 할 수 있어요.
en: I don’t know how to do it yet but I can do it (if I learn how).
Do you know how to ride a bike?
enAlt: Can you ride a bike?

en: The movie that I'll be watching today is a Chinese movie.
There's no bread for breakfast tomorrow.
I will go to the theatre this evening.

ko: 그러면 케이크나 초콜릿 같은 단 음식을 먹지 마세요.
en: In that case, stop eating sweets like cake and chocolate.
notes: 달다 - to be sweet

ko: 학교 근처로 이사 오는 게 어때요?
en: Why don't you move someplace closer to school?
If you want to play basketball well, you have to be able to jump high.
notes: '-려면' is the shortened form of '-려고 하면'.

en: If you're trying to get to Dongdaemun, you should take subway line 4.

ko: 이 선생님을 만나려면 월요일에 학교로 가세요.
en: If you want to meet with Ms. Lee then come to school on Monday.
I am busy now so call me later.
Thank you for coming.
It’s hot, so shall we turn on the airconditioner?
There is some bulgogi in the refrigerator so eat it.
enAlt: There is some bulgogi in the refrigerator so you can eat that.
notes: The first translation is the literal translation, but the second translation is closer in meaning. Koreans often use the imperative when the English would say "You can..."

en: Please speak louder.
It looks like it rained yesterday.
Where would you like to go?
notes: '어디로' is often used with the verb 'to go'. '-로' means 'direction' in this case.

en: I won’t tell you.
enAlt: I will not speak to you.

en: That must hurt.
enAlt: It looks like it hurts.
notes: -겠- indicates assumption so you must say this about someone else, not about yourself. (In the first person it indicates intention or sometimes possibility.)

en: I think this will be good.
(I think) You’ll be late.
Do you think you could handle it on your own?
Even I would (be able to) fit in.
I’m so tired (I could die).
enAlt: This is so tough.

ko: 조금 읽어봤는데 이 책은 별로 재미없는 것 같습니다.
en: I read this book a little bit, and it doesn't seem very interesting.

ko: 오늘 선미가 못 올 것 같습니다.
en: I think Seon-mi won't be able to come today.

ko: 영화가 재미있을 것 같아서 봤는데 재미없었어요.
en: I thought the movie would be fun so I watched it but it wasn't fun.
Please speak louder when you answer.

ko: 이따가 집에 가실 때 저한테 들르세요.
en: When you go home later, please stop by me (my place).
notes: 들르다 - to drop by

ko: 어제 집에 갔을 때 아무도 없었어요.
en: When I came home last night, no-one was there.
notes: Note the difference: 갈 때 - when I was, am going, 갔을 때 - when I have finished going.

ko: 버스를 타고 가는 동안 음악을 들었습니다.
en: I was listening to music while riding on the bus.

ko: 제가 집에 없는 동안 찾아온 사람 있었어요?
en: Did anyone come to see me during the time I was not home?

ko: 아기가 자는 동안 가게 좀 다녀오겠습니다.
en: I'll go to the store while the baby is sleeping.
You can read this magazine while you are waiting.

ko: 한국에 계실 동안 친구를 많이 사귀세요.
en: Make a lot of friends while you are in Korea.

ko: 비자를 받은 뒤에 외국에 갈 수 있습니다.
en: You can go abroad after you get a visa.
If you want to speak Korean well then only speak Korean every day.
If you don't want to lose your pen then write your name on it.

ko: 우리 회사에서 일하려면 한국말도 잘하고 컴퓨터도 잘해야 합니다.
en: If you intend to work at our company, you have to be able to speak Korean and use computers well.
The balloon became bigger.
notes: 풍선 - balloon

en: My elder sister became thinner.
I’m not sure if it all ended.

ko: 서점이 내일 문을 열지 잘 모르겠어요.
en: I’m not sure if the bookstore will open tomorrow.
I’m not sure where we will go.

ko: 내일 만날지 안 만날지 잘 모르겠어요.
en: I’m not sure if we will meet tomorrow or not.
I’m not sure if this is the right place.
I’m not sure what this means.
notes: 뜻 - meaning

en: I hope many people come tomorrow.
I hope it stops raining.
notes: 그치다 - to stop

en: I hope you like my present.
notes: It's possible to also use this expression without the past suffix (하면 / 했으면) but the meaning is less strong so it's not used very often.

en: I wish I were 20 years old.
It seems like the week is just flying by.
That was because my eyes hurt a bit.
Look! The autumn sky is really blue.

ko: 하늘은 파랗고 구름은 하얘서 그림 같아요.
en: The sky is blue and the clouds are white, just like a painting.
Your face has tanned really brown (black).

ko: 휴가 때 바다에 갔다 와서 그래요.
en: That's because I went to the beach during vacation.

ko: 파란 티셔츠 입은 남자가 누군지 아세요?
en: Do you know who that boy wearing the blue T-shirt is?
It used to be far away, but since I've moved it has become closer.
After it rained, the weather turned cold.
If you eat a lot of carrots, your vision will get better.
Please let me know when the guests come.
I will show you a different T-shirt.

ko: 그 사람은 지금도 서울에서 살 거예요.
en: He probably lives in Seoul even now.
Do you mind if I leave first?
notes: '-도 괜찮다' has the same meaning as '-도 되다', but it is less direct and more careful.

ko: 몸이 좋지 않거나 기분이 우울할 때는 잠을 잡니다.
en: When I don't feel well or feel depressed, I go to bed.

ko: 김 교수님을 만나시려면 지금 가셔야 돼요.
en: If you plan to meet professor Kim, you need to go now.
If you want to get completely healthy, you need to have surgery.
notes: 완전히 - completely, 수술 - surgery

ko: 이 회사에 취직하려면 어떻게 해야 합니까?
en: How can I get a job at this company?
enAlt: What do I have to do in order to get a job at this company?

en: It will probably rain.
Is he tall?
Who is she?

ko: 한 달 안에 방을 비워 주세요.
en: Please empty the room within one month.
notes: "안에" can refer not only to physical location, but also to time.

ko: 두 시간 내에 기차가 떠날 거예요.
en: The train will leave within two hours.
notes: "내에" can be used instead of "안에".

en: Shall I open the window for you?
Shall I carry the luggage for you?
notes: 들다 - to carry

ko: 아마 선생님이 말을 천천히 해서 그럴 거예요.
en: It's probably because the teacher speaks slowly.

ko: 극장에서 영화를 볼 때 앞 사람의 의자를 발로 차면 안 됩니다.
en: You shouldn't kick the chair in front of you when you watch a movie at a movie theater.
notes: 발 - foot, 차다 - to kick

ko: 처음 한국에 도착했을 때 기분이 어땠어요?
en: How did you feel when you first arrived in Korea?

ko: 또 모르는 게 있으면 언제든지 물어보세요.
en: You can ask me anytime if there's anything else you don't know.
notes: 언제든지 - anytime

en: It was made in Korea.
notes: We don't know who made it so we must use the passive voice in English, but in Korean, the active voice is usually used in such situations because the subject can be dropped if we don't know who it is.

ko: 한국 친구 집에 갈 때는 뭘 가지고 가면 좋아요?
en: What should (could) I bring when I visit a Korean friend at home?

ko: 내일 저녁에 친구들이 모여서 로라 씨 승진을 축하해 주려고요.
en: We are planning a gathering among friends tomorrow evening to congratulate Laura on her promotion.
notes: '-려고요' is a contraction from '-려고 해요'. 모이다 - to come together, 승진 - promotion

en: What will you order?
Would you like to sit in the non-smoking section or in the smoking section?
Therefore this year I'm going on vacation in the autumn.
You may not bring food inside.

ko: 살을 빼려면 꾸준히 운동하고 음식 양을 줄이세요.
en: If you want to lose weight, you should exercise regularly and eat less.
notes: 꾸준히 - consistently, 양 - amount, 줄이다 - to reduce

ko: 여기 온 사람 중에서 누가 마음에 들어요?
en: Who do you like among the people here?

ko: 저는 주말에 아무 때나 괜찮으니까 전화 주세요.
en: Call me, I'm free any time this weekend.
someone who is planning to buy it
There are many students who are planning to study abroad.
notes: 외국 - foreign countries

ko: 저 내일 못 올 수도 있어요.
en: I might not be able to come here tomorrow.
There is no news (from them).
notes: '런' is optional in this construction

en: It is tasteless.

ko: 안 먹고 싶어요. 그런데 먹게 돼요.
en: I don’t want to eat it, but I keep eating it anyway.
enAlt: I don't want to eat it, but somehow I'm eating it anyway.
notes: The '-게 되다' construction means that you do something or end up doing something because of an outside reason, not because of your wishes.

en: (I wasn’t planning to but) I got to see a movie last week.
You will (eventually) end up doing it that way.
You will find out tomorrow.
enAlt: You will get to know it tomorrow.

en: I ended up buying everything.
(Things have happened so that) now I can go back to (going to) school.
How did you get to come here?
enAlt: How did you end up coming here?

en: If you get to meet him, tell me.

ko: 잠시 후에는 안준호 교수님께서 한국 경제에 대해 강의를 하시겠습니다.
en: Professor An Junho will give a lecture on the Korean economy shortly.
notes: '-에 대해' or '-에 대해서' is used to describe the topic or theme of something.

ko: 열 명 초대했는데 아무도 안 올 수도 있어요.
en: I’ve invited 10 people, but it’s possible that no one will come.
I almost bought it.
notes: "-(으)ㄹ 뻔 했다" means that you almost did something (but didn't do it in the end).

en: I almost believed it.
It was scary so I almost cried.
enAlt: I almost cried because I was scared.

en: It was heavy and I almost dropped it.
I almost lost money.
I almost went there, but I didn’t go.
I practice yoga every morning.
notes: This sentence introduces the statement sentence ending (as opposed to the "let's" ending -자) of the 'plain' or 'narrative' speech style. If an action verb stem ends in a vowel, you add -ㄴ다 like this: 하다 -> 한다.

en: Starting from next month, the bus ticket price will go up.
notes: The plain style is used in various kinds of narrations - diaries, documentaries, newspapers, and so on. Also in dictionaries.

en: A new semester starts in the spring.
My father is listening to the radio.
notes: This sentence is both honorific and plain at the same time.

en: Minsu is reading a newspaper.
notes: To turn an action verb whose stem ends in a consonant into the plain form, you add -는다: 읽다 -> 읽는다.

en: Minhee is listening to the news.
The roses are too expensive.
notes: For descriptive verbs it's easy - the plain form is the same as the dictionary form.

en: Our country is in a difficult economic situation right now.
The weather is very nice.
notes: Friendly advice: study the plain form until you know it very well. You will need it for the reported speech, which is a very big part of Korean grammar.

en: Yuki is at home now.
notes: The verbs 있다, 맛있다, 재미있다 act like descriptive verbs in this context.

en: President Kim returned to Korea yesterday.
notes: After the past and future suffixes 았, 었, 겠, only -다 is added.

en: The job was very difficult for women.
I'll go to China next year.
notes: In the plain style, '나' is used instead of '저'.

en: My brother is a lawyer.
notes: Add '-다' or '-이다' after nouns.

en: It will rain tomorrow.
Money is not a problem for me.
This is good!
notes: The plain style can also be used in the spoken Korean when you want to show your surprise or discovery of a fact. Please note that this is not 존댓말 (polite speech).

en: Over there, there is a train passing by.
The phone is ringing.
He sings like a professional singer.
notes: '처럼' means 'like something' and is attached to nouns. One of its most popular usages in songs is '바보처럼' - like a fool.

en: Hayeong is as kind as an angel.
notes: You can also use '같이' instead of '처럼'.

en: He's as handsome as a movie actor.
Try doing it like I do.
The puppy looks like a bear.

ko: 제 친구는 미국인인데 영어를 영국 사람처럼 해요.
en: My friend is American but she speaks English like a British person.
notes: 미국인 - an American

en: I’m leaving now (before you).
notes: You can also use this style in the spoken Korean when you want to describe an action, a situation or a regular activity.

ko: 그러면, 다음에는 너 초대 안 한다.
en: If you do that, next time I won’t invite you (and make that a rule).
Kyeong-eun gets up at 8 AM as usual.

ko: 일어나서 제일 먼저 하는 일은 핸드폰을 보는 것이다.
en: The first thing she does after she gets up is checking her cellphone.
In this school, 500 students learn Korean.

ko: 전화가 안 돼요. 어? 다시 된다!
en: The phone is not working. Huh? It’s working again!
There come my friends.
Then I will wait here, okay?

ko: 한국어를 잘 하고 싶으면, 매일 공부해야 한다.
en: If you want to speak good Korean, you need to study every day.

ko: 8월은 휴가철이니까 비행기 표를 미리 사지 않으면 안 돼요.
en: August is vacation season, so you must buy plane tickets in advance.
notes: The double negative construction '-지 않으면 안 돼요' can be used to emphasize that something must be done.

ko: 병이 심각해서 수술하지 않으면 안 돼요.
en: We have to perform surgery because the illness is serious.

ko: 다음 주에 중요한 시험이 있어서 공부하지 않으면 안 돼요.
en: I must study because I have an important test next week.
It seems he doesn't know.
enAlt: I guess they don't know.
notes: "-나 보다" is used to express an assumption. In the present tense it can only be used with action verbs and 있다/없다.

en: It seems he didn't know.
enAlt: It looks like he didn't know.
notes: This construction can also be used in the past tense.

en: This seems like a fun movie.
enAlt: I guess this movie is interesting.
notes: You can say this, for example, when you watch a promo or a poster.

en: I guess Hyojin still doesn’t know.
It seems that it's raining again.
It looks like you had fun yesterday.
It seems there's no one here.
Looks like it's broken.
enAlt: It seems it broke.

ko: 나는 아무리 바빠도 아침을 꼭 먹어요.
en: No matter how busy I am, I always eat breakfast.
notes: 아무리 + 아/어도 = no matter how

ko: 그 옷이 아무리 비싸도 꼭 살 거예요.
en: No matter how expensive those clothes are, I will buy them.
She said that this is coffee.
enAlt: They said this was coffee.
notes: This is a reported speech construction for nouns. It is used in sentences like "Someone said that something is something." The verb "했어요" in this case means the same thing as "말했어요".

en: They said this book was free of charge.
He said that it was this.
She said she was a Korean person.
enAlt: She said he was Korean.
notes: If the noun ends in a consonant, you add 이 before '라고'.

en: What did you say?
enAlt: What did you tell them?
notes: When you ask a question regarding someone saying something, you also need to add '라고'.

en: What did the teacher say?
I heard that I was the first place winner.
notes: 일등 - first place. The reported speech constructions can also be used with verbs like 듣다, 말하다, 대답하다, 물어보다 etc.

en: They say that this is the TalkToMeInKorean office.
My name is Kyeongeun Choi.
notes: This is a standard expression how to introduce yourself. Technically it means something like "People call me name." It's often used in the formal 합니다 style.

en: Junho said that he's a newspaper reporter.
notes: "준호는" denotes the person who is talking, and '자기가' (oneself) is the person being talked about (meaning that Junho is talking about himself).

ko: 그 사람 부인은 한국 사람이라고 합니다.
en: They say that his wife is Korean.
I said I'm not a student.
notes: This construction is also used to say that something is not something (아니라고).

en: They say that it will be very hot tomorrow.
notes: Since the future tense of verbs is formed using '거' and '거' is a noun, future statements of any verbs are quoted using the noun quotation marker '-라고'.

en: It's been two years since I came to Korea.
notes: '-ㄴ 지' expresses how much time has passed since something occurred. It can be followed by verbs 되다 or 넘다.

ko: 담배 끊은 지 한 달 되었어요.
en: It's been one month since I stopped smoking.
You've been playing computer games for over five hours.
notes: The action can also continue to the present.

en: He's a teacher, not a student.
enAlt: He's not a student, he's a teacher.
notes: When '아니라' follows a noun (usually with the subject marking particle), the noun is negated.

ko: 아니요. 산 게 아니라 친구한테서 빌린 거예요.
en: No, I didn't buy it, I borrowed it from a friend.
notes: "아니라" can also negate noun phrases that end in 게 (것이).

en: I'm not selling them, just exhibiting.

ko: 고속 버스를 타는 것이 아니라 기차를 탈 거예요.
en: We are not taking an express bus, we will take the train.

ko: 여기는 날씨만 좋은 게 아니라 사람들도 친절해요.
en: Not only is the weather nice here, but the people are also nice.
notes: If you add '-만' and '-도', the whole meaning of the '아니라' construction changes.

en: It looks like he's been sick.
enAlt: He must have been sick.
notes: '-나 보다' is used with descriptive verbs in the past tense, but not in the present tense. (TTMIK says sometimes it's also used in the present but that's not standard grammar.)

en: There seem to be many students.
notes: '-은가 보다' is used with descriptive verbs in the present tense the same way '-나 보다' is used with action verbs.

en: I guess there were a lot of students.
He seems to be busy these days.
I guess the kids are sleepy.
enAlt: The kids must be sleepy.

en: I guess so.
It seems this way is faster.

ko: 성민 씨가 미국 사람이 아니라고 했어요.
en: Sung Min said that he was not American.
I've seen an Indian movie.
notes: '-ㄴ 적이 있다/없다' expresses whether you have or have not done (experienced) something.

en: I've never been late to work.
Have you ever been to Italy?
notes: '-아/어 보다' is often combined with '-ㄴ 적이 있다'.

en: I have learned it before.
Have you tried learning Chinese before?
I haven’t been here before.

ko: 나는 아프리카에 가 본 일이 없다.
en: I have never been to Africa.
notes: This has the same meaning as '본 적이 없다' but it is used less often.

en: It's been six months since I began studying Korean.
We've been dating for over three years.

ko: 어차피 해야 되는 거니까 재미있게 해요.
en: You have to do it anyway so (you might as well) have fun while doing it.
notes: 해야 되는 거 - something you have to do

en: Give me coffee, not milk.
notes: '말고' = '말다' + '-고'. You have to put whatever you don't want before '말고' and what you want after it.

en: I will buy that one over there, not this one.
Don’t worry, just give it a try.
notes: '-지 마세요' turns into '-지 말고' if you want to continue the sentence.

en: Come early, don't be late.

ko: 전화하지 말고 문자 메시지 보내 주세요.
en: Send me a text message instead of calling me.

ko: 저 기다리지 말고 먼저 가도 돼요.
en: You can go first without waiting for me.

ko: 차가운 물에 넣지 말고 뜨거운 물에 넣으세요.
en: Put it in hot water, not cold water.
enAlt: Don’t put it in cold water, put it in hot water.

ko: 내일은 여기 말고 다른 곳에서 만날 거예요.
en: We are meeting at a different place tomorrow, not here.
Don't buy it now, wait just a little bit.
I told you yesterday! (Don’t you remember?)
enAlt: Come on. I told you yesterday (already).
notes: The '-잖아요' ending is used when you say something that (in your opinion) the other person should know already.

en: Because it’s cute!
enAlt: You see? It’s cute!

en: Don’t you see that we also have time tomorrow?
enAlt: We have time tomorrow, too, anyway.

en: Come on. It’s Sunday today.
enAlt: It’s because it’s Sunday today!

en: Come on. You know.
enAlt: You know exactly (what I am talking about).

ko: 난 지금까지 한 번도 연예인을 만난 적이 없어요.
en: I've never (not even once) met a celebrity.
What do you think about this book?

ko: 어릴 때 유학 가는 거 어떤 것 같아요?
en: What do you think about studying abroad at a young age?
notes: 유학 - studying abroad, 어리다 - to be young

en: What do you think about my idea?
I became good at cooking.
I came to like football.
(It's been decided that) I will go abroad on a business trip.
notes: The point of '-게 되다' is that the will of the subject doesn't matter.

en: I did go there but I came back early.
notes: This '-기는' construction is used when you want to emphasize the first action (going in this case) and contrast it to something else.

en: I did see it but I don't remember.

ko: 어제 친구를 만나기는 했는데 금방 헤어졌어요.
en: I did meet a friend yesterday but we parted soon.
notes: You can also use '하다' instead of the repeated verb.

ko: 시간 맞춰서 도착하기는 했는데 준비를 못 했어요.
en: I did manage to get there on time, but I couldn’t prepare.
notes: 시간 맞춰서 - on time

en: I did read it but I don't understand it.
It is good but it's too expensive.
It really is delicious, but it's a bit salty.

ko: 미국 회사에 이메일을 보내야 해요. 이것 좀 영어로 번역해 주시겠어요?
en: I have to send an e-mail to a company in the U.S. Would you please translate this into English?
to say that someone is going
notes: This is the reported speech construction for verbs and adjectives. You take the plain form and add '-고' to it.

en: Did you tell them you would look at it?
enAlt: Did she tell you he would look at it?
notes: The translation of a sentence like this depends heavily on the context.

en: to hear that someone is eating something
I said that your phone is ringing.
He says that he will come tomorrow.
When did he say he would come?
What did he say this was?
I heard that it’s very cold in winter in Korea.
What should I write here?
Write that TTMIK is good.
Please tell them that I am going as well.
I heard that this is fun.

ko: 민희가 자기는 오늘 못 온다고 말했어요.
en: Minhee said she can't come today.

ko: 철수는 다음 주에 한국으로 간다고 해요.
en: Cheolsu says he's going to Korea next week.
enAlt: They say Cheolsu is going to Korea next week.

ko: 그분은 자기 아들이 내일 첫 월급을 받는다고 그랬어요.
en: He said his son is getting his first paycheck tomorrow.
notes: 월급 - monthly salary

en: The children are saying that they are hungry.
He says that everyone has arrived safely.
Misha says he's not going to eat.
My name is difficult to pronounce.
enAlt: As for my name, pronouncing it is difficult.
notes: 발음하다 - to pronounce

en: This is difficult to make.
This is difficult for a child to use.
enAlt: Using this is difficult for a child.
notes: 어린이 - child

ko: 회사에 다닌 후부터 일찍 일어나게 되었어요.
en: After getting a regular job, I became an early riser.

ko: 한국에 오기 전에는 몰랐는데 한국에 와서 알게 되었어요.
en: I hadn't heard of him before coming to Korea, but after coming here, I learned of him.
I am on my way.
enAlt: I am in the middle of going.
notes: This construction is -고 있다 + -는 중이다.

en: What were you doing?
enAlt: What were you in the middle of doing?

en: I was in the middle of looking for the key.
She's as pretty as Miss Korea.
He's as funny as a comedian.
The teacher is standing.
notes: '-아/어 있다' expresses the continuation of a state (as opposed to '-고 있다' which expresses the continuation of an action). It is often used with passive verbs and cannot be used with transitive verbs.

en: The students are sitting.
The patients are lying down in the hospital.
notes: 눕다 - to lie

en: His name is written on the umbrella.
I arrived home to (discover) the smell of something tasty.
notes: '-니까' has a second usage. In this case, you discover the second part as a result of doing the first part.

en: When I woke up in the morning, the gift had already arrived.
When I arrived home, I realized it was midnight.
I waited for my friend for no less than two hours.
notes: '-이나' indicates that the amount was much higher than expected or normal. It's usually added after counters.

en: We have (as many as) eight children.

ko: 사과가 맛있어요. 그래서 열 개나 먹었어요.
en: The apples are tasty so I ate ten of them.
no matter how rich you are
notes: Remember how '-라서' can be used instead of '-여서' with nouns? The same also applies for '-여도' and '-라도'.

en: no matter how much of a beauty she is
notes: 미인 - beauty

en: Even if he's a student, still...
enAlt: I know he's a student but still...
notes: What follows after "still..." is clear from the context so you can use '그렇죠' if you don't want to explain everything.

en: Be there by 2 at the latest.
No matter how delicious it is, stop eating now.
No matter how expensive it is, I’ll buy it for you.

ko: 아무리 학생이라도 공부만 하는 건 아니에요.
en: Even students don’t always study.

ko: 어떻게 해요? 지갑 안에 뭐가 들어 있었어요?
en: What will you do? What was inside the wallet?
There was an advertisement put up in front of school.
It's closed.
We started dating last year.
I ended up working at a Korean company.
enAlt: Things happened so that I came to work for a Korean company.

en: I ended up falling in love with her.
Since when are you so good at Korean?
enAlt: When did you become good at Korean?

en: Yes, I called but he did not answer.

ko: 어제 백화점에 가니까 세일을 하고 있었어요.
en: I went to the department store yesterday and saw they were having a sale.
I drank no less than 10 bottles.
He's got five (cars).
Your vision is bad indeed.
notes: '-군요' is an ending that is used to express surprise. '-네요' is also used for a similar purpose and it is slightly more common, but '-네요' cannot be used when you are surprised at what someone tells you. '-군요' can be used in such a situation.

en: You really like ice cream!
notes: '-군요' is attached to descriptive verbs, and '-는군요' is attached to action verbs.

en: I see you've caught a cold.
On my way home, I met a friend.
enAlt: While coming home, I bumped into a friend.
notes: '-다가' is attached directly to the stem of the verb. This construction is used if the first action was interrupted by the second action. (Sometimes the first action continues after the second action has happened.) Both sentence parts must have the same subject.

en: I was watching television and I fell asleep.
enAlt: I fell asleep while watching TV.
notes: 잠이 들다 - to fall asleep

en: I was traveling and I caught a cold.
enAlt: I caught a cold while traveling.

en: I was living in Seoul and then I moved to Jeju Island.
What were you doing before coming here?
I was studying at home and came outside.
enAlt: I was studying at home before I came outside.
notes: '-다가' shows that the first action happened right before the second action. Sometimes '다가' is shortened to '다'.

en: I was eating when I received the phone call.
I was outside and came inside.
Where were you before you came here now?
enAlt: Where have you been?

en: I’m taking a short break from work.
I went home but nobody was there.
enAlt: I went home and discovered that no-one was there.

en: I looked closely and realized it's someone I know.
notes: 자세히 - in detail

en: I've already met him before.

ko: 그래요? 부디 씨는 정말 돈이 많군요.
en: Really? Budi really does have a lot of money!

ko: 정말 비가 오는군요. 우산이 없는데 어떻게 하죠?
en: Wow, it's really raining. I don't have an umbrella so what shall I do?
Did you do it like I said yesterday?
Today is a Monday that feels like a Sunday.
Why did you make your house like a fortress?
Did you really believe that like a fool?

ko: 우리는 다섯 시 반에 시작하는 4회 표를 가지고 있었기 때문에 바로 들어갈 수 있었습니다.
en: We had tickets to the 4th show at 5:30 so we could go right in.
notes: 표 - ticket, 바로 - directly

ko: 제가 그 집에 갔을 때 문이 열려 있었어요.
en: When I went to the house, the door was open.
notes: 열리다 - to be open

ko: 이 골목은 막혀 있는 것 같아요.
en: This alley seems to be blocked.
notes: 골목 - alley

en: The roses in the park are in bloom.
The calendar is hung on the wall.

ko: 그 사람 지금 한국에 가 있습니다.
en: He (has gone to and) is in Korea right now.
I watch a movie once a week.
notes: '-씩' is a particle that means "each, apiece". It is usually attached to counters.

ko: 이 약은 한 번에 두 알씩 드세요.
en: Take two pills at a time.
notes: 약 - medicine, 알 - pill

ko: 한 사람 앞에 세 장씩 나눠 드려.
en: Give out three sheets for each person.
notes: 나누다 - to distribute

en: Phone numbers are read digit by digit.

ko: 살을 빼려고 매일 세 시간씩 운동을 해요.
en: I exercise three hours a day to try to lose weight.
notes: '-려고' means 'in order to' or 'so that'.

en: I bought a present to give to my wife.
I drank five cups of coffee so that I wouldn't go to sleep.
Listen (well) to your parents.
notes: '-아/어라' is the imperative ending of the plain speech style. It is used to speak to close friends or younger people.

en: Go (quickly) to school.
Study hard.
Don't make noise.
notes: '마라' is the irregular form of '말다'.

en: You can really sing well.
I see.
enAlt: So it's like that.

en: It's not interesting.
So he was a famous singer.
Then she will probably come as well.
I see this is a very good computer.
He's a student or a teacher.
notes: There are different types of "or" in English. When you say "I will do this or that", you mean that either action is possible and you will choose one. For this kind of "or", Koreans use '-이나' and '거나'. But in this example, you cannot choose whether this person is a student or a teacher, you simply don't know. In this case Koreans use '아니면'. It means "if not..."

ko: 집에 갈 거예요? 아니면 친구를 만날 거예요?
en: Are you going to go home? Or are you going to meet a friend?
notes: '아니면' can also connect two sentences when they are questions.

ko: 이거 살 거예요? 아니면 다른 거 살 거예요?
en: Are you going to buy this or something else?
They said that it would rain today.

ko: 그 사람은 내일 다시 올 거라고 했어요.
en: He said he would come again tomorrow.
I heard that they are going to have a birthday party.
I heard that you moved.
Did you say that you saw that movie yesterday?

ko: 어제 친구들한테 영화 볼 거라고 했어요?
en: Did you tell your friends yesterday that you would watch a movie?

ko: 내일 다시 올 거라고 말해 주세요.
en: Please tell them that I will come again tomorrow.
Come on, you said that it would end next week.
I bought a present for my girlfriend.
I sat at a desk in order to read a newspaper.
On days off I also help my wife.

ko: 저도 전에는 술을 마시기도 하고 담배를 피우기도 했어요.
en: Before I drank and smoked, too.

ko: 철수가 지금 집에 없을 것 같아요.
en: Cheolsu is probably not at home right now.
notes: The future form '없을' indicates an assumption in this case, not the future.

ko: 어제 거기에 사람이 많이 왔을 것 같아요.
en: Seems like many people came there yesterday.

ko: 내가 그 여자와 결혼할 수 있으면 얼마나 좋을까!
en: It would be so good if I could marry her.
notes: '얼마나' is not a question in this case, it's an exclamation.

en: The weather was cold, but then it suddenly became warm.

ko: 방 청소를 하다가 바닥에서 돈을 주웠어요.
en: I was cleaning the room and picked up money from the floor.
notes: 줍다 - to pick up

ko: 이 사람 밥 먹다가 어디 갔어요?
en: Where did he go without finishing his meal?
It was raining and it only stopped a while ago.
Why did he come here?
notes: This is a different usage of the '-지요' ending. It's used to make the sentence more gentle and intimate. It can be used in questions, commands and suggestions.

en: Come in here.
Let's go together.

ko: 일요일에도 우리는 축구나 야구를 하려고 학교에 갔습니다.
en: We went to school even on Sundays so that we could play football or baseball.

ko: 아이들하고 축구를 하고 있을 때 우리는 행복했습니다.
en: We were happy when we were playing football with other kids.

ko: 방학 때 저는 친구들하고 아침부터 저녁까지 농구를 하기도 했습니다.
en: During the school holidays, there were even times when my friends and I played basketball all day long.
I called so that I could hear your voice.
Even though I've lain down in bed, I can't fall asleep.
Would you mind if I sit here?
enAlt: I wonder if I can sit here?

en: Would you mind if I closed the window?
Do you mind waiting for a bit?
Do you mind explaining one more time?
Please tell her to be quiet.
enAlt: Please tell them to be quiet
notes: '-(으)라고 하다' is the construction for reported orders.

en: Who told you to go?
Where did they ask you to come?
I told them to give that to Hyojin.

ko: 저는 유학 온 게 아니라 일하러 왔어요.
en: I came here to work, not to study.

ko: 저는 한국 문화에 대해서 관심이 많아요.
en: I'm very interested in the Korean culture.
notes: 문화 - culture, 관심 - interest

ko: 이치로 씨는 한국의 명절에 대해서 알아요?
en: Chiro, do you know about Korean national holidays?
notes: 명절 - national holiday

en: I'm studying so that I can get into a university next year.
I am from France, not from the U.S.
notes: Note that even though the correct country is marked with the location particle, the negated one has the subject marking particle.

ko: 노래 동아리에 대해서 알고 싶어서 왔어요.
en: I came because I wanted to find out more about the singing club.

ko: 직업은 회사원이고 한국에 온 지 1년이 되었습니다.
en: I work for a company and I came to Korea one year ago.

ko: 지금부터 우리 반 친구들에 대해서 소개하려고 합니다.
en: I'm going to tell you about my classmates now.

ko: 한국말을 배워 가지고 한국 회사에 취직을 할 거예요?
en: Will you get a job at a Korean company once you learn Korean?
notes: '-아/어 가지고' indicates doing (by the same subject) the second action after the first one is completed. It is similar to and can often be replaced with the '-아/어서' form. It is used often in the spoken Korean and sometimes is shortened to '아/어 갖고'.

en: I bought a hamburger and ate it in the car.
I was tired so I went to bed early.
notes: '-아/어 가지고' also has a second usage - it can indicate the reason why the speaker did something.

ko: 배불러 가지고 도저히 더 못 먹겠어요.
en: My stomach is so full that I couldn't possibly eat any more.
notes: 도저히 - no way

en: I was so sleepy during class that I had a really hard time.
Would this be okay?
enAlt: If I do it like this, will it be fine?

ko: 승리 공원에 가려면 이 버스를 타면 됩니다.
en: You need to only take this bus if you want to go to the Victory Park.
enAlt: All you need to do in order to get to the Victory Park is take this bus.

ko: 어떻게 하면 한국말을 그렇게 잘할 수 있습니까?
en: What should I do in order to speak Korean so well?
enAlt: How can I learn to speak Korean so well?

en: All you need to do is get a Korean girlfriend.
enAlt: It's enough to get a Korean girlfriend.

en: Should we go there tomorrow or not?
Do you have anything besides that?
Now you may go out.
notes: "-도 좋다" is the same as "-도 되다".

ko: 수업 중에 선생님 말은 잘 알겠지만 다른 사람 말은 잘 못 알아듣겠어요.
en: I can understand what the teacher says during class, but I can't understand what other people say.

ko: 한국에 온 지 얼마 안 돼서 그럴 거예요.
en: It's probably because you haven't been in Korea long.

ko: 이대역에서 압구정동까지 사십 분 정도 걸리지요?
en: It takes 40 minutes to get from Ewha univ. to Apgujeong, right?
notes: 정도 - extent, degree, 이대 = 이화여자대학교

en: I will be teaching the level two class from today.
I am very happy to meet you all.
Every country has a different flag.
notes: 국기 - flag

en: (Your ideas are not bad but) What do you think about a watch as a present?
notes: If a sentence starts with '그것보다', it means that the speaker thinks he has a better idea. In some other cases it indicates that the speaker wants to change the subject to something more important or pressing.

en: My vacation will start in just one month.
notes: "Time period + 있으면 + 이다" - "in time period"

ko: 수진 씨 덕분에 여행 준비가 빨리 끝났어요.
en: Thanks to you, the preparation for my trip didn't take a long time.
notes: 덕분에 - thanks to (you)

en: a drink that costs 600 won
enAlt: a drink worth 600 won
notes: "-짜리" means "worth" and also other adjectives depending on the context. It's usually attached to counters. Expressions such as "1000 won bill", "5 year old child", "90 minute long movie" would all use 짜리.

en: It's a big problem because I only have a 5,000 won bill.
notes: 큰일 - serious matter

en: I'd like a 1.5l bottle of coke.
Something like two nights and three days would be good.

ko: 생일 케이크예요. 오늘 회사 동료의 생일 파티가 있거든요.
en: It's a birthday cake. A colleague of mine has a birthday party today.
notes: The "-거든요" ending is used when you want to give an explanation or a reason for something mentioned before. It can also be used to answer "Why?" questions. The information in the sentence is usually something the listener doesn't know.

ko: 오늘은 수업이 끝난 후에 공항에 가야 해요. 부모님이 한국에 오시거든요.
en: I have to go to the airport after my classes end today. My parents are coming to Korea.
notes: "-거든요" is mostly used in speech, not writing, and generally in informal settings.

ko: 보통 할인 마트나 시장에서 사요. 백화점은 좀 비싸거든요.
en: I usually buy them in a discount store or at a market. Department stores are a bit expensive.
I don’t know either. I just got here.

ko: 제가 지금 돈이 없거든요. 만원만 빌려 주세요.
en: I don’t have any money now. Could you lend me 10,000 won?
notes: This is a different usage of '거든요'. Here it indicates that a new topic has been introduced and will be continued in the following sentence(s).

ko: 지난 주에 제주도에 갔거든요. 그런데 계속 비가 왔어요.
en: I went to Jeju Island last week, but it kept raining.

ko: 아까 효진 씨 만났거든요. 그런데 이상한 말을 했어요.
en: I met Hyojin earlier, and she said something strange.
I don’t need it!
notes: This ending can also be used to emphasize your sentence when you're angry or upset. You'll hear this often in K-dramas.

ko: 약을 이틀 정도 먹으면 나을 겁니다.
en: It will get better if you take the medicine for two days.
Be sure to avoid places with many people.
notes: '-도록 하다' can be used to make gentler, softer suggestions than -세요 or -십시오. The construction '-도록 하겠습니다' can be used in the response.

ko: 기침을 하거나 재채기를 하시는 분들은 외출할 때 반드시 마스크를 쓰도록 하세요.
en: If you are coughing or sneezing, wear a mask when you go out.

ko: 친구가 좋은 가구점을 소개해 준 덕분에 마음에 드는 걸 샀어요.
en: I was able to bought things I like thanks to a furniture store my friend told me about.

ko: 선생님께서 잘 가르쳐 주신 덕분에 한국말을 빨리 배웠어요.
en: I learned Korean so quickly thanks to my very good teacher.

ko: 면바지에 셔츠를 입고 안경을 쓴 사람이 철수 씨예요.
en: The one wearing cotton pants, a shirt, and glasses is Cheolsu.
notes: Note the "바지에"

en: (Because) Every person likes different things.

ko: 이 어린이는 하얀 얼굴에 짧은 머리를 하고 있습니다.
en: This child has a white face and short hair.

ko: 왜냐하면 그 사람의 외모는 내가 원하는 이상형과 달랐기 때문이다.
en: It was because he looked different than my ideal type.
Half of the year has already passed.

ko: 한국에서 안 가 본 곳이 많으니까 저는 아무 데나 다 괜찮아요.
en: There are many places in Korea that I haven't been to so I can go anywhere.
Preparing four portions of food should be enough, right?

ko: 네 명이 넘게 오니까 모자랄 것 같은데요.
en: I think it won't be enough. More than four people are coming.
notes: 모자라다 - to be insufficient

ko: 아무나 할 수 있는 선물이 아니라 우리들만 해 줄 수 있는 선물을 주고 싶어요.
en: I want to give her something unique from us, not something anyone can buy.

ko: 일본으로 해서 호주에 가면 교통비를 줄일 수 있어요.
en: You can reduce your transportation expenses by traveling to Australia via Japan.
notes: '-로 해서' is used to show which route you will take to get to the destination

en: Which route does bus no. 401 take to Itaewon?
You can also go via Gwangju.
The more delicious it is, the better it sells.
notes: '-을수록' means 'the more - the more'.

en: The busier you are, the more important your health is.
The more people there are, the better.
You need to sleep even better especially when you are busy.
enAlt: You need to sleep more when you are busy.
notes: '-을수록' can also be translated to 'especially if...' or 'particularly when...'

en: You need to read a lot of books especially when you are a student.
The more, the better.
notes: You can add '-(으)면' in front of '-을수록' if you want to emphasize it.

ko: 싸면 쌀수록 많이 살 수 있어요.
en: The cheaper it is, the more you can buy it.
It keeps getting colder.
enAlt: It gets colder as time goes by.
notes: '갈수록' is a fixed expression, it means 'more and more so as time goes by'.

en: The more interesting a person is, the more popular he/she is.

ko: 어릴 때 유학을 가는 것에 대해서 어떻게 생각하세요?
en: What do you think about studying abroad at a young age?

ko: 사람들이 저한테 그렇게 예쁜 부인이 있어서 좋겠다고 해요.
en: People say I'm fortunate to have such a pretty wife.
I fell asleep as soon as I came home.
notes: '-자마자' - as soon as

en: I will start working as soon as I graduate.
I will call you as soon as I arrive.
As soon as I saw it, I liked it.
I came outside again right after I went in.
They asked me if I was a student.
notes: You can make reported questions by adding the '냐고' ending after the verb stem.

en: I asked who said so.
Ask him what time he will come here.

ko: 왜 안 왔냐고 물어봤는데, 대답을 안 해요.
en: I asked him why he didn’t come here, but he won’t answer.
He asked me where I was going.

ko: 저는 몇 살이냐고 물어보는 게 제일 싫어요.
en: I hate it the most when people ask me how old I am.
Please ask them if I have to come along, too.
I bought a camera instead of a computer.
notes: 대신에 - instead of

en: Instead of traveling, I took a part-time job.

ko: 저 대신에 해 줄 수 있어요?
en: Can you do it instead of me?

ko: 오늘 일찍 가는 대신에 내일 일찍 와야 돼요.
en: Since you are leaving early today, to make up for it, you have to be here early tomorrow.
notes: '대신에' can also mean 'in return' or 'to make up for it'.

ko: 저 대신에 가고 싶은 사람 있어요?
en: Is there anybody who wants to go instead of me?

ko: 이번에는 제가 도와 줄게요. 대신에 다음에는 저를 도와 줘야 돼요.
en: I will help you this time, but next time you have to help me in return.
Don’t pretend to know.
notes: '-(으/느)ㄴ 척하다' - to pretend to

ko: 모르는 척하지 말고 빨리 말해 줘요.
en: Please don’t pretend you don’t know and tell me quickly.
notes: '척' can be replaced by '체' in most cases, but '척' is used more often.

en: Stop pretending to be asleep and get up.
notes: Sometimes '척' is followed by a different verb than '하다'.

en: Don’t act as if you didn't drink.

ko: 그 사람은 예쁜 척을 너무 많이 해요.
en: She acts (too much) as if she’s pretty.
notes: '예쁜 척' involves making 'cute' faces at the camera, acting 'cute' with their boyfriends and similar stuff.

en: Shall we drink tea or something?
notes: This is the third usage of the '-(이)나' particle. It indicates that the speaker doesn't have any preference (for coffee, tea, juice or other drinks so they might as well drink tea).

en: I'm bored. Let's listen to some music or something.
There's nothing to do, I might as well get some sleep.
This student is worth a recommendation.
notes: '-ㄹ 만하다' - the action is worth doing or there is enough reason for something.

en: This is behavior that deserves a punishment.
enAlt: It's understandable that such behavior would be punished.

en: This person is trustworthy.

ko: 그 식당에는 먹을 만한 음식이 없어요.
en: There's no food worth eating in that restaurant.
The fire truck arrived as soon as the fire started.
The students left the classroom right after class was over.

ko: 운전을 배우는 데 두 달 걸렸어요.
en: It took me two months to learn to drive.
notes: '-는 데 걸리다' expresses how much time it takes to do something.

en: It takes me an hour to finish my homework.
It cost me 300,000 won to repair my car.
notes: '-는 데 들다' indicates how much money something cost.

en: I heard that you lost your wallet. Did you find it?

ko: 그때 내가 죽었으면 제 아내는 다른 사람을 만났을 거예요.
en: If I had died then, my wife would have met someone else.
notes: This is the construction to use when you want to talk about things that could have happened but didn't happen: -었으면 ... -었을 거예요 (if something had happened, someone would have done something).

ko: 키가 조금만 더 컸으면 저는 농구 선수가 되었을 것입니다.
en: If only I had been a little taller, I would have become a professional basketball player.

ko: 여기에서 명동까지 가는 데 얼마나 걸려요?
en: How long does it take to get to Myeongdong from here?
How much did it cost to move?
I told them not to worry.
enAlt: They told me not to worry.

ko: 저는 지난달에 오 년 만에 다시 독일에 갔습니다.
en: Last month I went to Germany again after five years.
notes: "만에" means "after" and it shows how much time has passed between the previous activity (the last time I went to Germany) and the current activity (going to Germany again). It's the same '만에' that's in '오랜만에' ('after a long time'). It's preceded by an expression denoting a time period (five years).

en: How many months were you away from home?
enAlt: After how many months away did you return home?

ko: 어제 십 년 만에 처음으로 피아노를 쳐 봤습니다.
en: Yesterday I tried playing the piano for the first time in 10 years.
I finished cleaning the first floor within 3 hours.

ko: 집에서 극장까지 삼십 분 만에 왔습니다.
en: I got to the theater 30 minutes after leaving home.
I knew it was going to rain.
enAlt: I thought it was going to rain.
notes: "-ㄹ 줄 알다" can be used to say you know how to do something, but it also has two other meanings: "to know that something will happen" and "to think that something will happen". The meaning depends on context and intonation.

en: I knew there would be a lot of people.
Did you think that I would tell you?

ko: 제 친구는 자기가 세상에서 제일 예쁜 줄 알아요.
en: My friend thinks that she is the prettiest in the world.
notes: "-ㄴ 줄 알다" can be used with adjectives and past tense verbs.

en: Did you know that I had gone to school?
notes: If the emphasis is on "알았어요" then it means "to know". If not, then "to think".

ko: 오늘 눈이 안 올 줄 알았어요.
en: I thought it would not snow today.
I didn’t know it would be here.
I didn’t know it was this expensive.
I thought it would not be difficult.
What did you think I would say?
It’s understandable to be so.
enAlt: It’s possible.

en: There is enough reason that he is popular.
enAlt: It’s understandable why he is popular.

en: Is this book worth reading?
enAlt: Do you recommend this book?

en: I’m okay. It’s endurable.
enAlt: I’m okay. It’s bearable.

en: (The place) is worth visiting once (or twice) with family.
notes: "-끼리" is a particle that means "among" or "with" (a group of people or objects)

en: It's much colder compared to Korea.
notes: "-에 비해(서)" - "compared to"

ko: 공부한 것에 비해서 성적이 잘 나왔어요.
en: Compared to how much I studied, the grades (I got) were good.
enAlt: I got good grades, taking into account (considering) how much I studied.

en: He is tall for his age.
enAlt: Considering how old he is, he is pretty tall.

ko: 다른 것에 비해서 듣기가 너무 어려워요.
en: Listening is very difficult compared to other things.
I'm a lot more used to it now compared to how it was initially.
I can’t cut it.
enAlt: Lit.: This isn't getting cut.
notes: In Korean, the passive voice of verbs can be used to show possibility or impossibility (that's why 되다, the passive form of 하다, also has this meaning). If you say '못 잘라요', it implies that you don't have the skill to cut it. '안 잘라져요' implies that you have the skill in general, it's just not possible or not happening in this situation.

en: I can’t hear you.
enAlt: It is not heard, can't be heard.
notes: This is what you have to say when you can't hear someone. Saying '못 들어요' would mean that you don't have the skill to hear (you are deaf).

en: I can’t see it.
I don’t understand.
notes: People like to say this because it implies that they do have the skill to understand, they just don't understand for some other reason. Basically this passive voice construction lets you blame someone else if you can't do something.

en: I’m worried because I can’t speak English.
Can you finish it today?

ko: 케익을 예쁘게 만들고 싶은데, 예쁘게 안 만들어져요.
en: I want to make this cake in a pretty shape, but I can’t do it.
Did you do it the way I told you?
notes: '-은/는 대로' means that the second action is done the same way as the first action.

en: Tell me what you heard.
enAlt: Tell me exactly as you heard it.

en: I delivered the message as I had heard it.
Do it like I do it.
Please tell me everything (whatever) you know.
Call me as soon as you arrive.
notes: '-는 대로' can also mean 'as soon as'.

en: Just do it the way you’ve always done it.
notes: '-던 대로' can also be used.

en: The kids are saying to hurry home.
notes: A sentence like '집에 가자' is called a propositive sentence because you suggest doing something together. To quote such a sentence, you add '-고 하다'.

en: Misha wants us to go play.
My friends asked me to eat lunch with them.
enAlt: My friends said "let's eat lunch together".

en: I suggested to people to be quiet.

ko: 그런데 사실 월요일에 비해서 화요일이나 목요일이 좋아요.
en: Actually Tuesdays and Thursdays are better than Mondays.
When do you (usually) feel like watching a movie?
notes: 어떨 때 = 'in what kind of times'

en: When do you (usually) have the hardest time?

ko: 어떨 때는 커피를 마시는데, 어떨 때는 안 마셔요.
en: Sometimes I drink coffee, but other times I don't.

ko: 어떨 때는 혼자 있는 것이 좋은데, 어떨 때는 싫어요.
en: Sometimes I like being alone, but other times, I don’t like it.

ko: 그 사람은 어떨 때는 친절한데, 어떨 때는 정말 불친절해요.
