en: Sometimes he is kind, but other times, he is very unkind.

ko: 이웃에게 불편을 주는 일이 없게 주의해 주시기 바랍니다.
en: Please take care not to inconvenience your neighbors.
enAlt: We wish you would not do things that may bother your neighbors.
notes: '-기를 바라다' means 'to hope, wish'. It is a formal expression used often in announcements. Technically the present tense form is '바라요' but almost all Koreans say '바래요' instead, and you should do that as well.

en: Let's maybe go to a karaoke bar (since we can't go hiking).
To paraphrase Edison, "Failure is the mother of success".
notes: When you want to make a direct quote, add "라고" and a verb after the quote.

en: Jesus said, "Love each other".

ko: 민우 씨가 "요즘 너무 바빠서 만날 수 없어요."라고 그랬어요.
en: Minu said, "I've been too busy recently to be able to meet you."
Dear, it says, "No parking here."

ko: 가끔 배가 출출할 때 "라면이나 먹을까?"라고 하죠?
en: Sometimes when you're a little hungry you want to eat ramen, right?
Please step aside so that people can pass through.
notes: '-도록' has several meanings, and one of them is "so that". It's most often used in requests.

ko: 제가 이해할 수 있도록 설명해 주세요.
en: Please explain so that I can understand.
Please talk in a way that everyone can hear you.
enAlt: Please talk so that everyone can hear you.

ko: 제가 볼 수 있도록 놓아 주세요.
en: Please put it so that I can see it.
I sang so much that my throat started hurting.
enAlt: I sang a lot, to the point where my throat hurt.
notes: '-도록' can also express a high degree of something.

en: I ate so many bananas that I got sick of them.

ko: 그 얘기는 귀가 아프도록 많이 들었어요.
en: My ears hurt from hearing this story so many times.
Hurry up so that you aren’t late.
Be careful so that you don’t fall over.
I explained it in a way that would be easy to understand.

ko: 이 신발은 다 떨어지도록 자주 신었어요.
en: I’ve worn these shoes so often that they're almost worn out.

ko: 감기에 걸리지 않도록 옷을 더 입으세요.
en: You should wear more clothes so that you don't catch a cold.
Ah, then I guess I should buy an mp3 player.

ko: 근처 백화점에서 세일을 해서 그런지 차가 많네요.
en: There are many cars. Maybe it's because the department store is having a sale.
notes: "-서 그런지" is used when the speaker is only guessing the reason but doesn't know for sure.

ko: 날씨가 추워서 그런지 두꺼운 옷이 잘 팔리네요.
en: Maybe the reason thick clothes sell well is that the weather is cold.

ko: 그리고 기능이 너무 많아서 그런지 좀 불편해요.
en: And it's a bit inconvenient to use, maybe because it has too many functions.

ko: 산 지 얼마 않아서 그런지 거의 새 거예요.
en: Maybe it's because I bought it recently, but it looks practically new.

ko: 제일 마음에 드는 것은 전원을 누를 필요 없이 열면 전원이 켜지는 거예요.
en: What I like the most is that it is turned on automatically when I open it, there's no need to press the power button.
notes: 전원 - power supply

ko: 내가 눈이 높은 걸까? 그래서 그런지 나는 아직까지 남자 친구가 없다.
en: Am I too picky? Maybe that's why I still don't have a boyfriend.
enAlt: Are my standards too high?

ko: 소개하기 전에 내 친구는 그 사람에 대해서 "정말 멋있는 사람이에요."라고 말했다.
en: Before introducing me to the guy, my friend said he (the guy) is really great.

ko: 점심을 먹으러 오는 길에 우체국에 들러서 부쳤어요.
en: I stopped by the post office on my way to lunch and sent it.

ko: 공항에 가는 길에 은행에 들러서 환전했어요.
en: I stopped by a bank on my way to the airport and exchanged the money.

ko: 가시는 길에 현금 인출기에서 한번 확인해 보세요.
en: You can verify it at an ATM on the way.
notes: 현금 - cash, 인출기 - machine

ko: 일 년 만에 만났는데 정말 반가웠다.
en: We hadn't met for a year so we were really happy.

ko: 친구들과 여기저기 구경하고 나니까 조금 피곤해서 나는 커피숍에서 이야기하면서 쉬려고 했다.
en: I was a bit tired after doing some sightseeing with my friends so I planned to have some rest at a coffee shop.
notes: '고 나니까' sort of combines "because" and "after".

en: The time of the farewell party has been changed. It's on Friday at five.
notes: '-ㅁ' can be used to turn a verb into a noun, for example 웃다 - 웃음. It can also be used as a sentence ending when you leave a note to someone. It's also used in laws, reports, etc. It's a neutral ending.

ko: 내일 부모님이 미국에서 오셔서 학교에 못 감.
en: I can't go to school tomorrow because my parents arrive from the US.
The concert is scheduled to start soon.

ko: 손님 여러분은 모두 자리에 앉아 주시기 바랍니다.
en: Guests, please take your seats.
You don't have to wear a formal outfit.

ko: 친구 집에 와서 즐겁게 보내기를 바랄게요.
en: I hope you have a nice time at your friend's.

ko: 동아리 친구 강호영 씨에게서 전화가 왔음.
en: You got a phone call from fellow club member Hoyeong Kang.
It can't be true.
enAlt: That's not possible!
notes: '-(으)ㄹ 리가 없다' means that there is no reason or logic for something to be so it can't be.

en: It can’t be snowing!
It’s impossible that she doesn’t know.
There's no way he went (there).
There's no way that tomorrow is Sunday.
It’s impossble that it is not cold. It’s January now.
It’s strange. It can’t not work.

ko: 어떨 때는 운동하는 게 재미있는데, 어떨 때는 운동하고 싶지 않을 때도 있어요.
en: Sometimes working out is fun, but there are also times when I don’t feel like exercising.

ko: 그러면 시청으로 해서 가는 길을 좀 알려 주시겠어요?
en: Will you tell me how to get there via City Hall?
enAlt: Can you tell me how to get there via City Hall?

ko: 예매하러 갔다가 사람이 너무 많아서 못 하고 왔어요.
en: I went to buy them but I couldn't because there were too many people there.
notes: '-았/었다가' is an expression that is mainly used with pairs of verbs with opposite meanings like 가다 - 오다, 열다 - 닫다, etc. It shows that the first action was complete and then the second action took place.

ko: 학교에 오는 길에 버스를 탔다가 고장이 나서 내렸어요.
en: I took a bus to school but it broke down so I had to get out.
enAlt: I got into a bus on my way to school but it broke down.

ko: 눈이 와서 길이 미끄러울 테니까 집으로 돌아갈 때 조심하세요.
en: It's been snowing so it's probably slippery outside. Be careful on your way home!
notes: '-ㄹ 테니까' is a combination of '-ㄹ 터이다' and '-으니까'. '-ㄹ 터이다' expresses either assumption or intention so that's how this construction is used. The first part of the sentence is either a strong guess or an intention, and that's the reason for the second part of the sentence. The first batch of example sentences are with the "assumption" meaning.

ko: 길이 막힐 테니까 집에서 일찍 출발하세요.
en: The roads will probably be full so leave your house early.

ko: 올림픽대로로 해서 가시면 시간이 많이 걸릴 테니까 피하시는 것이 좋겠습니다.
en: Going via the Olympic highway will probably take a lot of time so it's best to avoid it.
It must have been difficult for you so let's go eat something.
My house is far from school so I need to move closer.
notes: '-아/어야겠-' is used when the speaker will (have to) do something because there's a need for it. It's often used in self-talk. The 겠 part shows intention.

en: It's cold (in winter) so I will have to buy a scarf and some gloves.
What kind of size are you looking for?
enAlt: How big (of an apartment) are you looking for?

en: I'll have to discuss it with my friend.

ko: 하숙집은 식사 준비를 할 필요가 없으니까 편해요.
en: It's nice that you don't have to prepare your own meals in a boarding house.

ko: 남편 직장 때문에 외국에 가게 됐어요.
en: I'm moving to another country because of my husband's job.

ko: 아파트는 교통이 편리할수록 출퇴근하기 좋아서 인기가 많아요.
en: The better an apartment's location is transportation-wise, the more popular it is because it's easier to commute to work.
I'm thinking of watching a movie with my friends maybe.
I'm thinking about going on a trip to Europe.
notes: "-ㄹ까 하다" is used when you're thinking about doing something but there's no concrete plan yet and it can still change.

ko: 우리가 이야기하는 동안 아이가 물을 쏟은 모양이에요.
en: It looks like the child spilled the water while we were talking.
notes: "ㄴ/는/ㄹ 모양이다" is used when you see a situation or hear about it and make a guess as to what caused it or some related circumstances.

en: Looks like the food was expensive.
I'm thinking of booking the flight to New York on September 4th.

ko: 아마 제 친구가 다른 이름으로 예약한 모양입니다.
en: It looks like my friend made the reservation under a different name.

ko: 그런데 차를 가지고 갈까 하는데 주차는 몇 시간 됩니까?
en: I'm thinking of going by car. How long can I leave it in the parking lot?

ko: 유학을 포기하는 대신에 여기에서 대학원에 진학하기로 했어요.
en: Instead of studying abroad, I decided to attend a local graduate school.
enAlt: Since I gave up on studying abroad, I decided to attend a local graduate school.
notes: 포기하다 - to give up

en: Let's book the same place we always went to.
notes: '-던' is attached to action verbs, and it means that the action was performed regularly in the past but not anymore.

ko: 요즘에도 인기가 있지만 한동안 손님들이 꽤 많이 찾던 거예요.
en: It's still popular these days, but for a while really many customers wanted it.

ko: 그 책은 작년부터 잘 팔리던 거라서 서두르시는 게 좋을 겁니다.
en: The book has been selling well since last year so it's best to act quickly.
the movie that I was watching yesterday (and didn't finish)
notes: -던 has a second usage with action verbs - it can mean an action that was started but not completed. In this usage, there's almost always a specific time indicated, like "yesterday".

en: I used to frequently go to this place in the past.

ko: 친했던 친구들이 지금은 다 외국에 살아요.
en: The friends I used to be close to are all living overseas now.
notes: -던 can also be used with descriptive verbs to show the past tense. In this usage, almost always 았/었던 is used.

en: This is what we were talking about last week.
I try to always keep correct posture.
notes: 자세 - posture, 바르다 - straight, 노력하다 - to make an effort

ko: 저도 내일부터 투이 씨를 따라 해 봐야겠어요.
en: I should follow your actions starting from tomorrow.

ko: 하루에 세 번 이상 크게 웃으세요.
en: Laugh out loud at least three times a day.
notes: 이상 - this amount or more

en: I'm thinking of continuing my Korean studies.

ko: 사무실에서 식사를 하면서 일할 때도 많아요.
en: There are many times when I have to eat at the office and work at the same time.
It's not difficult for you to live in China, right?

ko: 이번 제 생일에는 집에서 파티를 할까 해요.
en: I'm thinking of having my birthday party at home this time.

ko: 이야기도 하고 음식도 만들어 먹을까 해요.
en: We could chat and prepare our own food.
That day is my birthday.
I plan to exercise every day for at least an hour.

ko: 민수 씨는 공무원이 되고 싶다고 했지요?
en: You said you wanted to become a civil servant, right?
When will you start preparing for the civil servant exam?
So exercise regularly.

ko: - 한국말을 정말 잘하시네요!- 잘하기는요. 아직도 더 많이 배워야 해요.
en:
- Your Korean is really good!
- No, it's not really that good. I've still got so much more to learn.
notes: "-기는요" is used to show disagreement. It can be either real disagreement or just modesty.

ko: - 어제 영화 재미있었어요?- 재미있기는요. 보다가 졸았어요.
en:
- Was the movie interesting yesterday?
- Not really that interesting. I fell asleep watching it.

ko: - 한국 문화를 잘 아시네요.- 잘 알기는요.
en:
- You know Korean culture well.
- Not that well.

ko: - 수현 씨 딸은 공부를 잘하지요?- 잘하기는요.
en:
- Your daughter is doing well at school, right?
- No, she's not.
She left in a hurry saying she had to meet someone.
enAlt: I saw her leave in a hurry saying she had to meet someone.
notes: "-더라고요" is used when the speaker directly saw or heard or experienced something (for the first time).

ko: - 어제 본 공연이 어땠어요?- 아주 재미있더라고요.
en:
- How was yesterday's performance?
- It was very interesting (I know because I saw it).
I just saw him studying in the library.
I just saw him playing soccer with his friends on the field.

ko: 처음에는 누군지 몰랐는데 만나고 보니 초등학교 동창이었어요.
en: At first, I didn't know who it was, but after meeting, we discovered we were schoolmates in elementary school.
notes: '-고 보니(까)' is used to indicate that the speaker learned or discovered something new after an action or event occurred.

en: I got off the subway and realized I didn't have my bag with me.

ko: 가방을 싸고 보니 여행안내책을 안 넣었더라고요.
en: After packing my bag, I discovered that I hadn't put in the guide book.
notes: '-았/었더라고요' is used for things that were completed in the past.

ko: 왜 여행 가방을 쌌다가 다시 풀어요?
en: Why are you unpacking the travel bag you just packed?
Why did you change the plans you made?
After I put the sweater on, I discovered I had put it on front to back.

ko: 막상 휴학하고 보니까 심심하고 학교생활이 그리워요.
en: Actually I discovered that taking time off from school is boring and I miss the school life.

ko: 그러고 보니까 일본에서는 밥그릇을 손에 들고 먹는 것 같네요.
en: Now that I think about it, Japanese people hold rice bowls in their hands while eating.

ko: 어렸을 때 얌전했던 윤주가 지금은 적극적인 성격으로 바뀌었어요.
en: Yunju, who used to be modest when she was young, now has an enthusiastic personality.

ko: 투이 씨가 도와준 덕분에 일이 금방 끝났어요.
en: The work was done quickly thanks to your help.
I can do the rest by myself.
It's all thanks to you.
Please also give teacher Kim my thanks.
I'll have to be more careful from now on.
Then I'll have to watch it sometime.
It's because you always wear just comfortable pants and a T-shirt.
notes: "-에다가" is often interchangeable with 에. It means to add something to something(s) or to move something to someplace else.

en: Put it over here.
I left it at home.
I come here quite frequently, too.
notes: "-ㄴ/는 편이다" is an expression that shows a tendency towards an action or a state. It makes the sentence less definite.

ko: 여기는 다른 곳에 비해서 조용한 편이에요.
en: It's pretty quiet here compared to other places.

ko: 저는 검은색 옷을 즐겨 입는 편이에요.
en: I quite enjoy wearing black clothes.
We are somewhat busier than last week.

ko: 한국어에 비해서 일본어는 발음이 쉬운 편이에요.
en: In general, Japanese has an easier pronunciation than Korean.

ko: 저는 옷에 별로 신경 쓰지 않는 편이거든요.
en: I don't care much about clothes.
A coat on top of a sweater is true winter attire.
You look tired.
notes: "-아/어 보이다" is used to say how something or someone looks.

ko: 머리 모양을 바꾸니까 훨씬 어려 보이네요.
en: You look much younger now that you've changed your hairstyle.

ko: 일이 많고 바쁠 때도 항상 여유가 있어 보여요.
en: He looks as if he has time to spare even when he's busy with work.
I'm a bit impatient (hot-tempered).
It doesn't look like that at all.

ko: 저는 성격이 별로 적극적인 편이 아니라서 친구를 사귈 때 시간이 좀 오래 걸려요.
en: I'm not that active so it takes me some time to make new friends.

ko: 1권을 공부할 때 시디(CD)를 들으면서 얼마나 열심히 연습했는지 몰라요.
en: I spent a huge amount of time practicing with the CD while we were studying the first book.
notes: "얼마나 -는지 모르다" is used to say that the degree or amount of something is very high.

en: He's studying very hard these days.
Soraksan views are very beautiful.
You should definitely go there.
I'm thinking of going shopping. How about Dongdaemun market?

ko: 회사 일이 많거나 한국어 시험이 있을 때는 얼마나 바쁜지 몰라요.
en: I'm super busy when I have a lot of work or when a Korean exam is coming up.

ko: 작년 생일에 친구들하고 같이 갔던 스키장이에요.
en: It's the ski resort my friends and I went to on my last birthday.
notes: When "-았/었던" is used with action verbs, it describes a situation that happened once, finished and was not repeated.

ko: 1년 전에 읽었던 책을 요즘 다시 읽기 시작했습니다.
en: I recently started rereading a book I already read one year ago.
Do you remember Chris? We studied together last year.

ko: 우리를 가르쳐 주셨던 선생님께 인사를 드리러 갈 거야.
en: We're going to go and greet the teacher who taught us.
Our teacher was very worried at that time too.
It's Saturday. Where are you going?
notes: '-니' is the question ending of the plain speech style.

en: Okay, be careful.
How is your preparation for university going?

ko: 모두 열심히 노력해서 꿈을 이루시기 바랍니다.
en: I hope you work hard and achieve your dreams.
I'm Zoey. I lived in room no.102 until last December.

ko: 제가 들어가고 싶었던 회사에 취직을 했어요.
en: I got a job at the company I wanted.

ko: 아마 커피숍에 있을걸요. 아까 커피숍에 간다고 했거든요.
en: He's probably at the coffee shop. I heard him say he was going there earlier.
notes: "-ㄹ걸요" indicates an assumption or a guess. It is less sure than "-ㄹ 거예요" and it is used mostly in the spoken language.

ko: 아마 안 갔을걸요. 예전에 테니스를 못 친다고 했던 것 같아요.
en: I doubt he went. I think he once said that he can't play tennis.

ko: 이 시간에는 보통 운동을 하니까 집에 없을걸요.
en: He's usually exercising at this hour so he's probably not at home.

ko: 고향까지 일주일 정도 걸리니까 벌써 도착했을걸요.
en: It takes a week to get to your hometown so it's probably there already.

ko: 습도가 낮아서 그런지 그렇게 덥지는 않은데요.
en: Maybe it's because humidity is low but it doesn't feel that hot.

ko: 민지 씨는 태국의 여름은 하루도 못 견딜걸요.
en: You probably wouldn't last even a day in Thailand's summer.

ko: 길을 건너서 오른쪽으로 가면 경찰서가 있거든요. 거기에서 왼쪽으로 가세요.
en: If you cross the street and go right, you'll see a police station. Turn left there.

ko: 길이 막히면 늦을까 봐서 좀 일찍 나가요.
en: I'm leaving early because I'm afraid there will be traffic jams and I might be late.
notes: "-을까 봐(서)" is used when you are worried that something bad might happen so you take action to avoid it if possible.

ko: 여자 친구가 싫어할까 봐서 담배도 안 피워요.
en: I even stopped smoking because I was afraid my girlfriend might not like it.

ko: 눈 때문에 길이 미끄러울까 봐 등산화를 신고 나가려고요.
en: I put on my mountain climbing boots to go out because I was afraid the ground would be slippery.
I am so worried that I failed the exam.

ko: 한국 회사에 적응을 못할까 봐 걱정이에요.
en: She's worried she might not be able to adjust to working for a Korean company.

ko: 회의하면서 마시게 커피 좀 사 올까요?
en: Should I go and buy some coffee for us to drink during the meeting?
notes: When -게 is attached to an action verb like this, it means almost the same thing as -도록. A slight difference is that 도록 often shows a degree of something while the goal with 게 is more certain.

ko: 그럼 나도 읽게 다 읽은 후에 좀 빌려 주세요.
en: Please lend it to me after you're done reading it so that I could read it, too.

ko: 한국문학 수업을 듣고 싶은데 너무 어려울까 봐 좀 망설이고 있어.
en: I want to take Korean literature but it might be too difficult for me so I'm hesitating (to sign up for it).

ko: 그럼 수업에 대한 정보를 좀 얻을 수 있게 그 수업을 들었던 선배들에게 물어보면 어때?
en: How about asking some students who've already taken the class what they can tell you about it?

ko: 친구가 오해하지 않게 잘 이야기해 보세요.
en: Explain it properly so that your friend doesn't misunderstand.
I'll make sure they feel comfortable.

ko: 뒷사람들도 잘 들을 수 있게 마이크를 사용할게요.
en: I'll use a microphone so that the people in the back can hear, too.
I'll put on earphones so that I don't disturb others.

ko: 입장료를 내지 않는 경우에도 예약을 해야 들어가실 수 있습니다.
en: Even if you don't have to pay the entrance fee, you still have to make a reservation in order to be able to enter the place.
notes: The part before "-야" shows what has to be done before the second part can happen.

ko: 건강해야 무슨 일이든지 할 수 있지.
en: You won't be able to do anything if you are not healthy.
enAlt: No matter what you want to do, you have to be healthy to do it.
notes: 무슨 일이든지 - anything, whatever

en: But I guess I should keep studying.
You should learn Korean well to live comfortably in Korea.

ko: 무엇보다도 음식이 맛있어야 손님이 많이 와요.
en: You won't get many customers if the food is not delicious.
notes: 무엇보다 - above all

en: Only members (can) receive discounts.

ko: 회의실은 우리가 같이 쓰는 곳이니까 저도 같이 정리를 해야지요.
en: We use the meeting room together so we should also tidy it up together.
notes: '-야지요' is similar to '-야 돼요', but not as strong. It is used in spoken Korean a lot.

en: Only people with good English skills can take this on.
Sorry but you can't get a loan without a student ID.

ko: 한국어 능력 4급 이상이 돼야 지원할 수 있어요.
en: You can't apply unless your Korean level is at least 4.

ko: 다음 방학에는 고향에 가서 엄마가 해 주신 음식을 실컷 먹어야지.
en: During the next vacation, I'll have to visit home and stuff myself with mom's cooking.
From this year I've got to obey traffic signals.

ko: 올해 꼭 해야겠다고 생각한 일이 있어요?
en: Have you thought of something you must definitely do this year?

ko: '올해는 꼭 텔레비전 보는 시간을 줄여야지'라고 생각했어요.
en: I've thought that I should watch less TV this year.
It's an important meeting so of course I should wear a suit.

ko: 한국에 못 오게 될까 봐 걱정도 많이 하고 울기도 했어요.
en: I was worried I wouldn't be able to come to Korea and I also cried because of it.

ko: 담배를 피우는 것은 정말 학생답지 않은 행동이다.
en: Smoking is not becoming/typical of students.
notes: -답다 is attached to nouns to express the typical characteristics of the nouns. The result is a descriptive verb.

ko: 오늘 경기 모습은 세계적인 축구 선수답지가 않네요.
en: His play today is unlike that of a world-class football player.

ko: 학생은 학생답게 옷을 입어야지. 좀 더 얌전한 옷으로 갈아입어.
en: Students should wear something fitting for students. Put on something a little more modest.
All types of coffee were delicious like in a famous coffee shop.
He handles everything like an expert.

ko: 어머니께 드릴 선물이라면 이 색깔이 더 좋을 것 같습니다.
en: If it's a present for your mother, this color might be better.
enAlt: This color might be better for your mother's present.
notes: "-(이)라면" is a contraction of 이라고 하면 so it means "if you're saying that...". But often the English translation doesn't need any "if", as you can see in the second translation.

en: I see that it's more expensive than I thought.
notes: "-구나" is the casual version of "-군요".

en: So you are still participating in the club?
The weather is too nice to stay at home.

ko: 일주일 동안 계속 일하고 금요일 저녁에 춤까지 추고 나면 너무 피곤하겠다.
en: You must be very tired after working all week and then dancing on Friday night on top of that.
notes: "-고 나면" means "if" or "after". More info here: https://funkorean4u.wordpress.com/2016/06/18/grammar-%EA%B3%A0-%EB%82%98%EB%8B%A4-after-i-did/

ko: 신나는 음악에 맞춰 춤추며 땀을 흘리고 나면 몸이 굉장히 가벼워지는 느낌이 들어.
en: You feel really light after dancing to up-beat music and sweating.
notes: "-며" has two meanings: a more formal version of "-면서" and a more formal version of "-고".

en: You look happy.

ko: 우울할 때는 혼자 있는 것보다 자꾸 사람들을 만나는 게 나아요.
en: When you're feeling down, socializing a lot is better than being alone.

ko: 집에서 하는 것보다 식당에서 하는 게 나을 거예요.
en: Having the party at a restaurant is probably better than having it at home.

ko: 제이슨 씨, 콧노래도 부르고 신이 나 보이는데요.
en: Jason, you are humming and seem excited. (Why?)
I'm in a good mood but somewhat cold.

ko: 집이 크고 깨끗해서 마음에 들기는 하지만 지하철역이 멀어서 교통이 불편할 것 같아요.
en: I do like that the house is big and clean but the public transportation is inconvenient since the subway station is far from it.

ko: 며칠 전에 갔는데 분위기도 좋고 비빔밥도 아주 맛있던데요.
en: I went there a few days ago. The atmosphere was good and the bibimpap was very delicious.
notes: "-던데요" is used when you recollect a past event and you want to contradict the other speaker or express surprise or admiration.

en: The last scene was very touching.

ko: 지난번에 갔을 때는 집이 아주 커 보이던데요.
en: But it looked really big when I went there last time.

ko: 아까 보니까 오늘도 얼굴 표정이 안 좋으시던데요.
en: When I saw him earlier today, he still didn't look good.
There's a restaurant called "School Food" here.
notes: "-라는" stands for "-라고 하는".

en: A friend called Alex will come tomorrow.

ko: 다 재미있었는데 그 중에서 '우리 생애 최고의 순간'이라는 영화가 제일 기억에 남아요.
en: All the movies were fun, but the one that stayed with me the most is called "Forever The Moment".

ko: 전 감동적인 영화도 좋아하기는 하지만 흥미진진한 영화를 더 좋아해요.
en: I do like touching movies, but I like exciting movies more.

ko: 좀 시끄럽기는 하지만 답답할 때 들으면 얼마나 속이 시원해지는데요.
en: It might be loud but if I listen to it when I'm frustrated I feel so much better afterwards.

ko: 타완이 연락하기로 했는데 깜빡 잊었나 봐.
en: Tawan planned to call you but he must have forgotten.

ko: 이번 주말 행사 준비 다 되어 가고 있지?
en: The preparations for the weekend activities are almost done, right?
notes: "아/어 가다" shows an ongoing process that is progressing towards the main verb, in this case (다) 되다.

en: The US economy continues to go downhill.
The flowers are almost in full bloom.
I will check carefully.
notes: 진행하다 - to proceed

en: Is our love already cooling off?
How have you been?
Who's this?
notes: 냐? is another plain style question ending. It is rather argumentative or condescending, however, and is used more by males than females.

ko: 우리 아무리 바빠도 안부는 전하며 살자.
en: Let's make time to greet (send regards to) others even if we are busy.
I plan to visit my teacher.
He probably won't even remember me.
He really adored you in those days.

ko: 엄마만큼 잘하지는 못했지만 그래도 아주 기뻐하셨어요.
en: I couldn't do it as well as my mom does it but they were still very happy.
notes: "-만큼" is attached to nouns and it shows the degree of something.

en: We don’t meet as often as in Korea.
How much should each of us pay?

ko: 각자 먹은 만큼 내면 될 것 같아요.
en: Each person should pay an amount equal to how much he or she ate.
notes: "만큼" can also be a stand-alone noun. Its meaning is the same - the degree or extent of something.

ko: 요즘 영화를 볼 만큼 한가하지 않아요.
en: These days, I don't have enough free time to watch movies.

ko: 다른 사람에게 조금 설명해 줄 수 있을 만큼 알아요.
en: I know enough to explain a little about it to others.
She's as kind-hearted as she is pretty.
He's as tall as his father.
You can take as much as you want.
Then your whole family will be there.

ko: 그런데 어느 날 진짜 호랑이만큼 큰 늑대가 나타났어요.
en: But one day a wolf really appeared and it was as big as a tiger.
Leave that to me.

ko: 먼저 캔은 캔끼리, 병은 병끼리, 플라스틱은 플라스틱끼리 모아.
en: First you gather up cans, bottles, and plastics separately.

ko: 씨앗을 처음 보지요? 직접 보니까 어때요?
en: This is the first time you've seen seeds, right? How do they look?

ko: 샤워를 할 때는 계속 물을 틀어 놓으면 안 돼요.
en: You should not leave the water running the whole time you're taking a shower.
notes: "-아/어 놓다" shows the continuation of a state after an action. In this case, the water was turned on and it stayed that way.

en: I turn my cell phone off when I'm in class.
When did you prepare a lunchbox?
Did you say it's raining?
notes: This form of reported speech is used to clarify or confirm what the other person just said.

en: Where did you say to meet?
Where did you say to come?
What did you tell me not to use?
Did you say you get up at 5 every morning and exercise?
You left the gas range on?

ko: 고기를 냉장고에 안 넣어 놓고 나왔다고요?
en: You didn't put the meat into the refrigerator before going out?
You have to tidy up your room before you can play.
Doesn't bibimpap need red pepper paste to taste good?

ko: 고추장을 많이 넣으면 매울 테니까 조금만 넣으세요.
en: It will be spicy if you add a lot of red pepper paste, so only put in a little.
I'm sure he did well, don't worry.
He will be here soon so wait just a moment.

ko: 지하철을 타는 게 좋겠어요. 출근 시간이라 길이 많이 막힐 테니까요.
en: Taking the subway would be best. It's rush hour so the traffic will be very slow.

ko: 음식을 충분히 준비하는 게 좋겠어요. 주말이라 사람들이 많이 올 테니까요.
en: It would be best to prepare ample food. It's the weekend so a lot of people will come.

ko: 제가 점심 살 테니까 경화 씨가 커피 사세요.
en: I will buy lunch, so you buy the coffee.
notes: This is an example sentence for -ㄹ 테니까 where the first part expresses an intention.

ko: 나머지는 제가 할 테니까 먼저 퇴근하세요.
en: I'll do the rest, you can go home now.

ko: 엄마가 용돈을 더 줄 테니까 더 기쁜 마음으로 도와 줘.
en: I will give you more pocket money, so you can be even happier to help others.
I thought about it and realized I was wrong, too.
notes: "-아/어 보니까" is the combination of "-아/어 보다" (to try) and "-니까" (to discover).

ko: 제가 우산 들고 지하철역 안에서 기다릴 테니까 걱정하지 마세요.
en: Don't worry, I will be waiting for you inside the subway station with an umbrella.
I didn't do my homework because I was watching a football game last night.
notes: '-느라고' is another construction that expresses the reason for something. The result is always negative or undesirable and the reason is sometimes just an excuse.

en: I was making kimchi and became really exhausted.
I'm extremely busy preparing the university admission forms.
notes: Only action verbs can be used with -느라고, and the subject in both parts of the sentence must be the same.

en: I was working out so I didn't know you called.
I spent all the money paying for my tuition fees.
notes: -느라고 is sometimes shortened to -느라.

ko: 나 데려다 주시느라고 우리 아빠가 지각하셨을까 봐 걱정이야.
en: I'm worried that my father might have been late [for work] because he gave me a ride [to school].
They say that this is the best.
notes: -대요 is short for -다고 해요.

en: She says she's going now.
They say this place is really famous.
They say it has ended already.
He says he doesn’t know where it is.
My friend says he will come to Korea.
notes: -래요 is short from -라고 해요.

ko: 김치가 건강에 아주 좋아서 몸에 좋은 약이래.
en: They say kimchi is a medicine because it is so good for your health.

ko: 그리고 김치를 먹으면 감기에도 잘 안 걸리고 나쁜 병에도 잘 안 걸린대.
en: [Doctors say that] if you eat kimchi you will be less likely to get a cold or other diseases.

ko: 우진이 너 감기에 걸릴 때마다 병원에 가서 주사 맞기 싫었지?
en: Woojin, you don't want to go to a doctor and get a shot every time you catch a cold, do you?

ko: 옛날에 할머니가 동생들을 돌보느라고 하고 싶은 공부를 못하셨대.
en: When your grandmother was young she had to watch her little siblings and couldn't study as she wished.

ko: 집안일 하느라 숙제할 시간이 없으면 밤이라도 새서 숙제를 하지.
en: Sometimes when I don't have time for homework because of chores, I even stay up at night to do it.

ko: 유행보다는 꼭 필요한 물건을 샀으면 좋겠어.
en: It would be better to buy things you really need rather than things that are in fashion.

ko: 이 케이크가 맛있어 보여서 샀는데, 너무 달아요.
en: This cake looked delicious so I bought it, but it’s too sweet.
I can’t see clearly because it’s far, but it looks like a “3”.

ko: 경찰처럼 보이는 사람이 그 여자를 데려갔어요.
en: Someone who looks like a cop took her.
Vitamin C is good if you have a cold (as you know).
I always told you to study hard.
I've spent all my money (living expenses).
notes: '아/어 버리다' is used to emphasize that an action is completely finished and often also to show the speaker's happiness or, as in this case, unhappiness about the result.

en: I’ve already told them everything.

ko: 10분 더 기다려도 안 오면 저 혼자 가 버릴 거예요.
en: If I wait for 10 more minutes (and) you don’t come, I will just go by myself.

ko: 어제 쓴 글이 마음에 안 들어서 다 지워 버렸어요.
en: I didn’t like what I wrote yesterday, so I’ve erased it all.
I only played games for 30 minutes as promised.
notes: '-대로' can also be attached to nouns.

en: Excuse me, does this go to Dongdaemun?
notes: '-ㅂ니다만' is very similar to -지만, only more formal.

ko: 무엇이든지 한 번에 많이는 좋지 않아요.
en: Anything can be bad for you if you take too much at a time.

ko: 엄마, 지금 우석이 오빠랑 메신저를 하고 있는데 오빠가 한국에 언제 오느냬요.
en: Mom, I'm talking to Wooseok on messenger and he's asking when we're going to Korea.
notes: This is the contracted form for reported questions.

ko: 오빠가 그럼 일요일에 친구들이랑 자전거 타러 가는데 같이 가재요.
en: He will go riding bicycles with his friends on Sunday and he suggested that I go with them.
notes: This is the contracted form for reported suggestions.

ko: 처음에는 생각이 없었는데 친구 가족이 오재서 오신 분들 많지요?
en: Many of you only came here after your friends suggested this, right?
notes: 오재서 is short for 오자고 해서

ko: 두 가족씩 한 조로 만들어 진행하겠습니다.
en: Every two families should form one group, then we will proceed.
notes: 조 - group

ko: 오늘 먼저 각 조끼리 함께 텐트를 치고 좀 쉬신 후에 다시 모여 주세요.
en: First every group should pitch a tent, then rest a little and gather together again.

ko: 이 시간엔 택시 잡기가 힘들 텐데, 어떻게 하지요?
en: What should we do? We won't be able to get a taxi at this time.
notes: '-ㄹ 텐데' is a combination of '-ㄹ 터이다' and '-은데', therefore it expresses an assumption about the future (or a current situation).

en: I don't know if there will be any empty taxis.

ko: 바람이 불면 추울 텐데 따뜻하게 입고 가는 게 좋겠어요.
en: It will be cold if it's windy so it'd be good to wear warm clothes when going out.

ko: 벌써 초대장을 받았을 텐데 연락이 없네요.
en: She should have received the invitation, but I haven't heard from her yet.

ko: 세일 중이라 사람이 많을 텐데 다음에 가요.
en: There's a sale going on so there will be many people there. Let's go some other time.
The weather will be hot later.
notes: '-텐데' can also be used at the end of sentences, just like '은데'.

en: It will be noisy in the coffee shop.
Do you mean the blue dress with the flower pattern?
enAlt: Are you talking about the blue dress with flowers on it?

en: The climate is warm and the scenery is very beautiful.

ko: 광고를 보니까 10만 원짜리가 좋을 것 같아요.
en: I like the one worth 100,000 won that I saw in an ad.

ko: 그 후에 같이 초대할지 따로 초대할지 결정해.
en: Then you can decide whether to invite them together or separately.

ko: 은행에서 돈을 빌려 가지고 집을 샀어요.
en: I bought a house with the mortgage from a bank.

ko: 밖으로 나갔다가 다른 쪽으로 다시 들어가셔야 합니다.
en: You need to go outside and then come back in from the other side.

ko: 친구들과 같이 삼겹살을 구워 먹을까 해요.
en: I'm planning to have some Korean barbecue with some friends.
In that case, why not ask the teacher?
notes: "-지 그래요" is used to suggest something, but it's a very mild suggestion.

ko: 그럼, 다른 옷으로 바꾸거나 환불을 하지 그래요?
en: In that case, why don't you exchange them for something else or get your money back?
Give me at least that one.
enAlt: Even though you don't have the item I really want, this one could be useful as well so give it to me.
notes: "-(이)라도" attaches to nouns similarly as (이)나 to indicate that the noun is not the best choice. The difference is that with (이)나 you don't really care what to choose, but with (이)라도 you care and want to pick the second best option.

en: Do you want some snacks at least?
enAlt: (I know that snacks are not proper food but it's better than nothing.)

en: In that case, why don't you rest, even if just a little bit?
Why don't you order it on the internet?
Why don't you add at least some soy sauce (since you don't have salt)?

ko: 정말 안 늦으려고 했는데 오늘도 또 늦어 버렸어요.
en: I was late today again despite trying not to be.

ko: 그러니까 집에서 좀 일찍 출발하지 그랬어요?
en: So why didn't you leave the house earlier?
notes: The past tense is used to express disapproval or regret.

ko: 내일 가지고 가야 할 전공책이 다 팔려 버렸어요.
en: The textbook I need tomorrow is sold out.

ko: 그러니까 좀 서둘러서 책을 사지 그랬어요?
en: Why didn't you buy the book sooner?
I read a lot so my eyes are tired.
notes: "-았/었더니" is made up of '더' and '니까', both of which you know already. The first part of the sentence is usually something you did and the second part is the result of it. This construction is quite similar to '어서' and '니까', but it has the nuance of personal experience. Sometimes it's also used when the result was unexpected.

ko: 어제 몸이 안 좋았는데 회식에 갔더니 더 안 좋아져 버렸어요.
en: Yesterday I was not feeling well but I went out and as a result got even more sick.
I worked late for a few days straight and fell ill as a result.
I drank some coffee earlier so now I'm fine.
Is it true you went to your home town?
notes: "-다면서요" is used when you heard something somewhere and now you want to check whether it's really true.

ko: 주말에 부산에서 서울까지 운전을 하고 가셨다면서요?
en: Did you really drive your car from Busan to Seoul?
I hadn't been to my home town in a long time and I saw that it had changed a lot.

ko: 5시간 동안 운전을 했더니 허리가 너무 아프더라고요.
en: I drove for five hours straight and got a severe back pain as a result.

ko: 지연 씨한테 같이 영화 보자고 했더니 약속이 있대요.
en: I asked Jiyeon to come with us to the movies but she said she had other plans.
enAlt: I asked Jiyeon to come with us to the movies but apparently she has other plans.

ko: 결혼하고 한 번도 선물을 받아 본 적이 없어서 장미꽃 한 송이라도 받아 보면 좋겠어요.
en: I haven't received a single gift since we got married. It would be nice to get even just a rose sometimes.
Please come and help out (because better qualified people are not available).

ko: 내일 개업식에 사람이 많이 와야 할 텐데 몇 명밖에 연락이 안 돼서 걱정이에요.
en: Many people need to come to the opening ceremony tomorrow but I'm worried because I've only been able to get in touch with a few of them.

ko: 그럼 연락된 사람이라도 꼭 오라고 하세요.
en: At least tell the people you could contact to definitely come.

ko: 집에 늦게 들어올 때는 전화라도 하라고 하세요.
en: Tell him to at least call you if he comes home late.

ko: 오늘 사무실 사람들과 같이 식사를 못 한다면서요?
en: Is it true you can't eat with your coworkers today?
Is it true you haven't finished the report yet?

ko: 그래서 교수님께 몇 시간만이라도 시간을 더 달라고 부탁드리려고 해요.
en: I plan to ask the professor for more time, even if just a few hours.
Is it true that you broke up with your boyfriend?
Is it true that Mt. Seorak is really beautiful these days?

ko: 그럼 주말에 가까운 곳으로 여행을 가 보지 그래요?
en: Why not go on a short trip on the weekend?

ko: 사진관에 가서 같이 사진을 찍지 그래요?
en: Why don't you go to a photo studio to take some pictures together?

ko: 더울 뿐만 아니라 비도 많이 와요.
en: It's not only hot, it's rainy as well.
notes: '-ㄹ 뿐만 아니라' means "not only - but also".

ko: 경치가 아름다울 뿐만 아니라 바다도 깨끗해요.
en: Not only is the view beautiful, the beach is clean as well.
Not only is she smart, she also has a nice personality.

ko: 일이 일찍 끝날 뿐만 아니라 월급도 많이 줘요.
en: Not only can I leave early but the pay is great, too.

ko: 가격이 저렴할 뿐만 아니라 디자인도 예뻐서 요즘 잘 나가요.
en: Not only is it cheap, it's also pretty so it sells well.

ko: 옛 마을 모습을 볼 수 있을 뿐만 아니라 한옥에서도 묵을 수 있어서 정말 좋았어요.
en: Not only could I see old villages there, I also spent the night in a traditional Korean home. It was fun.

ko: 저는 인터넷에서 사진을 보고 방이 넓은 줄 알았어요.
en: I saw a picture on the internet and thought the room would be bigger.
I drink coffee whenever I'm sleepy.
I'll make sure not to do that again.

ko: 스쿠버 다이빙 장비만 있으면 마치 물고기가 된 것처럼 물속을 마음대로 돌아다닐 수 있습니다.
en: Scuba gear is all you need in order to get around in the water as if you were a fish.
notes: 마치 ... 것처럼 is a common construction.

ko: 엄마는 뭐든지 네가 좋아하는 일을 하면 좋겠어.
en: I just hope you get to do what you like, whatever that may be.

ko: 지금도 엄마는 할아버지 사진을 보시며 진짜 미남이시라고, 아빠보다 훨씬 잘생기셨다고 말씀하세요.
en: Even now my mother says that my grandfather is much better looking than my dad when she looks at his photo.

ko: 나도 할아버지를 닮았냐고 엄마에게 물어보면 엄마는 제가 할아버지와 아빠를 모두 닮았다고 하세요.
en: When I ask my mom whether I resemble my grandfather, she says I resemble both my father and my grandfather.

ko: 초등학교 4학년 때부터 규칙적으로 수영을 하다 보니 이렇게 건강해졌어.
en: I became this healthy after I started swimming regularly in my 4th year of elementary school.
notes: "-다 보니" is short for "-다가 보니까" and it's used when some action was occurring for a period of time and something changed as a result, or the speaker learned something new.

ko: 박사님 말씀을 듣다 보니 규칙적인 생활이 정말 중요한 것 같습니다.
지나치게 긴 시간 동안 힘든 운동을 하면 오히려 건강에 안 좋으므로 적당히 하는 것이 좋습니다.
en: forlater

ko: 혼자 살다 보니 집 정리를 잘 안 하게 돼요.
en: Once I started living alone, I started not cleaning up as much.

ko: 처음엔 싫어했는데 매일 같이 일하다 보니 양강 씨의 좋은 점이 보이더라고요.
en: I didn't like him at first, but after working together with him, I have come to see his strong points.

ko: 하지만 졸릴 때마다 커피를 마시다 보니 이제는 습관이 됐어요.
매일 신문을 읽다 보니까 상식이 많아진 것 같아요.
매일 운전을 하다 보니까 길을 잘 찾게 된 것 같아요.

en: You must have been very embarrassed.
Really? That must have been very exciting.
Yes, I'll have to do that.

ko: 한국이 이겼다는 얘기는 들었는데, 어떻게 이긴 거야?
en: I heard Korea won. How did it happen?
notes: "-다는" is short for "-다고 하는".

ko: 이 밖에 다른 종목의 선수들도 메달을 따겠다는 각오로 열심히 훈련을 하고 있습니다.
en: Athletes from other disciplines are also practicing hard with a determination to win medals.

ko: 우리 선수들이 올림픽에서 기쁜 소식을 많이 전해 주었으면 하는 바람입니다.
en: forlater
These are called marbles.
notes: "-라는" is short for "-라고 하는".

ko: 자유라는 것은 아무거나 마음대로 하는 것이 아니에요.
en: Freedom doesn't mean doing anything you want.
Love is not easy.
notes: -이란 is short for -이라는 것은.

en: Please form groups of four.

ko: 사진이랑 동영상들을 보면 너도 생각이 달라질걸.

en: I'm late because of traffic.
notes: "-는 바람에" is used to show reason/result. The result is something unexpected or unintended and usually something negative. This construction can only be used with verbs, and the second clause must be in the past tense.

ko: 차가 고장 나는 바람에 수리 센터에 갔다 와야 했어요.
en: My car broke down and I had to go to a service center (as a result).
I heard that Mark is in the hospital.

ko: 교통사고가 나는 바람에 다쳐서 병원에 입원했대요.
en: He was injured in a traffic accident and went to the hospital.

ko: 경기를 하다가 넘어지는 바람에 금메달을 못 닸어요.
en: He had a fall during the match and didn't get the gold medal (as a result).

ko: 비싸지 않습니다만 잃어버리면 안 되니까 보험에 들게요.
en: It's not expensive but I shouldn't lose it so I'll get insurance.

ko: 돌아오는 대로 전화 좀 해 달라고 전해 주세요.
en: Please tell her as soon as she returns that I asked her to call me.
notes: "달라고" is used in quoted sentences when the unquoted sentence would have used "-아/어 주세요". In this case it would have been "전화 해 주세요".

ko: 국에다가 해물을 넣어서 끓여 먹었는데 그것 때문인가요?
en: Is it perhaps because I ate soup with seafood in it?

ko: 효진 씨는 똑똑한 데다가 공부도 열심히 해요.
en: In addition to being smart, Hyojin studies a lot, too.
notes: "-ㄴ/는 데다가" means "in addition to".

ko: 이 식당은 시끄러운 데다가 맛도 없어요.
en: Not only is the restaurant noisy, the food's also not good.

ko: 경화 씨는 친구가 많은 데다가 하는 일도 많아서 만나기 어려워요.
en:
In addition to having a lot of friends, Kyung-hwa also does lots of things, so it’s difficult to
meet her.
notes: -는 데다가 is often followed by -서 to express some kind of conclusion or result.

ko: 목이 좀 아픈 데다가 콧물도 나요.
날씨가 쌀쌀한 데다가 비까지 많이 와서 호텔에만 있어서 재미없었어.
en: Not only was it chilly, but it also rained a lot, so I was bored just staying inside the hotel.

ko: 그런 것은 아니지만 아무 약이나 드시면 안 되니까요.
en: That's not true, but you should be careful about what kind of medicine you take.
It looks like they are going to start now.
notes: -려나 보다 = -려고 하나 보다

en: It looks like she’s planning to go on a trip with her family.
I am sorry but there is no choice for me but to do it this way.

ko: 어제 술을 많이 마셔서 오늘 피곤할 수밖에 없어요.
en: He drank a lot yesterday, so he’s bound to be tired today.
I went there during winter and it was warmer than in Korea.
notes: "-더군요" is similar to "-던데요", it is also used to describe your experiences that you found surprising or interesting. "-더군요" is more formal and used less often than "-던데요".

ko: 세계에 홍콩만큼 야경이 아름다운 도시는 없습니다.
유행에 뒤떨어지지 않으려면 옷을 자주 살 수밖에 없어요.
en: If I am to keep up with fashion trends, then I have no choice but to buy clothes often.

ko: 환경을 보호하지 않으면 앞으로 인류는 멸망할 수밖에 없을 거예요.
en: If we don't protect the environment, mankind will be unable to avoid extinction.

ko: 일을 미뤘다가 한꺼번에 하니까 힘들 수밖에 없지요.

en: I'm really anxious today (unlike other days).
notes: "-따라" is usually attached to nouns describing a time period, and it means that this time is different from other times.

ko: 어렵기는 하지만 마음만 먹으면 시간을 내는 건 가능하던데요.
en: It is difficult but you can find the time if you really put your mind to it.
No, now that I started to learn it I've discovered it's easier than I thought.

ko: 남산에서 본 서울 야경이 아주 아름답던데요.
옷장에 옷이 이렇게 많은데도 또 옷을 산다고?
en: You've got all these clothes in the closet, but you want to buy more?
notes: "-은데도" is a combination of 은/는데 and 아/어도.

ko: 어제 푹 잤는데도 오늘 많이 피곤하네요.
en: Even though I slept well, I'm really tired today.

ko: 생활비가 부족한데도 친구들에게 술을 자꾸 사 주잖아요.
직장 생활을 한 지 꽤 되었는데도 돈을 많이 못 모았어요.
en: Even though I've worked for a while now, I haven't been able to save up a lot of money.

ko: 조사 결과에 따르면 등산을 제일 많이 한대요.
en: According to survey results, the most popular activity is hiking in the mountains.

ko: 여가 활동이란 일을 하고 남는 시간을 활용하여 하는 활동을 말합니다.
en: Leisure activities are the things you do when you're not working.

ko: 또한 여가 시간이란 직장 생활과 공부로부터 벗어난 자유로운 시간을 말합니다.
notes: "-로부터" means "from" and can replace 에서 or 에게서.

ko: 현대인들은 자신에게 맞는 적절한 여가 활동을 통해 일상생활에서 받는 스트레스를 풀고 건강하게 살려고 노력합니다.
notes: "-를 통해(서)" means "through" or "by way of".

ko: 박영민 씨가 성실하니까 박영민 씨가 가게 하세요.
en: Pak Yeongmin is dependable so make him go.
notes: "-게 하다" means to make someone do something (or be something).

ko: 아이가 운동이나 음악 등 달은 것에 관심을 갖게 하세요.
en: Try to make him interested in other things like sports or music.

ko: 한 시간이나 기다리게 하면 어떻게 해요?
en: How could you make me wait for a whole hour?

ko: 양강 씨는 저를 너무 행복하게 해요.
항상 약속 시간을 안 지켜서 저를 화나게 하거든요.
개인적인 질문을 많이 해서 저를 당황스럽게 하거든요.

en: Make him sit farther away from the TV.

ko: 교통이 복잡해서 불편한 반면에 문화생활을 즐길 기회가 많아서 좋아요.
en: I like it even though the streets are crowded because there are many opportunities to enjoy the culture.
notes: "-은/는 반면(에)" is used to express contrast. Often it's used to express the positive and negative aspects of the same thing.

ko: 좋은 공연이 많은 반면에 관람료가 너무 비싸요.
en: While there are many nice performances, the admission fees are very high.

ko: 일은 많은 반면에 월급은 적어서 회사를 옮길까 해요.
en: There's a lot of work to do, but the pay is low, so I'm considering changing jobs.

ko: 부탁을 많이 하는 반면에 도움도 많이 줘요.
이 책은 얇은 반면에 내용이 어려워서 생각보다 오래 걸려요.
서울은 교통이 편한 반면에 공해가 심하거든요.
그 반면에 물가가 비싸서 생활비가 너무 많이 들어요.
en: On the other hand, living there costs a lot of money.

ko: 합격한 회사에 갈까 말까 고민 중이에요.
en: I can't decide whether to take the job I was offered or not.

ko: 잘 모르겠지만 주말에 관람객이 많으니까 아마 문을 열걸요.

en: Which places are you thinking of visiting?

ko: 흐엉 씨도 올 수 있냐고 물어보던데 같이 갈 거죠?
en: She also asked if you will attend. You'll come with me, right?
notes: -던데 can also be used in the middle of the sentence. In this case, it indicates the past.

en: He asked us to reduce our electricity usage.

ko: 그리고 컴퓨터를 꼭 끄고 퇴근하라고 하셨어요.
en: And he told us to turn off our computers before going home.

ko: 제이슨 씨, 유키 씨한테서 들었는데 요즘 태권도를 배운다면서요?
고백할 용기가 없어서 지금은 바라보기만 할 뿐이에요.
en: I don't have the courage to declare my love so for now I can only watch him from afar.
notes: "-ㄹ 뿐이다" is used when there is only one available course of action or state of being.

ko: 오늘 회의를 8시간이나 했는데 결정된 것은 없고 시간만 보냈을 뿐이에요.
en: Today's meeting lasted a whole eight hours with nothing getting decided. We did nothing but waste time.

ko: 괜찮아요. 그냥 기운만 조금 없을 뿐입니다.
en: I'm not sick, I just don't have a lot of energy.

ko: 글쎄요. 저는 그냥 일만 열심히 할 뿐입니다.
en: I didn't do anything special to get promoted, I just work hard.
I just read a history book.

ko: 일 년에 겨우 서너 번뿐인데요, 뭐.
en: I only do it three or four times a year.

ko: 과장님이 이번 주까지 일을 끝내라고 하는 바람에 요즘 너무 정신이 없었어.
제가 서울에 온 지 1년 정도 됐을 때였어요.
en: I had been in Korea for about a year (at that point in time).

ko: 남자는 말을 직설적으로 하는 반면에 여자는 말을 돌려서 한다.
아이들이 놀다 보면 유리창을 깰 수도 있지요.
en: Glass windows are apt to be broken once boys start playing around.
notes: "-다 보면" means that if you do the first part for a while, the second part will also happen.

ko: 일을 하다 보면 금방 방법을 알게 될 거니까 너무 걱정하지 마세요.
en: Don't worry because you'll learn how to do it once you start working.

ko: 이런 얘기를 듣다 보면 나라는 달라도 사람들 생각은 비슷한 것 같아.
한국 친구를 많이 사귀어서 어울리다 보면 즐거워질 거예요.
그렇게 담배를 많이 피우다 보면 건강이 나빠질 텐데 걱정이네요.
제가 신발을 벗었더니 친구 어머니가 웃으시면서 신발을 신고 들어와도 된다고 말씀해 주셨습니다.
노래를 한번 듣거나 이 그룹이 나온 프로그램을 본 사람은 다 반하게 되어 있어요.
en: Anyone who hears them sing or sees them on TV is bound to love this group.

ko: 아무리 게을러도 손님이 오면 청소를 하게 되어 있어요.
en: No matter how lazy you are, you are bound to clean the house when a guest comes.

ko: 영원한 비밀은 없어요. 사람들이 알게 되어 있어요.
en: There are no eternal secrets. People eventually find out.

ko: 표를 못 사서 경기장에 가는 대신에 집에서 보기로 했어.
온라인 게임의 문제는 아이들이 게임에 빠지기 쉽다는 것입니다.

en: I don't know, it's a bit far for walking.

ko: 예쁘기는 한데 오늘 같은 날씨에 입기에는 추울 것 같아요.
en: It's pretty, yes, but today is too cold for you to wear it.

ko: 게다가 관람 시간도 길지 않아서 아이들이 보기에 지루하지 않을 겁니다.
notes: They're talking about a play

ko: 오늘 저녁에 콘서트 보러 갈 거냬요.
en: He's asking if we're going to the concert tonight.

ko: 퇴근 후에 회사 앞 커피숍에서 만나재요.
예전에는 책 읽는 것 같았는데 이렇게 연기가 늘다니 정말 놀랐어요.
en: I was really surprised her acting had improved so much, it seemed like she was reading from a book before.
notes: "-다니" is used when you are really surprised or can't believe something the other person just said. It can be attached in two ways - either to the reported speech form (간다니) or to the dictionary form (가다니).

ko: - 건강하던 민수가 병에 걸렸대요.- 그래요? 그렇게 건강하던 민수가 병에 걸리다니 믿을 수 없어요.

en: He's the president? Not the deliveryman?
notes: "-다니" can change to "-라니" and other forms, depending on which type of sentence you are quoting. It can also be used at the end of a sentence.

en: You already want to go? It's just 11 p.m.
It was only his first play and he got an award!

ko: 내가 유키한테 네 표도 같이 예매해 달라고 할게.
en: I will ask Yuki to get your ticket as well.

ko: 그렇게 멋진 리듬을 만들다니 놀라서 입을 다물 수가 없었다.

en: You should have checked the expiration date before drinking it.
You should have reported the card as lost right away.
You should have checked the pockets before washing them.
There's no way it's still there.

ko: 만약 타임머신이 있다면 언제로 가고 싶어요?
en: Which time would you like to go to if there was a time machine?
notes: If you add "-면" after the plain form, it shows a hypothetical situation that has a much lower chance of happening than if you use the simple "-면".

ko: 동물과 대화할 수 있다면 뭘 하고 싶어요?
en: What would you do if you could talk to animals?

ko: 복권에 당첨된다면 멋진 자동차를 사고 싶어요.
en: If I were to win the lottery, I'd buy a fancy car.

ko: 제가 한국에 오지 않았다면 아키라 씨를 만나지 못했을 거예요.
en: If I hadn't come to Korea, I would not have met Akira.
notes: The plain form + "-면" can be used with the past tense to talk about situations that didn't happen.

ko: 50년 후에는 사람 대신에 로봇이 일을 할지도 몰라요.
en: In 50 years, robots might be doing work instead of people.
notes: "-ㄹ지도 모르다" is used to say that something might happen.

ko: 50년 후에는 전 세계 사람들이 공통 언어를 사용할지도 몰라요.
en: In 50 years, the whole world might speak in one language.

ko: 장마철이잖아요. 장마철에는 갑자기 비가 올지도 몰라요.
en: It's the rainy season. It might start raining suddenly.

ko: 요즘 일이 많아서 다 못 읽었을지도 몰라요.
en: There's so much to do these days that he may not have finished reading it yet.

ko: 혹시 길을 잃어버릴지도 모르니까 지도도 꼭 챙기세요.
en: You might get lost so be sure to pack a map.

ko: 요즘 이사하느라고 정신이 없어서 약속을 잊어버렸을지도 몰라요.
en: He might have forgotten about the promise because he's so busy moving to a new place.

ko: 그 소식 들었어요? 그 배우가 결혼할지도 모른대요.
그 배우가 결혼한다면 많은 여자들이 실망하겠어요.
중학교 때 다리를 다치지 않았다면 축구를 계속했을 거예요.
일찍 일어났더라면 비행기를 놓치지 않았을 거예요.
en: If I had gotten up earlier I wouldn't have missed the plane.
notes: "-았/-었더라면" is used to talk about past situations that could have happened (but didn't happen).

ko: 공부를 열심히 했더라면 시험을 잘 봤을 텐데 정말 후회돼요.
미리 예매했더라면 공연을 볼 수 있었을 거예요.
en: If we had purchased them in advance, we could have seen the show.

ko: 생일인 줄 알았더라면 선물을 준비했을 텐데요.
en: If I had known it's her birthday, I would have prepared a gift.
